Best game ever

No game has captured the fantasy of learning martial arts like this one.  It starts off brutal, and you will die many times, likely getting a game over by stage 3. Unless you're a master of the genre, you will struggle to "git gud" and look for every shortcut and advantage you can get...

But eventually, as you go back to prior levels to try to beat them with fewer deaths (so you'll have more to spare later), you'll notice that you ARE improving at the game. Until eventually, you have that Matrix moment of "I know kung fu" and start to clear levels with no deaths at all.

And then the game will throw a new challenge at you and taunt you with it.  And when you overcome it, a new one will stand in your way, with one in particular taking away your most powerful crutch and telling you "Nah, you want to finish the game?  Do it for real.  No cheap tricks."

And even after that, another challenge still opens up...But by then...You'll be ready for it.  And you will look back at the journey and see how much you've mastered the game.

Sifu is brutal, yes. It's going to punish you for every mistake, it's going to humble you repeatedly, and even tell you to go back to the start and pursue a new set of upgrades entirely... But boy does it make this journey of vengeance a blast, as you go from struggling to fight the hordes of enemies to outclassing entire rooms without taking a hit.

This game is marketed as a Beat-them-up fighting game. IT IS NOT, it is actually closer to a music rhythm game than an actual brawling/fighting game. 

Most of this game consists of memorizing enemy's attack instead of reacting/forcing an enemy to behave a certain way. What do I mean by this?  Well, you get barely any feed back from your actions. The difference between a perfectly parried attack and a parried attack are almost unnoticeable. Same with the difference between a perfect dodge and a failed dodge, only feed back you get is that your "Structure" bar hasn't filled up. The non existent enemy attack telegraphing is also not doing this game any favors. Sure you might get more satisfaction from finally be able to (sometimes) dodge their attacks, it is not what most people expect from the trailers and marketing.

Your attacks are not really attacks, it's more like initiating a section of a rhythm game and use combo. I've hit the guy like 4 times, he is staggered, I should move in and finish him off right? Nope! He snaps back to his combo instantly because he hasn't finished all the attacks in that combo. You have to WAIT till he finishes his combo, no matter if you spin kick him in the face, chain punch him in the throat or jab him with a machete, he WILL not care until he finishes his combo!

Your actions do so much less than in other fighting games, you never truly feel the impacts of your hits. As a person who's trained in martial arts and had to use it in real life, I can tell you with confidence that people do not recover from a lot of the attacks you do in the game that easily. You can NOT approach this game with the mentality of a fighting game, it is NOT.

If you like stylish kongfu dance-off that expects you to grind through the same few areas again and again and again whith barely sufficient guidance as to how most of the game mechanics work to memorize the ridiculously short/unclear dodge windows, go ahead, You'll love this one. If you want a real Beat-them-up or Souls-like game, this is not the game you are looking for

Your enjoyment of this entirely depends on what kind of challenge you like.

This isn't "Dark Souls hard" or "combos in fighting games hard," but an odd mix of both of those things at about half power each. Me, I like both of those kinds of challenges, so I think this game's the s**t. 5 out of 5 for me. But if you get frustrated easily or don't like focusing on improving at a game, this might not be the one. I've never booted up Sifu thinking I was about to have a lil chill sesh, I boot it up to sweat my way through some sick fistfights and hard as f**k boss battles. Be self-aware going in.

If you're still down, the story is honestly the only real major stumble here, it's somewhat lacking in delivery. As cool as the age/death system is, they also don't do a great way of conveying how it works in regards to level-to-level progression, or that you can basically "start over" by selecting The Squats at the stage select. Neither of those things is going to get in the way of what you're here for, though. The fighting is fantastic, the progression is steady, and the animations are captivating. Finishing this game keeping your character in their 20's provides a real sense of accomplishment that few other games can provide, and it's very possible.

BE ADVISED: Permanent unlocks are key. Don't worry about decking out your skill tree every run. Pick 2 or 3 skills to go in on at a time and work on not only unlocking them but actually using them consistently. This will help you learn. You're not going to beat the game on your first run, or your fifth one, or maybe even your tenth one. Trust the process.

Glad it's finally here instead of the EGS, I don't mind paying twice but let's not make the same mistake next time, hm? Bonus points for keeping the additional content free.

Let me just start with this thorough review by saying: I think this is one of the best games of all time. This review will contain some story spoilers, mostly talking about the beginning of the game and a LOT of gameplay spoilers.

Sifu is a 3rd person brawler/beat 'em up game with a lot of mechanics borrowed from other games and implemented very well, your objective is to go through each level defeating all sorts of enemies with different attack patterns and statistics. You start off by playing as the villain in the game as you go through your former martial arts school, with his henchmen defeating any person that gets in the way until at last you face your former sifu. You defeat and kill him and that's when the game introduces the main character of this game by making you choose as a boy or a girl. One of the main villain's henchmen kills you but since you were holding a special powerful pendant, you come back to life. Main character then trains hard for 8 whole years with revenge in his mind (I'm gonna call the main character "Him" because that's what I chose, but you can be a man or a woman at will and change whenever you desire).

So the game has very complex mechanics and the gameplay seems simple at first until you dwelve deep into it, let's start by separating them: You have your classic light attacks and heavy attacks which you can combine to perform different combos, some skills require to hold said button or make a pause before pressing it again to perform a different skill. You have a Focus bar which let's you perform specific powerful attacks that cannot be avoided or interrupted and you have a Structure bar that works almost exactly as the Posture bar in Sekiro where if it's filled because you got attacked a lot before you could recovered it, you get stunned and vulnerable, enemies also have a structure bar and when you break them, they are vulnerable to a takedown which is free and will (almost always, depending on the enemy) defeat them. You gain back health by defeating enemies. There are 4 ways you can avoid damage in the game and each of them have their own purpose and risk: Dodge, Avoid, Parry and Block.

Dodge: By pressing the dodge button, main character does a dash in the direction you're going, it's a great way to avoid damage and creating space between your enemies but doesn't give you any benefit in exchange other than: You didn't get hit.

Avoid: By holding the Block button and then moving up, down, left or right you can avoid a specific attack depending on where is the enemy is attacking you and if you done it successfully, you will gain Focus, regain Structure and the enemy attack slows down just enough time to give you a chance to counter attack. Much better way to deal with enemies than just dodging because it rewards you for the risk.

Parry: By tapping the Block button just before you get hit you can parry the enemy attack and depending what attack it is you can leave your opponent vulnerable and it eats their Structure. Parrying also leads to specific skills or combos you can perform, it also prevents all damage from being taken. The risk of parrying is doing it too much will build up your own Structure.

Block: By just holding the Block button will block all damage from being taken that is not dealt by a weapon, a weapon will only deal reduced damage if you happen to block it instead of parrying it. I do not recommend blocking in any instance of the game whatsoever, I think it's better to practice parrying and avoiding better. Blocking eats your structure like crazy very easily and does not consume the opponent's.

There are occasions where the enemy might do a powerful attack which can be identified by both a sound cue and orange colour coming out of their arm or leg when they do it. These attacks can be blocked or parried, blocking will almost always result in your structure being broken and parrying will result in your structure being consumed a bit, depending on the attack. Enemies can also be stunned which also are identified with a sound cue and a visual cue. Alright so by knowing all that you begin to experiment all those attacks and ways of countering your enemies and they are dealt with differently depending, but all enemies have their own patterns and they stick to them. This is a hard game at it's core, but it's extremely fair.

So the game has this very strange but very well made mechanic about what happens when you die that is hard to understand at first but after a bit, it makes sense. You start the game at the age of 20, whenever you die the game gives you a chance to spend your XP points on skills and also an opportunity to revive at a cost of you getting older, so if you die at 20, you will revive by turning 21 and increasing the death counter by 1. Depending on the Death Counter, you will age by that number each time you decide to revive, you can decrease that number by defeating specific strong enemies and by defeating bosses and boss phases. When you buy a skill, you keep it until you decide to restart the level or go back to a previous one (when you restart a level or go back, you start said level with the youngest age you arrived at), every time you age by 10 years (20, 30, 40, etc.) you get a boost of damage and a nerf in health right up until you are at least 70 years old, whenever you turn at least that age, your pendant breaks and you cannot revive anymore, forcing you to restart if you die again. Whenever you do restart a level you lose all your skills unless you previously Permanently Unlocked them which you can do by buying said skill a total of 5 times.

All levels also have 3 shrines you can interact with that heal you completely and you can get 1 shrine ability each. These shrines' requirement depend on: Requiring to be at least a certain age, have a least X amount of points in the current level or spending XP points. Unlike the skills you get from spending XP, you cannot keep the shrine abilities if you decide to back to a previous level or restart the current one. You can only keep them if you move on to the next.

The game also has these collectibles and keys you can gather by exploring the levels that motivate you to go back to previous ones to uncover more of the lore and unlock shortcuts. Every level in the game is uniquely distinct from each other in a very beautiful artistic way, same with the bosses which are all very fun and challenging to fight, they will definitely test everything you learn. The game also has 3 difficulties which vary in how much health you have, how much damage you deal and how aggressive enemies are, I personally chose Master (hard) difficulty and absolutely recommend it if you want a challenge. Also this game has a bunch of martial arts movie references if you're into that.

This game does something not a lot of games do well which is motivate me to become better at it and master it, which I can say I am close to doing so after already beating it without dying once on Master difficulty and getting all 3 stamps in every single Arena. Arenas are specific challenges separate from the story mode that vary in objectives and they are a lot of fun, specially after the last update that added a bunch of them, definitely making the game highly replayable.

This game went from one of the hardest challenges I ever done to being my comfort game that I play every once in a while after mastering it. I recommend anyone giving it a chance, if you're struggling be patient, be determined and learn from your mistakes, that's how you beat this game and it feels great.

This game is everything I want in an indie title: style, substance, and polish. The game looks beautiful, and there were so many moments throughout that made my jaw drop. This game is a work of art. Mastery of lighting, volumetrics, and space are shown as you traverse each level, giving a radically different feel despite having the same fundamental gameplay loop. 

Thankfully, the polish doesn't end in the environments, as the gameplay is top-tier as well. You will feel like an action hero, and your own skill will determine which hero you're playing: from the one who barely makes it out alive, to the unbelievably powerful who never takes a hit. You'll feel like the game got easier, until you mistime a single attack or meet a new enemy, and become humbled once again.

Honestly amazing game, better than I expected. This game is all about combat, and it's fairly fast paced. You will have to dodge, backstep, sidestep, forward step, jump, and parry to avoid certain attacks, all while trying to weave in your own most devastating attacks and combos. The game will force you to learn to the play it through the bosses. Once you learn them you can certainly be incredibly aggressive, but they require you to know when and how to avoid attacks, and when to strike.

I unfortunately thought that the arenas were rather repetitive, and would have much preferred more levels to play through. I unlocked the first few arenas, then got bored.

Nevertheless, I had a great time playing this game. If you like difficult, fast, reflex-driven combat and are a soul-like fan, this is a fantastic game that is definitely worth giving a try!

With the 2nd Anniversary of this game having rolled around I felt inclined to put my two cents on this game out there, and it's simple: It's so unbelievably fun. A lot of people were put off by this game around the time it came out due to the difficulty, but Sifu's ace up its sleeve is that it's designed around that difficulty. Expect to be beaten down and age up over and over, but that's part of the learning curve, so don't feel bad if you suck, everyone does at first. This game makes you work for the power fantasy, and you feel like a badass when you nail it down. Along the way, you get new tools in the form of different moves or stat bonuses from shrines, which add to the variety. My only complaints are that I would've liked to see more enemy types and the stutter when you traverse to a new section can be a little jarring, but overall the game runs great, since it happens just when you load a new area.

If you're into games like Sekiro or Furi, this game will scratch that itch. 10/10

Sifu is just perfect in every way. 

It teaches you to become better. You fail, you learn. You miss, you see the consequences. It is not about who is perfect but who is the strongest. Those who leave are weak, those who stay and learn may find their strength.

Sifu is a game where balance and knowledge is the key to success, and of course, in real life too. You start up as a young person who knows how to move and attack. Yet, you feel weak due to lack of knowledge. You define your playstyle in your first moments. Then you see if it works or not. If it doesn't work, you have to change and find another way to complete each fight. 

Not only that, you have to bring a balance between being aggresive and defensive. What makes Sifu different from any other game is that no matter where you come from, you are destinated to fail. However, effort, resilience and dedication is what makes each gamer face. You are a gamer that doesn't respect your enemy, don't worry there will be another game that will give you that feeling. In Sifu, you are not Neo, you are a dude with human strength and movement. Knowing your limits is key, so, you realise what might go good or wrong.

In conclusion, it's a 10/10 game where it's more about knowledge and stress rather than jump-in kill everyone. Same as real life, you want to success? Great, respect each decision and respect others so you can have a gap to win. 

P.D.: I got all achievements and 77 hours, everyone can beat this game. Stay strong.

Part [i]Sekiro[/i], part old school beat'em up, part roguelite, all classic Kung-fu movie action.
Took under 20 hours to complete the full mission, including completing the board, including "secret" ending, on easy mode. Skills acquired carry over to "medium" mode so it constantly feels like you're growing as a character and building on your failures.
The story is a classic revenge plot. I normally skip all dialogue in games, because I don't care about the plot and they're usually drawn out and boring, but I found myself actually watching all the cutscenes.

Definitely worth full price, especially if you like the difficulty challenges of Souls-like games where you have to learn enemy types and movesets to be successful. Plenty of hidden features, content, and challenges, for longer replayability. The average player could easily spend 20 - 30 hours in this game; the completionist types, and challenge seekers, can easily spend upwards of 100+.

I really wanted to like this game , and I did up to the end of the 3rd stage. This game definitely peaks at the Museum, but I found the Tower and Sanctuary to be a lot shorter and duller. It almost feels like the devs had to rush to get it finished or something. The last two boss fights are also extremely underwhelming and are just poorly designed. The game trains us to use focus powers and yet you cant use them in the last fight. You know, the challenge that is the culmination of all the fights before?

On another note, I don't know if this game is just poorly optimized, but it's the first game that has nearly bricked my PC twice! This is not a game with high graphical fidelity and yet it crashes regularly in the last two stages with a VRAM overload exception and renders my entire computer unresponsive until I hard-reset it. RTX2070 super, drivers up to date, verified game files. Never had this issue before, even when running more demanding games like Cyberpunk 2077. 

It's too bad this game falls off for me at the midpoint, but I was really impressed with it for 3 of the 5 stages. I recommend getting it on deep-deep sale.

Sifu is one of the best fighting/beat'em up games I have ever played, and the fact that players can mod their characters is absolute perfection. I did Mai Shiranui, my favorite female fighting game character. Sifu is challenging by keeping players on their toes, especially when failing an area and wanting more by learning new techniques. Each time you die, the AI changes tactics to see if the player has learned anything, thus forcing players to learn new strategies to overcome the obstacles. I highly recommend this fighting gem for gamers who want a fun challenge.

I think a controller will save your keyboard from rage induced/confused key mashing. I only recommend this game to people that genuinely enjoy fighting games and wanna get better at it.

I cannot say how much fun I am having with this game. The controlls are responsive and fluid. The skill floor is very obtainable and the skill ceeling is so high that there's always room to improve. While I still maintain that the Disciple difficulty is the most balanced one I do appriciate the master a lot, really made me work on structure management and tight parries.

In terms of overal difficulty I would say it isn't very harsh game...unless you're playing on master at which point the game will kick you in the balls and throw you out the door... but you are almost certain to go back inside for another round.

The arena challenges provide tons of additional content that's bound to keep you entertained.

The basic moveset is very nice and flexible and the alternative movesets and just alternative moves are a very welcomed change of pace if you feel bored with the original. Come to think of it all the random modifiers are pretty fun to mess around with.

One mild point of critisism is that sometimes you can encounter very strange bugs. Such as getting stuck on piece of geometry next to a wall and if the enemies send you flying you'll hit the wall at termial velocity killing you instantly. Also it is sad you cannot make the enemies go into supercharged mode or carry weapons in the training room, it would help out bunch to figure out the timings on them.

I would very much like to see Sifu 2 one day. Perhaps expand the weapon roster, enemy variablity or shrine rewards where some rewards are just way too useless to pick them once you figure out which are important.

For the record, I beat the game on the medium difficulty (the only one it originally released with, apparently).

They were so close to something great, but they ruined it with awful boss fights that entirely break up the fun with misery, and honestly just boredom. The group fights actually rule but the bosses aren't just "git gud scrub" difficult. They entirely break the rules of the game itself. You can smack them over the head with a baseball bat and it just doesn't matter, they're still going to keep their combo going. They don't feel good to fight because even blows that land still don't even feel like you did anything.

The first phase of the third boss is particularly egregious. She does circular swings with a bladed weapon, so you can't even reliably block them. She has an attack with no recourse and it will almost entirely continue until you get hit. Yes you can parry it but you'll have to parry between 3 and 6 blows as it continues long after you decide to face it.. If you run away, she can chase you at the exact speed of your sprint.

The final boss has an unacceptably stupid caveat. Your focus attacks, which you may have thus far structured your entire build around, just don't work. The game gives you a tool, encourages you to rely on it, and then takes it away for the final fight. It's not fun. It's not good game design. It's just miserable, slow, and boring. There's really nothing interesting or fun about the last fight which kind of makes it the worst of all. You can literally just brute force it by running in, light attack to provoke, then spam block, and then once his string of attacks is done then go back and light attack again. Thankfully you don't have to perfect Yang, so you can kind of just brute force this technique. Because he does more unparryable attacks in his second phase, you'll take more damage but as long as you went in young enough it's easy. I went in at 34 and finished him at 61 and didn't have any fun and didn't feel like I learned a thing.

Because the structure of this game ensures that you have to replay levels to near perfection, I've had to beat the worst bosses a dozen times. It wasn't fun once. Unlike soulslike bosses, who are actually very fun once you figure out how to fight them. This game forces you to replay levels whether you find them fun or not and in fact, the less fun you find it, the more you're going to have to play that level. The levels themselves are very fun, but you only really do them each once because you'll eventually get a shortcut that makes them much shorter and you run almost straight to the boss, at which point you start grinding.

The structure of the game ensures that you will spend the most time miserable repeating the least fun activities it has to offer.

If you're seeking punishment that feels arbitrary, this is the game for you. If you're looking for something that feels fun to get good at, this just isn't worth it in comparison to other brutal games that feel good to play. The combat here is excellent, but it's so simple that the only way to make it difficult is to introduce enemies that go outside of how the combat is supposed to work. That's a fake difficulty.

I also failed to mention the performance issues. I like the aesthetic of the game, but it is low poly and should be able to run on a PS2. Instead, it actually stutters quite a bit on my 5800x/3080 gaming PC. I originally experienced these stutters on my Steam Deck so I figured it was just a little bit poorly optimized but it obviously has something pretty wrong.

Sifu is an excellent martial arts action game with a rogue-lite-ish(?) flair. You take the role of a nameless protagonist on a mission of revenge through 5 excellent missions as you hunt down the killers responsible for your fathers death. The moment to moment gameplay here is superb. It shares a lot of DNA with many other beat 'em up games, typically invoking the names of the Batman: Arkham series or the more recent Spider-Man game. It improves upon that formula, though, with a slightly more involved dodge system, an excellent set of combos, and stamina/posture breaking mechanics. Those new additions coupled with fantastic animations and combat encounters that severely punish mistakes creates a very satisfying gameplay loop that feels fresh through the 10-15 hour runtime.

It is a fairly difficult game, but not unmanageable. The previously mentioned rogue-lite-ish mechanics do a good job of providing meaningful progression throughout difficult runs. [b]Ultimately, I think Sifu is a must play for anyone craving a good martial arts action experience, as long as you aren't afraid of a bit of a challenge.[/b]

People talk about how hard this game is, but after a few hours you will really start to understand how the dodge / parry system works and once you start unlocking some additional abilities and combos you will be feeling like John Wick in no time.  This game makes you feel like the hero in a Kung Fu action movie.  The loop of getting better is so satisfying.

This boss felt so unfair at first and like I would never be able to do it.  After dying a few times and finally killing her I spent some time in training mode against her and really dialed in her patterns.

When I go through the level she is now almost the easiest part compared to some of the elite minions and it's honestly so fun to man handle this boss that at first felt impossible.  

For old heads, this game gives me Bushido Blade 2 vibes a bit.  Memories of the 100 ninja challenge come to mind.

Turn on some good music (John Wick soundtrack works great) and get ready to beat some ass.  But make sure it's a cathartic ass beating with vengeance set aside if you want the good ending =P

Sifu is a breathtaking journey through the world of martial arts that seamlessly blends intense action, strategic combat, and a captivating narrative. From the moment I stepped into the shoes of the protagonist, I was hooked by the game's unique blend of traditional kung fu and modern gaming elements.

The combat system in Sifu is nothing short of phenomenal. Every punch, kick, and block feels incredibly responsive and fluid, allowing players to string together complex combinations with ease. The learning curve is steep, but mastering the art of combat is an immensely satisfying experience. Each encounter feels like a dance, where timing and precision are key to overcoming challenging foes.

The aging mechanic adds an intriguing layer to the gameplay. Instead of the typical respawn system, death results in the protagonist aging, making each life lost a valuable lesson. This unique twist adds a sense of urgency and consequence, making every encounter a high-stakes battle.

Visually, Sifu is a work of art. The environments are richly detailed, capturing the essence of various martial arts schools and urban settings. The character models and animations are top-notch, immersing players in a world that feels both authentic and stylized.

The narrative is compelling, weaving a tale of revenge, redemption, and the consequences of one's actions. The character development is well-executed, and the story unfolds organically as you progress through the game. The emotional depth of the narrative enhances the overall experience, making it more than just a showcase of impressive combat mechanics.

Sifu is not without its challenges, and some may find the difficulty level demanding. However, for those willing to invest the time and effort, the rewards are well worth it. The sense of accomplishment that comes from mastering the intricate combat system and overcoming formidable adversaries is unmatched.

In conclusion, Sifu is a true gem in the world of martial arts gaming. It successfully combines stunning visuals, engaging storytelling, and a revolutionary combat system to deliver an unforgettable experience. If you're a fan of challenging games with deep combat mechanics and a compelling narrative, Sifu is a must-play that will leave you craving for more.
Unless you got a shit ton amount of time to just waste on one game I wouldn't get this game. Plus the camera is just an infuriating mess.

Ahhh this is definitely a fun game, but I just can't recommend it. If you have nothing to do with 100+ hours of your life and you wanna get good at something you could play this, or alternatively you could pick an actual real world skill to practise and consider how far along you'd be with that in 100 hours. How good would you be at drawing after 100 hours? How good would you be at guitar after 100 hours? It feels bad to have to sink so much time into a skill that is useful for this one game, and you will eventually stop playing it.

I'm enjoying it, but I think I have to stop playing. It's just too chaotic. There's no real way to consistently play this game flawlessly without cheesing. The enemy attack patterns can be a total 50/50 a lot of the time where if their combos are going to continue or stop completely, or attack high/low. Being surrounded is difficult, and while not impossible it will take 25+ hours to sink into the game to actually master getting out of that relatively unscathed, and that's just for being surrounded with the basic gangster enemies. There's no real way to evolve into the extended combos that you want to do as well. I think of other games like Mortal Kombat and Devil May Cry which tend to have pop-up abilties to extend your combos and it's a lot of fun, but here if you're not just cheesing and pushing enemies against a wall repeatedly then they will automatically start blocking your strings, or even parry them automatically at end of a string leaving to wide open.

While I have had a lot of fun, ultimately my problem with this game is the same problem I have with Souls-like games. Patterns are purposefully hard to read and master as an artificial way to extend game play. That mixed with the 50/50s on opponent combos just leaves you feeling unsatisfied in the end. You can't perform long combos. You just have to take small digs at opponents before being forced to go back into blocking cos you know they're about to automatically block you instead. So your options are to take 1 punch and push the enemy into a wall, and do that on repeat until you can executed them, or if there is no wall you can take 1 punch and trip them up and then beat them on the floor and repeat that again and again, or you can wait to block/dodge an opponent precisely and do a string with maybe 2-6 more attacks, which include trips and wall pushing anyway. So you're not doing anything unique.

There's a lot of things about the UI that are irritating as hell as well. You can't just exit back to your home base from inside the game. You have to give up on the current mission and then that returns you to the level menu and then you have to go back to the home base from the level menu, taking you through 3 different load screens. I don't understand why you can just jump from in-game back to the base if you wanna go into the training.
Similarly, if you die the age system is a good idea, but there is no "restart at last checkpoint" option even though each level has 3 checkpoints. You can actually just "give up" and exit the level and go back to the title screen and then load the level again and you'll pick up from a checkpoint without your age being damaged, so the ability to restart from checkpoints exists in the game but is not an actual option when you die. This prevents you from practising stages of a level. If you wanna "perfect" a level, you gotta restart allllll the way from the beginning again unless you wanna exit your current level after dying, go to the title screen, and then start the level again. Which includes 3 different load screens. This is a huge time sink.

The training mode is way too bare bones. I think it was very hastily thrown together in code. Training mode just pits you against 1-3 enemies of a certain type and they have no "structure bar" (which lets you 'exhaust' your opponents in a way before doing something bigger, like executing), and they recover much faster than normal enemies. So you can't really practise your comboing. You can only practise dodging and slipping in a couple shots. And even that is frustrating as i mentioned before cos a lot the enemy combo strings are 50/50s. So you're oftening just guessing "is this the end of the string?" or do you dodge up or down and get it wrong and get punished?

So sadly there is no real way to "master" this game. You'll find playthroughs online of people doing "no hit" runs, but they have to cheese the hell out of it with the abuse by pushing opponents into a wall. And the game is lacking some polish in terms of user-friendliness, which is desperately needed. Developers absolutely shouldn't overlook small things like improved training options or navigating through parts of the menu system quickly.

I had been told a lot about what to expect from Sifu in advance. I think this game is amazing. I think this game is fantastic. Visually, it's a grand achievement. Mechanically, it's flawless. It feels SO GOOD to play this game, to run through stages clowning on guards.

Despite being told much in advance, it exceeded my expectations anyway. Sloclap really knocked it out of the park on this one. 

I only have one complaint, and it's something that unfortunately does kind of kill the game for me after getting as far in as I am: after beating the game, you unlock [spoiler]a whole bunch of special conditions and cool unlockable gameplay things that add a ton of variety to what is available in the game and are SUPER fun in a huge way.[/spoiler]

I have a very direct, simple, but severe complaint about that system: [spoiler]actually USING any of these fun unlockables disables the ability to earn any more; you can't complete challenges or earn points from runs made with any of them active, including slight moveset tweaks that are 99% of the fun of those options. I was so excited to see I could make a move deck again like in Absolver or God Hand only to have my hopes crushed when I realized that actually doing so disables the ability to unlock anything else, which kind of undermines the point of playing at all for me. I want to do repeat runs to unlock more stuff, put up a higher score, not just for the sake of doing them at all.[/spoiler]

If anyone knows of any mod/etc. that fixes this, I would greatly appreciate it. As-is, the game is still amazing despite this one complaint. I highly recommend it. If you enjoy martial arts movie-styled gameplay you're going to love this game.

One more note: a lot of people play up this game's difficulty. Listen. It has a little bit of a learning curve, yes. But I have faith in you. If I was able to beat the game and get the true ending in 20 hours, you can do it too. You've got this. The process of learning is to figure out why you got hit by an attack and then figure out what you have to do not to get hit by that attack - you have a bunch of defensive options available. Get that down and you're golden. It's really that simple, and it's not as hard as you think.

This game is very fun, but there is one BIG issue...VRAM memory leaks. When I start the game it's at 2500 MB, and 30 minutes later it's at 6500. If I play for more than 2 hours it will start running out of memory to even display elements of my desktop, and that's with an RTX 3080. Essentially, you have to restart the game every 30-60 minutes. This is something that I have seen people complain about since the game's release, yet still hasn't been fixed. 

That said, the game is actually quite fun. It's like a mashup of the hardcore "souls-like" elements and critical parrying of Sekiro and the environmental beat-em-up of Yakuza. The art style is great, the level design is memorable, the mechanics are engaging, the story is cool, and the Mandarin voice acting is quite nice. I started out playing on Master, which I only recommend if you are serious about challenging yourself. I have permanently unlocked (that means unlocked six times) more than half the skills and still haven't beaten the second boss. It's a hard game, but one where practice genuinely feels rewarding. Just like Sekiro, that feeling when you turn that first boss from an inexorable murder machine into a squealing whelp later on once you GIT GUD makes the entire experience worth it.

This is a fantastic game for anyone that has that "I want this game to hurt me emotionally" itch.

The difficulty ramp is mostly consistent, controls are tight, and the game play loop is satisfying (and upsetting when you're sucking). The story is a revenge tale with a couple of twists, and it hits just right for me. The stages are VERY interesting visually and the art style is gorgeous.

My suggestions for the devs:
1) The amount of times the game throws you into poorly lit arenas with half a dozen or more enemies can be infuriating. I'd like to see what's kicking my ass, thanks.
2) It'd be nice if the Training room would allow you to practice fighting the boss BEFORE you beat them (but after you meet them). It's frustrating to fight through an entire stage over and over only to get obliterated by boss moves you don't know how to counter. Also adding in life bars in training would be awesome!
3) Short unskippable cutscenes at the beginning of each stage...maybe it's just because I'm terrible, but I'm WAY too familiar with those painful 5 second long camera pans and would love to skip them after attempting a stage for the 10th time.
4) The camera is mostly good, though can be far too pulled in during fights in tight spaces.

Overall a wonderful game. Fully recommend to anyone looking for a challenge.

Sifu is one of my all-time favorite games, with its unique art style and gameplay mechanics that got me hooked immediately. Although the revenge story is relatively simple, the characters shine through with each line of degrading dialogue they spit at you during combat. I may not be a huge fan of kung fu or martial arts cinema, but this game makes you feel like you're living in one. The combat is incredible to say the least. One thing I have to say is that it can be difficult with the tight timing, but the death system gives you ample opportunities to learn if you're willing. It'll take around 10 hours to complete, although it obviously depends on how well you play. Please don't take this to mean that you shouldn't take your time to fully appreciate the experience. I do despise the camera angles sometimes, especially when you're next to a wall or in a group of enemies. If you're interested in gaining more content with mods since this is on the shorter side, there is a thriving modding community consistently releasing additions to Sifu. I would definitely recommend some of the Matrix mods or getting outfits such as Daredevil. I found Sifu to be worth the money and if you're into improving your skills like one might learn to play a song, I would heavily recommend this game. PLAY W/ MANDARIN OR CANTONESE AUDIO !!!

Enemies would telegraph their moves, but not long enough for me to comprehend. Going back to the game's complex moves, almost each attack has its own counter that needs to be pressed in a small time frame. If you use the wrong one, you might as well have not been touching the controller. Even after playing for a while, I felt it was very difficult to keep track of all the enemies around me and counter each one perfectly. Granted this can just be a "skill issue" that can be avoided by getting good, but it seems more unfair than other games. Sifu is a game that tests your ability in reflexes, decision making, and energy management. No same level will play the same. If you play inconsistently, the game would be much harder to predict. Enemy NPCs don't stick to one routine and tend to play out and spread their attack patterns sporadically which makes blocking all of it a hit or miss.

Overall, if you like martial arts, souls-like combat like Sekiro, and smooth animations, then this game is for you.

[h1] Spoiler-Free Sifu Review @ 64hrs, 100% achievements [/h1]


[h2] Sifu? More like see (my) foot before it hits your face [/h2] 

[b] Sifu [/b]is a one of a kind fighting-brawler game. It's actually not like other brawler games much. I would say it's more akin to Soulsborne games where it requires your full attention and patience to play well. You got your ala parry, dodge and counter attack timings. But boiling it down to just three elements is too simple. There's also the rhythm and the "zen state" that you learn to just enter. It's quite similar to Sekiro, to be honest, except you have two options to deal with offensives--dodging and parrying.

The game is broken down into "stages" where you have to infiltrate, beat up a bunch of angry Chinese kung-fu grunts and elites and bosses alike. Where it separates itself from most Souls games though, is that it encourages you to stay in the fight vs. dodge rolling. There isn't really a dodge roll in Sifu. It's more like a stand-in-place-become-an-I-frame-avatar dodge. So you have to deal with whoever's trying to land a punch on you either way.

There's a virtual progression in the game in the form of perks like extending your HP, getting more focus per hit, etc. but in my opinion, the true progression and level up happens within you (which is what makes these kinds of games great).


[h2] Highly Recommended...with some caveats [/h2]

If you know anything about Souls-seki-borne games, they're [b] notoriously hard[/b]. And you will die. You will die [b] a lot[/b]. They're hard for a reason. Sifu is slightly more forgiving than most Souls games. For one, there's a difficulty selector. That makes it quite accessible to a wider audience. However, even at the easiest difficulty, the game demands a level of mastery from the player that may or may not appeal to everyone. If you like progressing your own skill level as a player, you're gonna love Sifu a lot. However, if you're more into casual games (which aren't bad, by the way) you should think twice before getting Sifu due to it's pretty steep barrier-to-entry.

But, if you're up for the challenge, you should start the path to Sifu. I promise it'll be worth it in the end.

It's hard as nails and expects you to replay sections of the game multiple times to perfect each section, just in line with the kung fu theme; practice makes perfect. This results in a massively satisfying game loop once it clicks but can be quite frustrating until it does. Its incessant focus on the game mechanics themselves creates a product which is also highly replayable if that is important to you,  in some ways its  even more fun to replay it once you've mastered the controls. One thing not talked a lot about is the way the age works, and I'll explain the best way I can:
-Die:
What to do when dead = level up abilities/moves (you don't have to die to level them up, there are also altars)
 EITHER: Age up a year or more depending on what year you are currently. 
 OR: restart the stage at the age you started said stage at.
-WARNING: Age up too much ~70 you age out and have to restart the stage, thus a Gameover. You'll lose level, progress, and any NON-PERMANENT abilities/moves.
To make an ability/move PERMANENT simply level it up around five times. 
PERMANENT Abilities/Moves: You keep them no matter what per save.
 For example: If you gain a permanent on Stages 2-3, but want to be younger, you can retry Stage 1, and keep your Permanent Abilities.
RESETTING AGE: You can replay from stage 1 to update your age as long as you perform better than previously. (yes you can just replay stage 1 then go to stage 3, BUT it will just subtract the stage 2 years from the new stage 1 years)

Conclusion
====================
I wish it was longer, and at this point in my life that's high praise. It's really, really well made. No rough corners, no rushed design. It feels like it was made by passionate developers who took their time and refined it down to perfection. I think the only reason it isn't Overwhelmingly Positive is because 1.) It's short and 2.) It's difficult. Both of those are valid and true, so if you want something long or easy this isn't for you.

Overview
====================
It doesn't fit well into one genre. It's like you took the combat from the Arkham games and sprinkled a little bit of fighting game tech (nothing too difficult execution-wise). If you like combat in Arhkam games or Assassins Creed you'll like the fighting system here, but it's a bit more difficult (in a fun way, I promise).

The campaign that wraps it all up is a bit like a roguelite. If the aging mechanic sounds offputting to you, think of it like a roguelite instead. You can always replay a portion of the campaign to try to improve your "best run" and take the gains forward into the next level. No failure is permanent and the only wall you'll really hit is the kind of "git gud" wall you'd hit in a Souls game.

"It's difficult"
====================
Yeah, it is.... but I'm 33 years old and I beat it in about 10 hours. I have the advantage of having played every Souls game and having some fighting game experience... but that fighting game experience was just enough for me to realize I don't have the reactions to keep up with the kids :P . It's a challenge, and if you've never beaten a Souls game or competed in a fighting game I would still encourage you to try this game out, but urge you to embrace the challenge and fight the instinct to get frustrated when things aren't going your way. It IS beatable. It CAN be learned. If you sleep on it and come back the next day you'll make progress and it will feel good. If you're already into competitive games (without raging at them too hard :P), or perhaps you enjoy practicing martial arts or an instrument in real life, then you probably already have the mindset to enjoy this game.

"It's short"
====================
Yeah, it is. To me that's a plus. I'll take a game that leaves me wanting more over a game that bores me before I beat it any day of the week. It's like when you go to a fancy restaurant and the portions are small for the price. It's not a "value" meal. It's a rich, delicious, indulgent luxury meal. I promise, even if you end up frustrated by the difficulty of the combat, you won't find any other flaws. The visuals, the audio, the animations, the voice acting... It's just so refined. Like bonsai tree, it may be small but the amount of love and care that went into it makes it a true gem.

[h1]"His hands go out like [b][i]LIGHTNING[/i][/b]... and the other, doesn't want to fight anymore." [b]10/10[/b][/h1]

Every aspect of Sifu appeals to me in such glorious fashion, from the gameplay, story, the visuals, and OH most [i]definitely[/i] the music. I immediately copped this game on launch, clocking in about [b]108+[/b] hours of playtime (99h 56mins on Epic Games Store + 9 hours on Steam just to 100 percent it and write this review lol) after being so intrigued by its State of Play trailer appearance and have been following its progress since.

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
I'm a big sucker for 'die & try again' beat-em-ups (Hades, BloodBorne) but ooh boy, how this game has humbled me into thinking I was good at the much later levels. Each engagement is quick & snappy, leaving little room to improvise and more room to take the beatings and play on different strategies for the next run. 

Sifu's learning curve is the album cover for Arctic Monkey's [i]AM[/i], and you will generally feel more discouraged to give up than to continue, but with how the game is structured, which intends for players to replay the first four levels a good amount of times before reaching the big boss, the result is super rewarding. I have to admit, I did take notes on a couple of speedrunners to figure out which combos are best suited for each situation and enemy type but ultimately, you will inevitably develop the "right" way to fight and also end up utilising [i]every[/i] skill in your arsenal to gain the upper-hand for each encounter.

[h2]Story[/h2]
I wasn't familiar with the concept of Wude but I am a big fan of narratives transitioning from revenge plots to transforming into the better person type-beat stories. I love the idea, that the purpose of Kung Fu, devoid of militaristic intent, is not an art-form used to hurt other or be used in violent engagements. Our main character (I'm surprised they don't have a name lol), after witnessing his father's death; has festered an innate wrath for eight years, and went on a killing spree across the city. Initially, you'd be on board because its totally justified, however the principle of Kung Fu and the Eastern ideology of "pacifism unless provoked" is a much more endearing trait of character growth and maturity, which is fitting for a game that literally has you become wiser as you age from each death.

All the characters (yes, even you Jinfeng) are all such interesting and hapless creatures, each with a unique backstory that makes all of them worthy of sympathy. These five bosses aren't your typical cookie cutout villains, but victims of a cause that forced them to take matters into their own hands to eventually achieve their lifelong dreams, to which some ended up saving their lives, or diminished by it (Poor Fajar).
I feel like I would've appreciated the characters, their backstories, and intertwined relationships a bit more if the lore was more vocal about it, presentation wise; rather than just tidbit clues discoverable for the Detective Board. I was so intrigued about "The Guardians", Yang's tragedy and the lead up to our main story, to which I feel bummed out about how it couldn't be visually expanded but I understand that's not the direction they went with, yet I still find the end result enjoyable as always.

Also, I appreciate all the references to martial arts films and easter-eggs relating to popular martial-arts cinematic culture in game, it makes me so giddy every time I have one of the costumes equipped. Even though the fighting style is Pak-Mei, I can't help but draw comparisons to 'Ip Man', one of my favourite Chinese films and its comparable Wing Chun style.

[h2]Art & Music[/h2]
I usually pair these chapters in the Story section, but Sifu's Art and Sound Direction is too good to not be given its own praise. Howie Lee does an amazing job of composing intense feelings of rushing drive and determination in the music. Lee's background in the electronica/dance genre served extremely satisfactory in capturing the fast-paced, high-energy fight choreography that's present in each encounter. That, and the combination of elements derived from traditional Chinese instruments, as well as the addition of unorthodox sounds picked from their respective levels (e.g. train horn in The Squats), really amplifies the creative world-building and feeling of a fulfilled and alive environment.

Shout-out to Paul Emile-Boucher and the well-deserving art team for creating such a beautifully stunning art-style that's so aesthetically pleasing to look at [b]while I curb-stomp a fool on the edge of a table.[/b] The concept art-esque mix with semi-cartoon, oil painting style is such an creatively interesting approach, art-wise and game design wise. A game like Sifu could've definitely went along the photo-realistic route like most Souls-like entries, but instead, Sifu's art direction allowed to enhance its storytelling through the eased manipulation of the environment and interpretations of major concepts of each character without delivering an excess-use of dialogue (Kuroki's Museum is a perfect example of this and one of my favourite levels).
If you were to make an anime based on Sifu, keeping the art-style is a must.

[h3] TL:DR [/h3]
Sifu is a magnificently constructed action adventure, offering painstaking droves of challenging yet rewarding foes. Its unique "death = aging" mechanic provides all players of intermediate experience, a fighting chance to adapt from and improve upon their mistakes. [b]10/10[/b]

This is a HARD game. Expect Dark Souls level of frustration and repetition, but you have to "git gud" at kung fu. If this is your kind of thing, Sifu is an amazing game. Not too long, but lots of replay value if you like combo-heavy beat-em-ups with extremely challenging bosses that require intense concentration for the perfect run.

Sifu is one of those games that impressed me a lot with its art direction, action set pieces and the vibe of Hong Kong Kung Fu flicks. The lore is nothing to write laurels about but gets the job done. The strength of the game is the core gameplay loop with fluid action set pieces where something badass is always happening and its the player controlling the character doing it, not a prerendered cutscene.

The game has five different stages excluding the prologue and has a ton of replay value. Each stage is visually distinct as well as feature variety of enemy types. The stages offers a level of lore connectivity that makes replaying the same level albeit with a collectible from a future stage give more lore into the individual bosses as well as the overarching story.

The tutorial of the game does a not so good job of explaining the various defensive mechanics of the game. Each defensive mechanic is equally important however the tutorial seems to emphasize on parrying as the go to defensive mechanic. Remember to watch a tips and tricks short tutorial to derive maximum value out of the gameplay.

Definitely worth the price if you even remotely enjoyed flicks like Oldboy, Enter the Dragon, A Game of Death to name a few. Good OST, great artstyle, goated gameplay.

A 3D beat 'em up that emphasizes getting your ass kicked, getting back up, and learning. The kung-fu aesthetic is on point and really plays into the game's core design philosophy of learning through strife. 

The game can potentially be fairly short depending on how skilled you are, but even after beating the game and replaying for the "true" ending, the game's combat never once felt boring. The complexity and fluidity of the game's combat kept me engaged in every encounter, and when I was finally stringing together perfect parries, combos that ruin opponent's "structure", and environmental attacks, I felt a rush I haven't felt gaming in a while. I look forward to playing this game on the hardest difficult and learning more tech. This game friggin' rocks.

A fantastic action game that only does one thing, THE ACTION! And it does it so well!. Parries, counters, dodges, AI aggression, great group combat, great bosses, it has it all.

The campaign is short, but it will take time to master and there is a modifier system that lets you make your own custom difficulty.

And they have gone bananas with the challenge mode. If you like action games, this is a no brainer. GET IT!

Edit: I have also tested the entire campaign on Steamdeck. It runs essentially flawless on high settings, except minor stutters when going through new areas. This does not affect combat though.
Gitting gud is addictive. Starting over is like NG+ with perks but it's really just your skill. Make sure you mock your foes's weak kung fu for true immersion.

Sifu is a great game if you ignore the fact that the combat system is possibly one of the most unintuitive I have ever experienced. As a fan of Kung Fu films, there is a lot to love here if/when you can get yourself into a "flow" state of dodging/parrying/countering at the right time, but the moment you are not in that flow state, the game is more of a hassle to deal with than it is really worth. I'm also really not a fan of the resurrection mechanic or how you can only restore health from beating mini-bosses(and it doesn't always restore the same amount of health) or from doing a take down of the weaker enemies. I think the game would do very well with some health packs thrown in throughout the levels.

There are a lot of interesting mechanics that are a real downgrade from Absolver in terms of their execution.

~7 hour review: this is the most fun I've had getting my ass kicked in any game. Seriously. Hell, this is the most I've enjoyed a game in a few years that I can remember. Sifu is difficult with a fairly high skill curve so if that's not your jam then I'd say pass. It's not a "1 button press and you can get through it" type game. It's a "analyse the situation and try to remember the 30 or so button combinations to win properly. Also don't forget when to block, when to dodge, and which way to dodge - all which require distinct button presses." type game. I still get cornered plenty (not something you want to do) and spaz out with my button presses, but am definitely getting more confident with each run. I *just* got through my first level with just one death (which was most definitely avoidable) about 10 minutes ago and just want to replay for that perfect no-death level run. I also have only made it through to the beginning of 3rd out of the 5 levels.

Graphically I love the aesthetic and the sound design is fairly good as well. I've experienced 0 technical issues - no crashes, no weird bugs, or anything of the sort.

This is definitely not for a casual gamer and I can see why not everyone loves it. But if you can press through the first couple hours and see how potent certain combinations can be and don't mind the difficulty and skill curve, I promise you'll love it. I will update the review once I beat the game and play the "Arenas."

Edit: 40 hour review:

Finally completed the story mode. Yeah, 40 hours in because I realized for my skill level the age required to beat the final boss required I replay a few areas without dying or only dying once. I still wholeheartedly recommend Sifu and it is likely my top brawler game of all time, even though I've dumped 100s of more more hours into the Street Fighter series (at least up until IV) since the 90s. It is a game that requires a good amount of skill and hours to get good enough to complete. The story mode could easily be beaten in under 30-45 minutes once you've developed the skillset needed. I normally do not like games like this any more since my gaming time is generally limited, but there is just something that kept bringing me back for more. Maybe because I liked the feeling of being a badass and that the game just got progressively harder with a "Eh, you're not THAT good" reminders it kept throwing out at me. I'm on the fence as to if I'm going to attempt to 100% this, but I definitely will start this up at least a few more times to check out Arenas.

A couple of things issues I did come across that I didn't notice in my initial review: the camera can sometimes rotate in a way that makes it very difficult to see what is happening. It happened more than a few times which was frustrating. The second issue was that a number of times I would start a combo or attack on one enemy, and another enemy would approach and the combo/attack would inadvertently get executed on the second enemy - it didn't happen nearly as often as the camera issue, but enough to be annoying. I wish the devs would come back and patch a camera improvement, but it seems like at this point they've moved on to their next project.

Also, as a note - most "how to defeat x in Sifu" video tutorials out there are trash. They involve cheesing bosses and generally running around and attacking. This will do nothing except screw up getting the "true" ending and will definitely make the final boss fight much, much harder for you to defeat. Practice in the "training" mode and just remember - parry and dodge are what you want to focus on.

Edit: final update. The Arenas for the most part of fun, but some challenges (and modifiers) can be really annoying. Definitely am not going to try and 100% this and it can be really frustrating. Also, I have experienced right around 10 crashes in the Arenas, and only experienced one in my entire playthrough of the main story.

This is an excellent beat-em-up. Hard but fair, and a compelling take on the genre.

The core fighting gameplay feels kind of like a more complex, refined version of Arkham Asylum style combat with additional inspiration from Sekiro. There's a lot of moves at your disposal and you can really get creative and develop a style. My only complaint is that in group fights, you often don't have time to actually use a lot of your cooler moves because a goon will try and hit you in the back while you're doing them. Realistic, but always makes me sad.

The game could do a better job of explaining and easing you into some of its mechanics, in particular how defense works. How parries actually work, how to dodge attacks high/low, and when you want to do either one are not immediately obvious. Once you get it, you get it, but it can be a big source of frustration early on.

The levels themselves are really tightly designed too instead of just being an excuse to do one combat setpiece after another. The environments are beautiful and the encounter design is interesting. 

I think the story is pretty good too. I wasn't really expecting anything out of it, but it surprised me. There's a fair bit of interesting backstory you can glean if you pay attention, and the main story is classic but well-told. Getting all the endings is not terribly obvious but once you know what you're supposed to do it is straightforward.

The age mechanic is a genius way to get you to replay levels. The game as a whole really makes you feel like you're learning and improving into a kung-fu master, and not just by letting you unlock abilities. You can see your progress as you manage to clear levels with barely a scratch that you previously were barely able to finish.

I have to say, Chinese culture is DYING to get some good representation in video games and Sloclap have done a stellar job here. There is even Mandarin and Cantonese voice acting available! That's shockingly rare in western games.

The OST is great and they did such a good job of syncing it up with the in-game action.

I think the boss fights are the weakest part of the game. They aren't all terribly interesting and tend to have a specific gimmick to them. Some of them in particular can feel frustrating because they feel like a departure from what the rest of the game is trying to teach you, mechanics-wise. Be like water, I guess.

This is a 9/10 for Hardcore Gamers, and a soft-pass for everyone else.  No power fantasy loot grinds to be found here.

Sifu is a tough as nails Kung-fu quest for vengeance. It's premier game mechanic is a talisman that brings you back into the fight a little older upon death, with each decade of life granting you more power and speed at the cost of health. Every death increases the amount of years you grow older exponentially, but a hard won victory can decrease the punishment. Progression has two-tiers split between "shrines" and abilities. This helps coax you into the rhythm of Kung-fu, as each make you a little stronger in a different way. Abilities are bought with fight xp. They vanish when you die your final death when your talisman breaks (the death after you turn 70). Each time you buy the same ability, however, you count towards its "permanent unlock," ensuring it'll never go away upon death, new levels, or retrying old ones. Permanent unlocks will have your back, even in time travel. Shrines, on the other hand, are very powerful upgrades that only occur 2-4 times per level. And your access to them depends on the CURRENT timeline. If you choose an upgrade, die, and restart the level, the upgrade is gone. If you finish a level and move to the next, it remains with you insofar as you keep the progress of that finished level. Your anti-death talisman is in essence a time machine. You can redo old levels but it will change your shrine progression in the next. Certain objects like collectables/plot pieces are never altered once you collect them, no matter what you do. It took me a while to completely this system, but I appreciate the care that went into balancing the game in this way. Sifu is hard, it encourages you to repeat the same few levels and "get gud." If you don't, you're practically doomed. Even on the lowest difficulty, this game isn't for someone who doesn't want to or legitimately can't learn. But it masterfully digitizes the very real repetitive aspect of martial arts; martial artists train for hours striking the same dummy with the same punch to master the technique, and Sifu players beat down the same enemy playthrough after playthrough trying to master their approach. The game requires you to do things properly before you can even access a shortcut, and once you can you still have to weight the consequences. Shortcuts drastically reduce your progression potential, so taking every one will render you underpowered in a successively harder landscape. These aforementioned methods are how Sifu, a small game with 5-6 levels, a few gigabytes on disk, and incredible framerates on lower end hardward, is able to be packed with a massive amount of replay ability and a jaw-dropping level of care put into each section. Sifu is well worth it. It's not a sprawling game and the message is simple. But it's the definition of efficiency in design. It's a deal at MSRP OR discount.

[b]A PREAMBLE:[/b] I played this game previously before it came on Steam to the tune of 100+ hours, having already completed the story on both "endings", on Master difficulty. 

[h1]SIFU: [url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shuhari]the embodiment of Shuhari[/url][/h1]

[h3][b]SHU / 守[/b][/h3]
You've already read Sifu's summary on this page so I won't be repeating it or how it plays. Sifu is much like an actual Sifu telling you to do better, without much coddling, if any at all. It is INFURIATING in its gameplay and too repetitive with its miniscule scope of contents, with your attacks blocked every other seconds alongside myriads of enemies and bosses that kills you over and over without respite. Makes you wonder why you purchased this game at all..

[h3][b]HA / 破[/b][/h3]
Well.. that's what I would have said about the game on my first day of playing anyway.

Fun is subjective, and the kind of fun within Sifu is better described by myself as "satisfaction". I get catharsis when I pull off a counter at the right time, making micro-decisions that allows me to win an engagement, that could only be achieved through constant and constant grind of pure skill and defeats. Sifu is, true to it's Steam store page summary, realistic. If we're being nitpicky, one could claim that the Arcane-styled graphics isn't realism or that enemies being HP sponges isn't realistic when you're so comparatively fragile. But that's not where the realism is meant to lie. It lies in the game design and how it encapsulates the entire idea of martial arts. It is monotonous with its animations and basic defenses and attacks. Guess what else is monotonous? Martial arts and the practising of martial arts. Wax on, wax off, anyone? 

There are strong arguments in favour of as well as against realism in video game debates. People play to blow off steam, and that realism isn't inherently fun. And that's true. Practising martial arts, for most people, wouldn't rank high on the fun activities chart. Dying over and over to a system that is immutable (you can't change your stats for the better for the most part and the enemies are always the same) isn't fun. So going by that, Sifu shouldn't exist as a video game. And yet.. Sifu exists as the antithesis of those statements. It gives you a different sense of fun, which would have been difficult before it came along.

It gives you "fun" when you eventually, subconsciously, figure out the attack patterns of your enemies and then pulling off the appropriate responses to it. You stop second-guessing yourself and feel proud at how you can now play at an expert level after a period of time getting good. It's like the earning of dopamine released in our brain: [b]You can get an immediate release of the feel-good chemicals when you jerk off, or you can do some grueling exercises for a lengthier and lower releases of that same feel-good chemicals[/b]. One gives you immediate gratification, but the other has a longer lasting impact on your psyche. 

This would only work if the game does actually give you fun at some point, and it does. This would not have worked if the "endpoint" was not fun. The only difference is here, is how and when do you get your fun and satisfaction. Sifu is not an argument for more video games to be made like this, but a special exception, proclaiming that it is possible to feel just as good playing it, as it is for other games. The "novelty" of it is in the delivery method of fun.

[h3][b]RI / 離[/b][/h3]
Sifu is personally, my GOTY and as such I've nominated it for that award on Steam. It is extremely uncompromising with its design and mechanics (on the original and Master difficulty) and does not attempt to cater to a wide crowd of audiences. That in of itself, its a feat worth commending, and I would consider it "art as a video game". I understand that because of said lack of compromises for the wider audiences, it will turn off a lot of people from playing this, and prevent it from being on the forefront of mainstream popularity with other contemporaries, like the Yakuza / Like A Dragon series or Genshin Impact. But does it need to be? It doesn't need to. It has found a special place in my heart and mind, and that's all it needed to do. And I am not alone in thinking this.

If you are someone who wants a 3rd-person melee combat game with an expansive amount of content, as well as constant fun ON THE WAY of mastering said games and a balance between zany fun and genuine difficulty, the Yakuza series is what you want to play. I'd recommend 0 if you've never played it before. (Link: https://store.steampowered.com/app/638970/Yakuza_0/)

[b]BUT[/b] if you are someone who understands that you'll be forgoing most of what I just mentioned in lieu for catharsis towards the "end" where you become a Sifu of the game in your own right, then it is very much a game for you as much as it is for me.

Sifu is a really fun action game. The art style is interesting; it's simple but also clear and detailed. The story is alright (bit of a mystery mixed with a revenge). I do want to give praise to the devs for getting the idea of the moral code of martial arts, or "wude", right. You can also feel the passion and love for martial arts from the game, with many moves recognizable from Chinese martial arts and some stage sections referencing fight scenes from films (old boy hallway comes to mind).

The game play loop is well made, and combat feels responsive and intuitive for the most part. Controls are simple: you got your light/weak attack, your strong/heavy attack, a side step/ dodge key, and a block key that is also used with your movement keys for dodging in spot (dodge a low with block + up, or dodge a mid/high with block + down). So it's simple to pick up and play.

Now the game I think is very much a rhythmic and pattern recognition game at its core. You have to recognize patterns and timings to dodge or parry attacks. As such there's some knowledge, but also a lot of reaction. At first it'll be real hard, but with time the game does get easier.

Now with all that praise, let's get to the parts that I have issues with:

1) Performance. Even on a fairly decent computer there is stuttering at parts, like when you enter a specific area, or turn the camera too quickly. The frame drops are minor and not frequent, but it's noticeable when it happens.

2) Camera. The camera does lots of things automatically for you, like locking to opponents, shifting and zooming in and out based on the area or angle,etc. The worst is when you have a tight space, and your character is ganged on and the camera man zooms in, basically literally inside the character. It's a tough issue, and understandably challenging for devs to work around with, but it's still annoying. So if you want to survive, better find a good camera angle to start a fight in.

3) Difficulty. You know the game is difficult, when looking at any of the unlock-able skills, and it's all extra moves or build meter faster, but no extra health or extra defense (well I guess extra structure, or the meter that shows how much your character is allowed to block before being guard broken, counts as extra health). I feel like the game takes a Dark Souls-like approach to difficulty - you gonna learn or you gonna die. Unless you got lightning reflexes, prepare to die and get old a bit, especially during first play through. While the game does slowly teach you and ramp up the difficulty through the stages, there are parts where new enemies with new patterns appear, and if you never seen them before, it's hard to dodge that low sweep mix, especially since you have been conditioned to dodge low (duck high attacks) with most of the mobs only doing high or mid attacks.

I feel like I'll rant too much, so I'll just say even if you beat the game once and have gotten a grasp of the system, you can still get wrecked really quickly if you take a fight wrong.

Final thing worth mentioning is you'll also be fighting crowds a lot, and fighting the crowd auto targeting system the game has. It's not terrible, and controlling a crowd isn't that bad, but there are two issues I find a little annoying:

1) The moment you are about to complete a combo on one enemy, the next guy/gal will jump in to hit you. I guess it's to add a nice flow and also to keep you on your toes, but it's really annoying at times, especially when I'm in my chain punches and I get hit because I was a little off with my parry (well to be fair, parry is supposed to be hard and rewarding, dodging is safer and equally viable, albeit you don't damage opponent's structure).

2) Also the game is a lot about breaking the opponent's balance (or structure as it's called) to deal a finishing blow. You can either break structure or reduce health to zero, whichever comes first. Most times you'll actually want to break structure (as it's usually faster). Now here's the neat part about a group fight - your character will often, as you finish up a combo and reduce an opponent's structure to just before breaking, switch lock on to the next opponent jumping into the fray, making sure that the person who almost got structure broken will get a second wind (structure bar recovers fast if you don't engage). So often you'll want to whittle numbers down, only to get interrupted before you can KO someone so that the fight becomes all chaotic like a scene out of that Bruce Lee movie where he goes and group fights a Karate dojo (or when Ip Man challenges the 10 black belt Karatekas), except they both knock out a person before taking on the next.

So yeah, overall it's a fun game and a unique style of martial art game with lots of cool things and I did enjoy it a lot. However it is also quite punishing with the dodge and parrying timing and demands focus (which is neat and kinda true to the spirit of sports and martial arts). When it flows well, it really is fun, but some of the situations with the camera and group fighting does get annoying and frustrating.

Sifu is a fun roguelite martial arts/kung fu brawler that offers a combat system that is easy to grasp, but takes time to master.  In addition to the stellar combat, the game has a unique system that upon your "death", your character ages.  So rather than dying, you can simply see it as a setback and your character comes back for more at a later date.

Because the game only has 5 levels, you get most of the replay value through beating your own scores and making your own challenges. (Deathless run, Run at a maximum age, No upgrades ect.).  You genuinely get better and feel like a bad ass when you practice. The game invites you to keep trying and rewards you with satisfying mechanics that empower you to be a kung fu god.

Overall, if you enjoy street combat games and/or old kung fu movies this is an easy game to recommend.

Fun and brutal, with the emphasis on brutal. I mean this is the kinda game I could see people giving up after the second level, it's tremendously difficult. Art style is a 10/10, gorgeous graphics and animations (which should be expected from the developer of Absolver, another gem of a game). The animations really shine here, it's gorgeous to look at. I recommend giving it a shot, though of course with the knowledge that it's brutal. Don't go into it thinking that it's like Dark Souls or Sekiro. Those games always strike me as reactionary in a sense, that the character reacts to attacks and the better you are the quicker you are to react and analyze positioning etc. This game has some of that, but combat is way more precise. If you try to simply react you'll get killed very quickly. It requires careful planing that's way more reserved compared to the minute to minute gameplay that souls games have (cf. Doom Eternal too). With that in mind though, I give it very high marks, it's excellent. Pick it up. Pick. It. Up.

EDIT: Alright, I think this game has one of the strongest ludo-narrative cohesion ever. SPOILERS for some minor game play elements. I havn't seen this discussed in many places so I thought it's important to mention it. There is a way to spare the big baddies. BUT the game makes it way more difficult to do that than to just kill them outright. This is absolutely genius. The bad guys kill you and your father and tons of other people, but the message of the game is that the moral choice is far more difficult than the immoral one and this is reflected in game play. You essentially have to "beat" (not kill) the bosses three times to spare them, and I just find this so fascinating. Unlike other games where moral choices end up being a button prompt, in Sifu the choice literally means you have to be better than the boss skill wise as well as choice wise. This makes the choice so much more impactfu! Very interesting and ingeniously made game design.

All in all, Sifu is beautiful game, with a meaningful story that's all about learning how to be a better person--that the only real revenge is to be a better person than those who wronged you.
