Story is pretty short and not many cut-scenes, mainly just straight forward combat through in through. Game is more or less made to be replayed to challenge yourself. With added arena modes and added difficulties for story mode. 
The combat can be very fluid and engaging if understand how it works.  Which I imagine is why people would want to play it over and over. It actually made me feel like how they should have made the story mode for Yakuza games. Especially when came to picking up and using weapons. Which I rarely ever did in a Yakuza game. Generally only using my fist most of the time in those games. 
Thing doesn't really explain well in this game is guarding. Which I recommend using alot at first to learn and understand enemy attack sequences.  Guard can be broken if absorbing to many attacks. Though you can maneuver your body.  From left right down and up (which can still work on grapples).  To evade blows giving an opportunity or gap to attack. Game encourages deflecting at the start which is not good to try often when starting off imo. Since likely going to mess up a bit at first which is really going to cost you when constantly trying to deflect or parry. Think those are mainly beneficial for enemy power strikes though if fail to counter them and do devastating damage. There not very frequent and are usually used at the end of a combo. 
FYi I did just finish it on easy, though it was still pretty hard. There are actual cheats called modifiers which I never used which lock achievements. Which seems like would make the game far easier. Feel like I can raise the bar a bit now though.  Playing on easy my first time I think made things a bit less intense. So now feel comfortable tackling other difficulty modes.

[quote] Before you embark on a journey of revenge, dig two graves. [/quote]

Vengeance. Redemption. Wude. 

When I first ran the game, I was really stunned - it's an unbelievable mix of a thrilling and immersive martial arts experience that transcends the boundaries of conventional action games. It's a gripping tale of vengeance and redemption, presented through intense, hand-to-hand combat. The story full of battles, in mind and on the field.

The most striking aspect of Sifu is its fluid and dynamic combat system, which seamlessly blends traditional martial arts movements with a modern gaming experience. Each fight feels like a carefully choreographed sequence, emphasizing precision, timing, and strategic decision-making. It really feels like you are engaged to fight, from start to end, planning each move and your positions in battle.

The game's narrative is a captivating journey that explores the themes of perseverance and determination. The protagonist's quest for revenge is portrayed with depth and emotional resonance, providing a compelling backdrop to the adrenaline-fueled action. The storytelling and character development keep me gripped through the game and invested in the protagonist's personal struggle.

To get the best experience in the game, you must master it. It is a bit difficult task (esp for a person like me, far away from MKs or Street Fighters), but it is worth the price.

10/10. Worth it.

I find myself looking to append my review after 50 hours playing this game.  Initially I have an overall positive view of the game and highly recommended it based on the tight fight mechanics, artistic level design and superb story line that is very profound despite being low on narration and scripting.  All of these views still hold true but I have to say this is my favorite game of the year and have had it reflected as such with this years nominations.  

I found the game very difficult initially but nothing felt cheap or unmanageable.  Rather, I had to "git gud."  The good news is I did get a lot better, but I am no  where NEAR as good as I'd like to be! Whilst the game can be beat in an hour  or so, which is what some people complain of, it is absolutely not a fair way to critique this masterpiece.  

No one I know could pick this game up and just have the competence to complete the game without practice.  I'd recommend playing on disciple and then trying student to continue to practice if disciple is too difficult.  This game is VERY challenging but amazingly rewarding after you continue to make progress in a very similar fashion that Souls games offer.  I would honestly say that it would be extremely rare to buy the game and finish it on disciple in under 15-20 hours of play.  Perhaps one could on Student difficulty.  While I can already hear the "OmG I finished the game in X time" the stats say another story.  Only 9% of players have finished the game on any difficulty under 25 years old and around 16% under the age of 50.  The average person doesn't finish the game.  As the game rewards practice, you will likely find a lot of satisfaction seeing your practice pay off as that's what I found and continue to find true.  Ultimately I would like to finish this game on Master Difficulty at age 20.  I didn't even think I would be able to finish any level at age 20 when I first started!  

The combat is very dialed in, there are numerous ways to approach your enemies and take them on.  The graphics are nothing ground breaking but the artistic design, colouring, lay out all are congruent with the story and vibe of the game.  One more response to the people that would complain the story is short, those complaints don't factor into the arena mode that offers a TON of content in addition to the story with their own objectives.  As I am 48 hours into the game I have only scratched the surface of the DLC as I have been waiting until I had a good grasp of the main story complete.  

Overall, I think this was one of the biggest gaming surprises I have had in the past few years and recommend this game at full price or on sale.  10/10 for me.

Sifu is like a kung fu movie where your character ages faster than you do, trying to avenge his teacher. It's as if Bruce Lee met Benjamin Button on the street and decided to settle his affairs through a fight.

TL;DR; Sifu is an exceptional game that offers a deep and fulfilling experience. An absolute must-buy for fans of action games and/or martial arts. Highly recommend. 

The absolute best beat'em'up genre representative. 
The combat system obviously is where Sifu truly shines. It's both challenging and rewarding. It demands precision and timing. Every fight just flows, like a dance, where each move counts. The aging mechanic, where your character gets older with each death, adds a unique twist to the gameplay which at this point is just a cherry on top. The absolute best element of the game is actually the combination of four different defenses which compliment each other just perfectly. 

The art style is stunning, environments are both beautiful and immersive. The level of detail in each scene complements the game's overall aesthetic, creating an engaging world that feels alive and dynamic. The soundtrack is captivating, enhancing the intensity of fights and the depth of the story. The sound effects of combat are crisp and satisfying, making each punch and kick feel impactful.

The plot is compelling, pretty cliche but cool nevertheless, driven by themes of revenge and mastery. 

The (higher) difficulty is be punishing, but never feels unfair. It encourages learning and adapting, prefectly embodying the spirit of martial arts where practice leads to mastery. Beautiful allegory. 

And once you are done the campaign there's like a hundred custom arenas' levels from which the final ones REALLY put your skillset to test. Not an easy 100%.

"Is one life enough to know Kung Fu?"

Absolutely not, but I wouldn't have it any other way. 
I died countless times in this game, but not once did I feel like it was because of some BS moment or OP enemy, it was always my fault, my lack of awareness, slow reactions, pressing the wrong dodge button, not knowing how to use the environment to my advantage and not knowing the most effective combos.
This is a game that I have already finished quite a few times, given the trial and evolution narrative that is presented, and I am going to try to give a very honest review, targeting pros, mixed points, and cons.
Here it is:


PROS:
- Amazing art style and art direction, the clean, almost clay-like character models, objects and backgrounds give a vibe that I have never gotten from a game ever, it's pastel heaven one second, splash of color the other, and neon accents another. The game truly knows how to juggle light effects to it's advantage.
- Character designs are beautiful, the bosses truly have personality, it really felt like I was fighting actual martial arts masters, each with their own view on life and with their own lives and hobbies. Not to mention the very different fighting styles each of them has.
- The Music and Sound are damn amazing, and I recommend you play fully in Mandarin, English is fine but it feels a bit off at times, and Cantonese is just not good sounding imo...
- The Upgrade system is really interesting, it works in such a way that facilitates you playing levels multiple times, with each bought skill you get one step closer to permanently (buying a skill 5 times) unlocking it for future playthroughs. 
- The Pendant and Age mechanic is the whole gimmick of this game, and I think it's really well implemented. You die a lot of times and it creates a snowball effect, each death pilling up until you spiral out of control. While it can be frustrating, it forces you to adapt and evolve. Killing high value targets deletes 1 death off your death counter, as well as buying the reset death counter from the shrines available in all levels. With each 10 years that pass your damage increases and you health decreases (makes sense, you refine your skills but you are more frail with old age). Also, you can't teach an old dog new tricks, which is exactly why you have some shrine upgrades that can be bought only up until a certain age.
- Button mashing is not encouraged, it is punished. You have to wait and time your attacks, switch, dodge, throw enemies and parry their hits so that you can create opportunities to strike. It's like a dance of fists and kicks all the time, and you absolutely have to learn this dance well.
- Arenas are a very welcome addition to the game, with brand new locations based on the core game's locations, you have a ton of challenges, testing you score gathering abilities, your speed in killing enemies, and your crowd control skills. Getting 3 stars in every arena level is hard, but getting gold stamps is way harder, and can give you a ton of replayability in trying to perfect your performance.
- Perhaps the strongest point of Sifu, is the fact that once you finish the game the way you would expect to play it, that is killing everything that you encounter, you are greeted with the bad ending. Only by rewiring your brain and refining your skills you are able to replay the entire game and spare the bosses. Why would you? Because that's the good ending and the ultimate message of this game: "He who has Kung Fu and Wude makes the other know he can break him. And the other doesn't want to fight anymore. This is Wude."


MIXED: 
- The Storyline is nothing too crazy, it's a revenge story of a orphan Kung Fu student, however by completing the detective board you can learn quite a few new things and explore the whole picture, which I highly recommend you do.
- The game truly feels like a very polished old style arcade game, it is not easy, not forgiving at all, and it doesn't get easier, you just get better. Or you give up.
- Cheesing bosses works well on maybe 2/5 bosses, and by cheesing I mean waiting for an attack you know how to dodge and punish well, and disengaging all the other ones. Boring technique? Yes, but it works.
- The Training area feels a bit underdeveloped and bear-bones, but to be honest, who even uses it?


CONS:
- It is absolutely not worth buying the Costumes DLC, because you have to unlock them by playing and finishing very hard challenges, so if you think you can just use them because you paid for them, well, nah.
- Focus attacks are sometimes unresponsive and you can easily miss-click the one you want. I understand that you have to wait for a pause in the enemy attack to do them, but I still don't really enjoy that aspect. 
- You cannot get gold stamps in any Arena level, if don't know EXACTLY what the game wants you to do.


That being said, use every death as a means to progress and learn, don't give up when it gets frustrating, and enjoy your time seeking vengeance and trying to brute force through the game, you will realize how stupid and pointless that is, very quickly. Only then you will truly fall in love with this game, just like I did.

[h1] Sifu Redefines Martial Arts in Gaming with Innovative Aging Mechanics [/h1]
If you're into "Sifu," you're probably in it for the badass combat and cool art style, not so much for the storytelling. But let me tell you, the story's all about seeking revenge for the tragic loss of the protagonist's family. The game is set in a world that's all about martial arts, and you get to be this determined hero on a kickass journey for justice. As the story goes on, you'll face all kinds of tough enemies, each with their own fighting style you'll need to master to kick their butts.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3005718992

[h1] What makes "Sifu" truly unique? [/h1]
In "Sifu," the aging mechanic is a central and innovative gameplay feature that sets it apart from traditional combat games. Whenever the player's character is defeated in battle, they experience the effects of aging. This means that each time the protagonist dies, they physically grow older, reflecting the toll of their arduous journey for vengeance.

However, the aging mechanic is not a mere punishment for failure. Instead, it serves as a strategic and transformative element of the game. As the character ages, they gain wisdom and unlock new abilities. This progression empowers the player to approach subsequent battles with a fresh set of skills, making the character more capable and experienced in combat.

This mechanic adds a layer of depth and complexity to the gameplay, encouraging players to learn from their mistakes and adapt their fighting style as they evolve throughout the game. It transforms defeat into an opportunity for growth, symbolizing the character's resilience and determination to overcome obstacles on their quest for justice.

The aging mechanic in "Sifu" not only reinforces the narrative themes of growth and personal development but also creates a dynamic and engaging gameplay experience, rewarding players with a sense of achievement and mastery over time. It beautifully intertwines the character's emotional journey with their physical prowess, making "Sifu" a truly unique and memorable martial arts gaming experience.

[h1] Combat Carnage: Unleashing the Thrilling Resemblance Between Sifu and Sekiro! [/h1]
Posture, parry, and dodge – these are the heart and soul of the electrifying combat systems in both "Sifu" and "Sekiro"! Brace yourself for a thrilling journey through intense martial arts battles that will leave you breathless.

In "Sifu," posture is the key to victory! Strike with precision and relentless power to break your enemies' defense, opening them up for devastating follow-up attacks. It's a game-changer that keeps you on the offensive, unleashing a storm of furious blows that will leave opponents reeling!

But wait, there's more! Both games share the mastery of parrying, a skill that transforms you into an untouchable force! Perfectly timed counters deflect enemy strikes, turning their aggression into a perfect opening for your own strikes. It's a dance of skill and finesse that rewards quick reflexes and calculated moves.

And let's not forget the art of the dodge, where agility and evasive prowess are your best friends! In "Sifu" and "Sekiro," you'll be dodging, weaving, and sidestepping with grace, avoiding enemy attacks with sheer finesse. Be like a shadow, untouchable & elusive, ready to strike back with lethal precision.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3006228904

In conclusion, the combat systems of "Sifu" and "Sekiro" will keep you hooked from start to finish. Embrace the thrill of mastering posture, parrying, and dodging, and you'll find yourself immersed in a martial arts adventure unlike any other.

[h1] Arena Challenges [/h1]
The Sifu Arena Challenges constitute a distinct game mode, encompassing 45 diverse challenges featuring various enemies, modifiers, and environments. This addition serves as an ideal post-game content, significantly enhancing the game's replay value.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3008568776

[h1] Sifu Mods [/h1]
The game offers a plethora of character and moveset modes, each providing a distinct and enjoyable experience. For instance, players can embody iconic figures such as John Wick, Batman, and Tifa, and these mods go beyond mere character additions by incorporating realistic physics. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3006228789

Moreover, the Moveset mods overhaul the default move sets, offering abundant content and enhancing the game's replay value. Trying out these mods is highly recommended, as they promise a lot of fun and immersive gameplay.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
Sifu delivers an extraordinary martial arts experience that stands out as a true gem in the gaming world. With its innovative aging mechanic, the combat becomes an exhilarating journey of growth and resilience. The fluid and skillful combat, coupled with an emotionally charged storyline, immerses players in a captivating narrative. "Sifu" is a must-play for martial arts enthusiasts and action game fans alike, offering a unique and unforgettable gaming adventure.

Sifu is a relatively short but very hard game. This will test your limits the first time you play it, but once you get used to it and "git gud" at it, you start to enjoy the game in ways you did not enjoy the first time around.

You start trying to up your combos, die less times and even speed run the game. Over time you might find this game to be easier than you'd like. Well.... the devs got you covered. They added a "hard" mode. This mode is a significant step up in difficulty, making enemies more agressive and able to predict better your moves.

Of course you cant be keep playing the campaign over and over again. It's only five (master crafted) levels! The devs got you covered again! A new fighting mode, called Arenas was added. This mode consists of several challenges in different arenas, and I do mean several. Completing arenas will also grant you points to unlock new outfits which, by the way, are all very nice.

Overall this game is an incredible package for its price. I fully recommend Sifu and rate it at 9/10!

I agree this game has amazing combat, deep learning of fighting techniques and scenarios reminding us of many martial arts movie we watched, more or less.
But what moved me is that it has an underlying story which goes unnoticed for many.

This game revolves around the notion and implications of causality; and how every action we do comes at a cost. Should be follow in a patch of vengeance and deal every hurt we ever received, back to the ones that hurt us, or should we forgive them and seek enlightenment. No choice is made for us, as we need to forge our own path in a world on flames. The only question is do we walk down the blazing road, forging us anew in the trials of fire, or do we douse the flames to clear us that path to our ultimate goal.

Every bruises I receive is a reminder, that I have much to learn; every bone I break is a measure of my resolve and my determination, and every life I take or spare reflects what kind of person I strive to become.

The control scheme of the game is artificially inflated in difficulty because of how they require you to dodge attacks using the 'Avoid' mechanic, where you hold down the parry button, but also have to use the thumbstick to directionally dodge high or low attacks (90% of the time it's high attacks). General enemies are fine, occasionally they can feel cheap when they magically gain hyper armor for reasons, but it's not terrible. Some enemies and one specific boss attack VERY quickly, so finger dexterity was a legit issue for me personally and my hands would actually get tired trying to keep up. This was only fixed with practice to improve.

Bosses on the other hand are the weakest and most frustrating part of the game. They all have a moveset gimmick and hyper armor like 95% of the time which means you're forced to fight them the exact way the devs intended you to fight them, which can be frustrating if your technique isn't nearly perfect. The frustrating part is if even you successfully dodge/parry/avoid say 90% of the time, the times you fail you will quickly build up chip damage to your health and will quickly lose lives, so again it's about mastering the mechanics to survive, and I think most people who comes from a Soulsborne gaming history will be very humbled by this game unless you choose to stick with it and persevere. VERY frustrating game, but yeah sure it's good if you stick with it, but god do I hate it.

Pretty solid title, worth a go. It was very fun the first few goes around, but, like staring at a beautiful portrait for too long, the more time you spend on it, the more glaring the faults become. 

The story is fantastic, and uses some very simple design choices to give a lot of replayability to what would otherwise be a rather short title. There's a scoring mechanic, which alone would scratch an itch for many, giving a reason to go again and do better. Furthermore, however, some of the bonuses/stat buffs you can grab are locked behind a score wall, which is a great trick to get you go through a level again in attempt to meet the requirements for that one bonus you'd really like to have early on. 

Then, once you've beaten the game, and really feel like you've mastered it, you're given a whole new incentive to try again; this time, can you do it WITHOUT  taking the easy road and defeating your foes? I won't spoil anything, but there is definitely more to the game than just "winning," and the moment you feel like a master it will ask you to prove it. It really is the kind of challenge that humbles the ego you'll likely build from your initial victory, and has additional story beats to go along with that challenge that coincide with that feeling. The message it delivers is even, dare I say, profound. 

Then... there's the arenas. It truly feels like an entirely different team worked on the arenas than did the story. The arenas seem almost designed to shove the game's primary shortcoming right in your face: character control. So on a player/character control chart, sifu feels like it falls about here: 

[  ] Smash bros melee/project M
[  ] Very high
[  ] High 
[x] above-average
[x] average
[  ] below average
[  ] Low
[  ] abysmal
[  ] auto battler

Which is fine. In fact, story mode creates an illusion of it even being about high or maybe even very high. The reason is thus: you see, when you fight a mob there is no lock on, and pointing the stick toward a particular opponent is more of a suggestion to your character, rather than a command. In story, this isn't such a big deal; "oops, I wanted to hit that guy, but I guess I'll kick this guy's ass a bit, and break off back to my intended target." Occasionally there's that one annoying enemy you want to get rid off, but your guy just cannot or will not finish him, instead fighting you (the player) to go after everyone but. However, most encounters are designed so you can go with the flow, and when you hit that zen, it doesn't matter, you just drop whoever is stepping up next, with whatever technique flows from your soul.

In the arena... well... the only way to do certain challenges are to use very specific techniques in very specific ways to achieve very specific results. This is a nightmare, and I died a little inside on my road to 100% this game. I mean, I did it, but... you probably shouldn't. The issue herein being that most advanced techniques in this game involve flicking your stick this way or that before pressing X or Y, and the direction (stated as, for example, "DOWN then UP") is dictated by the camera, which often sits at odd angles; great for seeing what is going on, terrible for registering these inputs. The game's descriptions can also be very unclear in conveying how and when to execute certain techniques, compounding the issue. I beat the story in it's entirety without bothering to use most of these wonky input techniques because they were just so unreliable, but the arenas DEMAND them, and it's nothing short of migraine inducing. 

That said, I will recommend the title. It can be a hell of a lot of fun and, like climbing a mountain, offers a rewarding sense of triumph by the end. There's costumes to unlock, some interesting bosses, and it has the vibes of the old 70's kung fu flicks, with a bit of profundity sprinkled on top. Just sick to story, unless you are truly a completionist who simply must finish everything.

You enjoy kung-fu movies? Sifu is for you. You enjoy fair, but challenging gameplay? Sifu is for you. You enjoy unique settings and cool soundtracks? Sifu is for you. I've had a lot of fun with this game, the setting is masterly crafted and it runs smooth like butter. Game is worth the price, buy it if you can afford it. If it's ever on sale, this game is a must-have.

If you like parry-focused games, you'll love Sifu; it's a pretty difficult game from the get-go, but it has a nice learning curve and it's surprisingly intuitive.

The story itself is quite short, but the game has a very high replayability because of how it's structured and with the addition of arenas and post-run challenges you can absolutely sink in a lot of hours in this game.
The bosses have great design and generally feel tough but fair (apart from the Artist phase 1, fuck that) with the last boss feeling especially overwhelming at first but more like a proper showdown between kung-fu masters later, all the while keeping it a fair fight.

Defenitely worth the money.

Reviewing as a semi-casual player who now just wants fun more than crazy difficulty/challenges.

Sifu may seem short but its gameplay mechanics is what stretches the gameplay out longer, other than the story mode, the challenges arenas are what really prolongs this game and its intricate and fun gameplay. New game+ exists via the previously mentioned arena/challenges as well as changing or modifying your martial arts moveset as well.

Combat or gameplay itself is simple yet complex at the same time. You get a few set moves that can trigger different things like knocking down an opponent, pushing them further or just generally doing a half dodge and immediate strike. 
- Learning enemy move set matters
- Parry timing matters
- Positioning around mulitple enemies matters
All of these merges into a blend of multiple variance whch makes every fight different

Environments are also really well done and differentiates themselves apart, Soundtracks honestly in my opinion could be more hyped but mostly takes a sombre slow tone to follow its story mode I guess, although the club portions start to ramp up.

Overall, worth the cash even at full price now taking into account how most triple A games have inflated to a average $79-$99. Especially if you are looking for a challenging skill based martial arts game which honestly there aren't many martial arts games out there at all.

[h1] Sifu	[/h1]
[i] A Kung Fu action game that truly only shines in 1 category.	[/i]

[b] Pros:	[/b]
+ Music is awesome, very different and unique osts in each area.
+ Loved all the movie references from the outfits to specific moments in the game.
+ Relaxing art style for such an intense game, but didn't alienate the game's selling point.
+ Combat is the main focus and it's of course top notch action, love doing all the combos.

[b] Cons:	[/b]
- Sifu, in all intents and purposes is a beat'em up with roguelike elements, however, the roguelike aspect is so bare-bones I'm left asking myself, "Why did they even implement this?"
- Despite their disclaimer, if I purchase the cosmetic pack with real life currency I fully expect to have immediate access to those outfits, NOT for them to be locked behind specific conditions post game completion.
- Narrative is a big thing for me and if a game provides any form of that I will suspend disbelief and give it my full undivided attention, but it lacks big time. If the story plays second fiddle to the gameplay then they should've put those resources and time into the Arenas portion of the game and made it the focal point.

[i] Sifu's a great action game, but the roguelike elements are an afterthought and it's narrative sucks. Buy it on sale if you're bored.	[/i]

[b] Overall Rating:	[/b]6.2/10

Great game that you can just tell the devs poured their passion into.  Fun combat, amazing level design and a simple but interesting story with some of the best presentation I've seen in a game.

The whole game is just a love letter to martial arts movies and Chinese culture as a whole(there's full voice acting in both Mandarin and Canto in the game too); the references in this game and the attention to detail in the environments, set pieces and character designs are honestly reason enough alone to play this, but on top of all that they also made one of the most satisfying melee combat systems ever.  If you've played the Arkham games I would compare it to the melee combat there except this game has more meaningful combo strings, more complex defensive options, and animation cancelling tech for combo chaining, and the enemies are much tougher.  

Fair warning though that this game is pretty hard, despite only having 5 main levels which you can eventually run through in a couple minutes each, it took me around 10 hours to beat the game on the recommended difficulty, and another 2 hours to get the true ending.  There is an easy mode which drastically decreases the punishment for dying so I don't think this game would be impossible to beat for someone who sucks at these mechanically demanding types of games but you will 100% get frustrated even if you're a good player - that's intentional though and woven into the themes of the game in a nice harmony of gameplay and narrative.  

Really strong 9/10 for me, and if you think even a little that you might like this game just give it a shot. A tightly designed, complete game with a strong vision that's executed this well doesn't happen often, and is worth experiencing.

This is a very technical game, which I like. The fighting - especially the essential role of timing attacks and defenses - is realistic. The graphics are average quality. The difficulty of mastering this game is very high, in my opinion. This is a level/map based game structure, and you cannot save your progress as you go. Game saves only by level/map completion. This is part of the reason why the game is difficult to master. I also like the fact you can play it on PC with mouse and keyboard, or with a game controller. I use the former control combination, which also raises the difficulty of game. The levels/maps are rich in detail; but there are very few objects you can interact with. Overall, I recommend this game for anyone who likes technical 1st/2nd/3rd person martial arts combat games.

This game is a very stylish parry-oriented combat adventure. The movements are tactile and responsive, and landing the parries and combinations is rewarding. Overall, from the short amount of time I put in, a very polished fighting game that bring in the rogue-lite elements from the genre. The aging system is fun an unique, and while I think the skill system can be a little tricky to get into, taking time to master them and your standard combinations, you'll be a black-belt in ass-kicking kung-fu, Probably one of the better brawlers I've played in some time and with the gameplay style that it achieves, just a great way to enjoy an afternoon.

All that being said, I've got a couple gripes. The first is the difficulty swings harder a bored couple from San Francisco. You go from just wrecking groups of nameless walking stereotypes to getting beaten like a red-headed stepchild in a matter of footsteps. It's all over the place, and there are stronger aforementioned minions that are completely indistinguishable from the standard assortment of target dummies. You won't know until you're suddenly getting your cheeks clapped like your ex while you're at work. There's no way to immediately identify problems and manage the threat reasonably. This leads to a lot of unnecessary deaths. And while fighting a boss and taking a fat L is part of the learning process, you don't learn anything from unfair deaths due to bad design choices. What you do learn is new way to put curses together under your breath towards the devs for this oversight. Also, the stamina bar breaker attacks, which are usually signaled by a glowing limb they want to deliver somewhere between your lungs and colon, are only signaled 0.0001 seconds before you realize it's going to take a surgeon and a Caterpillar crane to remove it from your ass. If you're going to go through the trouble to telegraph attacks I need to dodge instead of parry, then fuckin telegraph them usefully otherwise don't do it at all. 

I still highly recommend this game. Chances are that if you played Sekiro and did well, this game will probably be a bit of a breeze for you. For the rest of us that aren't cocaine-addicted Monster fanatics, don't bother with the hardest difficulty. The first one is a little too easy, and the second one will have you biting a pillow and begging for mercy.

Amazing animation and a really fun fighting system, completely undermined by a single absolutely awful design choice.

At first the aging system sounds really cool and thematic, until you realize that it's a hard limit on the number of times you die. And not just in a single stage -- which are quite long and comprise multiple mini-bosses and setpiece brawls, topped off by a multi-stage boss with Sekiro-level attack strings -- but for the ENTIRE CAMPAIGN. If you hit this limit, you can retry the stage, which will put your age back to what it was at the start... but it's entirely possible to get yourself into a position where you have to basically perfect the next level if you died too much on previous stages.

If you want to beat this game on a difficulty that is challenging for you, you will have to restart the game multiple times. In 2023 -- hell, any time after 1994 -- this is just jaw-dropping. It's not a roguelite with persistent unlocks between runs, it's a multi-hour narrative campaign, and I'm assuming you have to do the stages in the same order on every attempt. 

Some people seem to be defending this as being thematic and forcing you to get good at the game, and it does do those things, but it's mostly just padding out the playtime in my opinion. I want to master the combat, but I want to do it by progressing through the story, and maybe returning to specific fights or even doing a full run again. What I don't want to do is be forced to replay the same stages over and over before I can be rewarded with seeing something new, or lower the difficulty to make it less challenging. 

The aging mechanism itself is fine, just let me be a 960 year old martial arts legend. Or better yet, make the unlimited aging and hard cap an optional difficulty add-on, like Ironman mode in other games, because that's what it is.

Sifu is as close as it gets to the perfect conversion of a kung-fu movie into a video game. The quintessential amalgamation of classic martial arts cinema themes, callbacks, and fresh game mechanics. An excellent beat ‘em up with unparalleled polish, every aspect of the game is so finely composed. You can feel the intention, focus and passion that went into its development. The artistic direction is beautiful, with an excellent aesthetic making every set piece look like a painting. It’s a great example of stylized graphics providing a timeless look, and lessening the burden on hardware by not striving for needless realism.

Deciding against realism in favor of style does not mean the game’s environments lack detail. Every level is packed with well-thought environments, and a very enjoyable amount of clutter for the area. Better yet, Sifu takes its beautiful style and creates some amazing set-pieces. The levels are such a treat to fight through. Without spoiling much, each level is a boss’s hideout, and you’re on a path of revenge, punching and kicking your way through waves of their goons. The hideouts very much reflect the personality of the boss and are relevant to their occupation. There’s a lot of subtle environmental storytelling in Sifu (as well as easter eggs hidden throughout the levels that expose more). This would be enough to impress, but every level has a distinct soundtrack that fits the theme and feeling, creating some very powerful atmospheres. The environments paired with this banger soundtrack really elevate the experience and make it feel truly cinematic.

The animation is so fluid that I find it jarring going back to most games, even AAA titles. A lot of games feel very stiff in comparison. This fluid and dynamic animation seamlessly transitions your attacks. This is an impressive feat, as though Sifu doesn’t have an unbearable amount of possible attacks, there is a wide variety of basic moves creating a lot of potential combos, and the animation system blends every single one perfectly into the next. It even accounts for the same moves done in different environments, which can determine how the finishing blow is dealt. This isn’t unique to Sifu, but it’s rare, and Sifu does it well.

Sifu has a unique resurrection mechanic that is built into its story. Upon death, you can resurrect at the cost of a few years of your life. You age every time you fail until you reach any age above 70, at which point you’ll be on your last life. If you die for good, you start over. This is a key part of Sifu’s difficulty, forcing the player to learn and improve, coming out of levels younger and younger, perfecting the art of each level and obstacles to be overcome. Thankfully, the youngest age you complete a level at will always be saved for convenience. If you manage not to die for two levels for example, you can always just start from the latter level for your next attempt. Though the story is nothing revolutionary, it serves as an excellent canvas for your classic tale of revenge often told in kung-fu classics, helping bring those themes to life. It's an elegantly told story. Everything feels intentional and you can tell the developers communicated greatly, ensuring every aspect of the game is cohesive. The outcome of your journey can change in a way that is very heartfelt, depending on some of your choices. These choices aren’t made obvious to the player, and I won’t delve into them, but you can technically get a different ending and we’ll leave it at that. 

There’s a lot of incentive to replay the game’s main story, whether it be to flex your skill and come out unscathed, never aging, as you flawlessly master every encounter, or to discover the secrets in each level that sometimes unlock items used to access areas in previous levels. The game is designed with the intention of you replaying it a lot, but not through irritating grindy mechanics, rather the natural incentive to improve and uncover more of the story for those curious. Additionally, there’s an entire separate mode in the game called Arenas, with a massive amount of new levels and challenges to overcome, providing even more replay value and a lot of extra quality content. I could easily see some players not even bothering with the main story, and just having fun playing through one-off scenarios in Arenas, though I’d highly recommend not even touching Arenas until you’ve beaten the main game. 

So, you’ve got this $40 indie game with a level of polish and presentation unparalleled by most games, with fun beat-em up action, excellent enemy AI, a lot of replayability, and genuine challenge that you overcome as you ‘git gud’. This is one of the easiest recommendations I can ever make, as I really think anyone can enjoy this game if they have a little bit of patience for learning how to not suck at it. Nothing feels tedious either, a big part of whether I personally can stomach a game's difficulty and stay interested. No question in my mind if you’re a fan of martial arts cinema, it's essential you give this game a shot. Buy it. Sifu has soul, this is a game made with care, with intention, and we need more games like this.

Sifu is a challenging and satisfying martial arts brawler that will test your skills and patience. 
The combat is fluid, responsive, and realistic, with every punch and kick feeling impactful.

However, the difficulty can be frustrating at times, especially in the boss fights, where you have to learn their patterns and exploit their weaknesses. The camera can also be problematic in some areas, obscuring your view or getting stuck in the environment. 
Sifu is a game for kung fu lovers who want to feel like a badass.

[h1] Sleeping Arkham, Hidden God Hand [/h1]


[h2] "One epitaph for Clover Studio: We made one of the best games of all time and it was just a game about punching people." [/h2]

[b] SIFU [/b] is definitely without any doubt one of the best modern beat 'em ups to date. 

This game took Batman Arkham's freeflow combat and made the countering, dodging, and the punching and kicking more deliberate and as technical as your standard 2D fighting game.

This game is styling, visually and mechanically. The thematic imageries throughout the five stages are a feast, especially at the middle chunk of the game's main campaign. I never got tired of them. I did get used to them, but I'll never say they're boring. This game is quite the cultural exhibit, in every sense of the word. 

Mechanically; combo strings, pause combo, charge attacks, directional dodge, directional throws, follow-ups, sweeps, environmental interactions, takedown finishers, and dash attacks.
This game has all of those, and they all work together really well.
They even use a scoring system similar to Devil May Cry's, but the game isn't going to tell ya about it up front, cheeky little bastard.

The game feels good to play. It feels good to lose, and it feels very very good to win. Beating the game gave me a good amount of satisfaction, but mastering and understanding the many elements the game throws at you is enlightening. 
It's as good as people say it is.

Oh yeah, the arena challenges are great. They're there to push your limits, and in a roundabout way, a great tool to teach you techniques that most players would've ignored during their main campaign runs. 

The game is [b] GREAT [/b], but it's not perfect. There's slight jank in there, although they're seldom. Here are my findings:

glitches:

main story:
- [spoiler] Yang [/spoiler] stuck in a wall during second phase
- [spoiler] Sean [/spoiler] stuck on object during second phase 
no softlock and was able to resume the battle without restarting

arena:
- enemy spawned out of reach from player (on the roof, in the air)
- player/enemy could stuck in falling animation at the edge of a map
-  this happened once, an enemy just teleport from the lower floor mid jump kick into the player's face


Now, my personal nitpicks
 
- let me toggle the target for focus attack, and maybe make the slo-mo focus menu slightly slower

- enemy seemingly attack from out of frame

- directional input attacks can mess up the soft lock-on targeting, a hard lock-on toggle might help, I'm not sure myself 

- wrestling with the camera sometimes, of course

- game crashes due to physics items went haywire?

Sifu

- is in my opinion one of the best action games of all times (at least Top 10) and can run against the Titans of the genre (GoW, DMC, Doom, Arkham  etc) with its unique approach of constantly dying and ageing again and again in fast combat scenarios, until you reach the end of a level and finally the end of the game. For me it's one of the best combat systems ever created,  because (when trained enough) the player is in full control of every single move he makes and the flow and feeling of it is incredble, while being threatened with death all the time. It is also the real "Get good" game because there are no shortcuts by RPG level up mechanics (looking at you "Soulslike" genre). Also "Easy to learn, but (very) hard to master" is a description that fits the game very well, because simple and tight button inputs have to be used against pretty tough AI. Of course the Kung Fu Movie style and its settings plus the music round up the whole experience, like a delicate meal accompanied with a fine wine. And the Arena mode is like a very delicious (and big) dessert. 

I also recall the reviews when it was released: "It's good, but very hard" was the overall opinon and i am not sure that all reviewers have seen all 5 stages at that time. Remember: after the first month less then 30 % of the regular players had finished the second level (out of 5): "The Club" (Shoutout to YouTuber "Djisso" who helped many players to overcome some of the bigger hurdles at the beginning). So Sloclap was forced to create the easy mode, to make the game more accessible (this way i even got my girlfriend to fall in love with it) and let beginners at least experience the story of the game as a "Student" first, before their real life-long journey as a "Disciple" starts, to reach the true heights of Gong Fu and becoming a "Master" with Martial Virtues ("WU DE").

For sure the game was not appreciated enough as Indie "Game of the year 2022" contender (maybe the easy mode at release could have made a difference in the perception of the game and its accessiblity). As a evolution and reimagination of the classic Beat'mUp genre, by definition it also didn't fit in the fighting game category either ("Best Combat" category would be nice). Also as "Skill Up" mentioned: "Sifu was "THE GAME": in the week before Elden Ring was released !!!" Probably in the long term the game will get its recognition (especially for the gameplay and the unique progression system). 

So the gameplay is phenomenal, the only real gripe i have is the unbalanced economy of the challenge/reward system for the outfits and movesets (for your personal Kung fu style) and also for mods and cheats. Modifiers and new moves are to expensive or the rewards are just not big enough to unlock more then a few things.  To get some of the best outfits you need to overcome some ultra-hard challenges (tedious work). It makes no sense to hide all the good stuff behind a narrow reward system. Respect my time: to grind even more and harder for the stuff that should be easy to enjoy after finishing the game is just not fun, i already have a job !!! Just let me play (as free as possible) !!! Don't make me hate the game (and not want to play it anymore) because you show me all the nice stuff, but then lock it behind a wall of tedious work. In this particular area it is just bad game design and an affront to the fans (who just want to enjoy the game) and to all gamers who just play to have fun. It is a big middlefinger right into my face and i have to give this one right back to you, Sloclap !!!

So in this regard Sloclap fumbled the ball right in the endzone to create a perfect game. This is especially sad, because they came so close to make a well rounded experience that everyone could have enjoyed by his own personal preferences.  

I bought the game now the 3rd time on Steam, because the Epic games store version had some problems on the Steamdeck. No regrets there, because Sloclap evolved from "Absolver" to "Sifu" so much, that on this fundaments and with some tweaks of the reward system (and some insights of what makes a game fun instead of grind) even bigger things are possible and i can't wait to see them.

Originally, I had thumbed down the game. But after logging in more hours, I've changed my mind; but that doesn't mean I recommend it though. I did have fun. And that's all I can say. However, there are two things that greatly ruin this game for me: the bosses and the combos you unlocked.

Bosses are supposed to be hard, sometimes rage inducing (you will get that a lot), however there is a gripe I have with the boss designs. Imagine playing an RPG and the first boss you face is just some big dude with a sword. You have unlocked some abilities to face him and he has some tricks up his sleeves as well. Then the next boss, you've gotten better and unlocked more abilities, but the boss has also gotten some buffs to make them harder, forcing you to use everything you have learned so far. This is a healthy progressive system where bosses gradually get harder as you, the player, get better. That's not the case for Sifu.

Fajar, the first boss, is like facing Sephiroth instead of the Scorpion Mech in the first area of Final Fantasy 7. He is a tough guy. And as someone who has beaten this game dozens of times, he still trips me up, sometimes managing to kill me. And after you finally beat him, new players will be like, "Dang! How are the other bosses gonna get harder?" Not the case, because Sean, the second boss, is a f**king joke. So is the Artist, once you learn her gimmick, and the CEO. Yang is Fajar, only more predictable. So why is Fajar, to me, the hardest boss, but everyone else is a jester? Fajar will mix up his attacks and quickly finish you off with quick blows. Everyone else, even Yang (the final boss), have two or three combos they do, and they don't ever mix them up. They are as predictable as thunder after a lightning strike. You will always be second-guessing yourself when facing Fajar; but everyone else, once you've learned their tiny moveset, will be a cakewalk. Now, enemies do get harder, but bosses are suppose to be big moments in games, a trial to prove yourself that you are ready to take on the next area of the game. I never had that feeling. Once you get past Fajar, you can still have fun, just don't expect the bosses to get any harder.

And finally, the combos you unlock. Now, I'm still learning about combos and chaining them together effectively. But doing so is cumbersome, because enemies will suddenly start to block in the middle of your combos-- which makes sense! No one would just give up and take a beating. But the real kicker is when the game suddenly gives them super armor so that they can deal out there attacks. I hate that. I hate it when a game chucks immersion and realism out the window and gives enemies super armor, but you get none. The only move you get that gives you super armor is the one where you hold block and hold down Y to do a charge attack. And that move sucks! Even if you power through the enemies attack to do the move, you're still f**ked because they still have super armor and they keep going until their animation is over. That sucks the fun out for me. Buff the enemy and nerf the player. I don't like that.

Those are my two biggest gripes about the game. I'm not gonna talk about the Arenas. All I'm gonna say about them is that they can go burn in Hell. I won't miss them. And that's only if you're trying to collect the three stamps in each challenge. 

Despite my gripes, the game is still fun. Even when you look past the boss difficulty and the enemies super armor, it is still a fun game. Don't let my negativity stop you. I'm just telling you what to expect.

My advice to new players: 1. abuse the f**k out of avoids. When you successfully avoid, time will slow down for the enemy, leaving them open for a small combo.
2. When you are facing a ton of enemies at once, create a "choke point" by getting into a hallway so that enemies can only come at you one at a time. This prevents them from surrounding you and attacking you all at once.
3. NEVER BE AFRAID TO RETREAT! Sometimes, it's best to put something between you and your opponent so as to give you a breather.
4. DON'T UPGRADE WEAPONS OR FOCUS AT SHRINES! Upgrade only structure and structure recovery first. Blocking is powerful, but don't rely on it too much.
5. Don't do Takedowns. There is a small chance that an enemy will get "second wind": they get all their health back. They are harder and faster and relentless. The more enemies you kill, the higher the chance for an enemy to get "Second Wind" but only if you do takedowns on them. However, this only works with grunts. It doesn't work with Disciples, Bodyguards, Flashkicks, and Juggernauts; so do takedowns on them all you want. 

This review is long enough. I've said my piece and can lay this game to rest.

Background:

I grew up playing the arkham games as a kid. and was extremely dissapointed with knight. I thought they simplified the controls, but replaying city made me realise it was only a challenge because my child mind couldn't see I was only pressing 2 buttons.  This game has filled a void that arkham 5 shaped hole in my life.

Everything is great about this game cept for 2 things. 1. the camera, however that was solved by remapping the controls so that I control the camera with the directional buttons on the right.
2. the processing speeds. I inherited a 4k gaming PC, and I feel like it should run this game better. Seems to be more an effort loading the environment then the combat itself. I don't see any reason why I should experience any dips in my frame-rate. Its not like there are unique animations for an opponent on the stairs. 
3. Other; there should be an option to turn off the bars and warnings. so that you rely on the animations for gameplay instead of a meter on the bar. 

Overall its these 2 reasons I'd say $60 is a bit much, this feels more like a $30-40 experience. It lacks that AAA polish making it feel like $70+. Especially since the DLC adds about 50%, and is only valued at $15.

From a gameplay perspective, you've got to approach opponents with a level of respect. Acknowlege that you can't treat them the same and that some will coordinate and use the same abilities as you. Took me a while to realise there was a bar showing your opponents sense of balance. That's because the animations are so detailed you can see when someone is a couple taps away from done. The fruits of this game are reserved for those who do not possess fragile egos.

[h1][b]8/10 - Great[/b][/h1]
Sifu is a great rogue-like fighting game that emulates old martial arts and Kung-Fu films. If you're up for a challenge this game is going to be very fun.

[b]Positives[/b]
[list]
[*]The combat is both very challenging and extremely rewarding as enemies will test your patience and reaction.
[*]The soundtrack elevates every fight exponentially.
[*]The level design for each of the 5 areas is well thought-out with multiple routes to take, encouraging multiple play-throughs for all of the collectibles.
[*]The art style, graphics, and animations are awesome.
[*]Sifu has multiple endings, allowing players to make decisions throughout a playthrough.
[*]The aging mechanic is unique and rewards/punishes you for dying.
[/list]
[b]Negatives[/b]
[list]
[*]Sifu is short, although there is a lot of side content in the form of challenges and arenas that the developer has added in the final update.
[*]Sifu's camera has a tendency to obstruct the view of enemies. A wider shoulder FOV would have made the combat even better.
[*]Some enemy attacks, like sweeping kicks, are almost unblockable. They're not well telegraphed and take a very quick reaction to successfully avoid. Avoiding attacks in general require tight inputs.
[*]If you play on borderless window sometimes the mouse cursor will get stuck on a different monitor, causing inputs to not properly work.
[*]Inputs are stacked on movement keys for KBM players, which makes them pretty difficult to successfully pull off in the correct amount of time. If possible, play on controller for a better experience.
[/list]

Honestly, what can I say about this game other than that it is an underrated masterpiece? I mean first off all, the combat is simply beautiful. It draws inspiration from Sekiro: Shadows die Twice, but at the same time SloClap kept in mind that they wanted to create Absolver (their first game) in a much better format. Not a single moment of combat feels dull. You love deflecting? You can deflect the entire game. You love to dodge? You can dodge the entire game without deflecting a single attack. You like judo? Well you can literally use inverted throw or just regular throws to throw people around and manage crowds. There is a little bit for everyone. The finishers feel amazing and they are well mocaped.

The story is ok. I mean its nothing convoluted. Its a pretty straight forward revenge mission from start to finish. The only unexpected twist is [spoiler] the moment that you realize that you can actually spare the bosses and it changes the ending. [/spoiler]

Arenas are A TON OF FUN. You literally compete with yourself to see can you beat your own score. Each Arena is made so that is uses different randomizers. This ensures that not a single mission is going to be the same as the last ones. Its very intuitive.

All in all. I rate this game an 8.7/10.

I had great expectations for this game, but am completely disappointed. I don't know what the developers intended the game to be, so I'll just express my impressions.

The game wants to be a cool stylish satisfying beat-em-up like the Yakuza games, but also wants to be technical like a normal fighting game (Street Fighter, Tekken and so on). And it fails at both.

The beat-em-up aspect sucks, because the enemies are too smart to actually get beaten up. Example: the game gives you a combo by default consisting of 5 light attacks. I didn't manage to land it once even on regular goons, because they start blocking and counter-attacking after like the third hit. So you cannot go around having fun beating people.

The fighting game aspect sucks as well. The control scheme is very uncomfortable (S, W, attack???); it is hard to differentiate between when you just blocked an attack or when you parried it both visually and sonically; your enemies have attacks with different properties. It all makes the combat very confusing. It could work if there were less enemies, but encounters generally have either multiple enemies, or enemies with weapons, and don't get me started on bosses of which I have seen just one so far and am not sure I would care to play more. The game simply comes down to you finding the most efficient (boring) tactic and abusing it.

In case you want to tell me to get good, I have been playing fighting games competitively for a long time, and have played Dark Souls 1-3 as a Soul Level 1 character. All these were much more fun than Sifu.

The visuals seem like the devs wanted to have them stylized, but they look simply poor for a game released at this time and age. The animations are pretty smooth though, I like them. The music is boring and repetitive. The story is almost non-existent.

If you want a game with cool combat where you go toe-to-toe with your enemies, parry their blows and then hit them, I wholeheartedly recommend Sekiro instead of this.

I know i am the minority here and really tried to like the game. I almost have 24 hours in the game and i got every achievement there is but why do i still give it a thumps down? 

For me the problem starts with the game just begin to hard. Yeah i know skill issue, git gut, jadajadajada we all heard it a million times, but Sifu in my opinion is just too unforgiving. I started on normal and i got frustrated so hard after two levels so i started on easy and suddenly the game was just too easy. The difficulty spike from easy to normal is just ridiculous! On normal you get punched to death in a sec and on easy you complete the whole game in 2 hours under the age of 25 so Sifu doesnt find the right balance here. You could argue that the audience for the game are people that love hard games, but games like Dark Souls or Devil May Cry fight just the sweet spot between those difficulties. These games are never too hard or too easy. Sifu just cranks it up, tells you to fcking git gut or get the hell outta here. The counters have to be frameperfect. Why? Just because you make it hard by default it doesnt get better, its just more annoying for players who just wants to have a good time playing fighting games but Sloclap just wants the elite players who are willing to die a million times to make it to end on hard or get three stars on every challange. 

Some of the challanges are just utterly unfair! If you make a single little mistake, your three star rating is gone. Sifu just wants to punish you for the sake of punishing you, nothing else to it. Sit through the suffering or look for another game is Sifu philosophy.

Sometimes i had the issue that my inputs were not read correctly, i checked the controls, did everything like the menu told, i checked YouTube and volla it turns out you have to counter or evade to throw. What kind of design is that? You show me the wrong input and dont even explain. Yea Yeah i hear you, just go to the training arena and practice. But i just dont want to practice in a arena, i want to play the story and enjoy the combat but Sifu just tries to kill you at every corner by either begin too hard, no explaing the basics properly or by just punishing the tiniest mistakes.

Achievements were luckly easy to obtain because since the final update they broke a lot of them so they just unlocked without me even doing the requirments. Thats fine for me i guess so i dont have to play the game ever again.

I only recommend this game to people who punishment at their workplace is not enough and want to sit through it after they got home. If you just want to enjoy a fighting game with good combos, go for Devil May Cry or any other fighting game. Hitting top 500 in Street Fighter 6 is easier and goes faster than completing this game on the hardest difficulty.

For a studio that has only made two games thus far they have a respectable reputation in the industry already but they completly lost me with this one and i am not excited for any other projects from the team.

I didnt hate my time with Sifu but the negatives are just more than the positives in this game. Shame because i really wanted to like it. Guess i go back to casual stuff (me bad gamer, git gut Smadge)

[h1][b]Just meh.[/b][/h1]
◘ Camera is garbage.
◘ Lighting is garbage. Lots of places where you can't see anything.
◘ Moveset is garbage. The animations are nice and punchy, but the moveset is not.
◘ Parry-frames are too tight. One-on-one they are more-less fine, but where you got a one-on-one here? All fights are 2-6+ enemies and these tight frames do not work with that camera.
◘ One-way bosses/enemies - my beloved garbage game mechanics, you MUST fight them only as devs intended. You have a whole arsenal of moves and abilities - well, they don't work now, just a waste of time ( Hello, Sekiro ). Not all enemies are like that and that is even worse because you are getting used to building your own style of play and at some point, the game just takes away all of that.
◘ Enemies don't have ability cooldowns - they can spam kicks that will break your meter with ease. And bosses have the same problem.
◘ 4 (!!!) actions on one button, this is not a mech simulator! Devs, you already have an evade button, why do another one with GUARD + DOWN? And another specific one with GUARD + UP... to EVADE a DOWN ATTACK ( you can't change this in settings, btw )?! This clusterfack of actions leads to wrong input executions.
◘ When you get into the flow - this game can be a nice experience, just to ruin all on bad game design and clustered input manager.
◘ Abilities that do not work or are just a waste of time. Why do I need a Leg Swipe supermove when I can use a default Eye Poke + Low Kick + Ground Finish? And then I can go for another Low Kick + Ground Finish = More damage while invincible.
◘ Why do I need 4+ hit combos? Most of the enemies will parry me on the 3 hit or die in 2. And you will have a STRONG + HOLD + STRONG move that is safe, fast, and chips away their meters.
◘ Try to Parry the boss, then go Low Kick + Ground Finish + Low Kick + Ground Finish + Eye Poke ( that must stun him ) and he will 100% evade/parry your next Low Kick - because of devs. Yes, this is a cheesy combo but still need a skill to execute the sequence near frame perfectly just to get a big "No-no, you are playing this game wrong."
◘ You get a training mode where you can fight with the selected opponent to learn his moves - great! But why the arena is just all RED in the most eye-irritating way? I must learn here, not burn my retina!
◘ Why this game is 20+GB? Mass Effect 2 and 3 are 15 GB - massive cinematic RPGs. And this is just a short arena style ( try to ) beat-em-up with stylised graphics - must be around 6-8 GB max.

If you want to look at good close combat execution - look at the GODHAND. Yes, the movement is a bit tanky, but you have a lot of control and freedom there ( and the game is still difficult af. )

Fun, neat idea, worthy attempt, but if you're a beat-em-up or unarmed combat (in video games, I stress; I'm not a COMPLETE douche) connoisseur, it won't take long to notice it's not as tight as it thinks it is. The trouble is that it comes maddeningly close a lot. Speaking as someone who plays Street Fighter semicompetitively, I can *see* the desynced animations v impacts. 

But sometimes it comes together and you do weave in between three or four enemies, kicking them out of the furball/killing them as fast as they can come in, and somebody hucks a bottle at your head, which you catch and break over the head of some goon. That feels great.

But then you also have enemies reliably doing the exact same one-two, one after another, in groups of 7-12, and it's very clearly compensating for filling enemy's poise bars, trying to displace your focus/damage. It's not difficult, it's tedious, and more than that, it feels fake.

And then other times your mostly-wearing-black character will be fighting also-mostly-wearing-black enemies in a literally black void. The game does a decent amount of artsy stuff, in one case inside a literal art museum, but a lot of times it comes at the cost of gameplay, whether through readability or otherwise fucking with perspective.

I found the boss fights too prescriptive to be enjoyable. There's very clearly a script you're supposed to be following, when honestly the most fun I had was jumping on top of the dumb losers trying to solemnly challenge me to a duel, and stomping their teeth in before stealing THEIR weapon and beating them to death with it. Less of that in the boss fights. After boss 2, it kept feeling like fighting Stalfos in Ocarina: just waiting for their attacks to be over, dodging and parrying at all the right times, counterattacking the CORRECT number of times, and then back to waiting.  Even your Supers, the focus moves, don't change it too much. The problem's made worse by the fact that the technical tightness isn't there (for me; let it be known that it can EASILY be done, it can be memorized if nothing else, I'm just saying the feel I'm looking for isn't here). It forces you to depend on a mechanic that doesn't have the anims, models, and hit/hurtboxes aligned. 

But I know I'm being unfair. It's not like these guys were working with a Capcom or Arcsystemworks budget.

It's neat, but if you're love a really good, technically-concrete beat-em-up, this isn't it. If you want an arcade kung fu movie homage, it's all right. I got through it faster than I hoped I would and it just never consistently clicked with me.

I'd really prefer there being a 'meh' option, but this is at least meh+; it's more good than bad.

I really wanted to like this. Godhand is one of my top games of all time and this is totally in that vein. Except it does too many things wrong.

Firstly, it has the "rpg elements" of gaining experience points and using them to unlock skills/upgrade your character. Except it's pointless. The unlocked moves are all unnecessary and do not help you. The combat system is not designed around unleashing your cool moves against the enemy. Its designed around defending/avoiding/guardbreaking and then punishing. So all the moves you can get are just flashy options and not utility at all. I thought the purpose of gaining experience and leveling a character was to feel like a badass by the end because of all your power. Like in Shadow of Mordor. By the end of this game, I had the same health, same damage, and still relied on the same moveset I began with. And I beat it.

Also, I do not know what the ideal "parry window" is for me but some games parrying feels great like Blasphemous or even Wo Long. And it's not rewarding like Dark Souls, it's more like Sekiro. You are just filling up their "kill me" bar. And a lot of the enemies later just feel like punch sponges. For constructive criticism, they should have made the parrying/avoiding has a bigger window and the enemies, like in Sekiro and Wo Long, could have had a reason to land multiple deathblows/executions. I think that would be way more.

All this to also point out that I only beat it on easy (Student). Hilarious considering I love Soulslikes and Roguelikes. It honestly hurts me to negatively review this game because I love martial arts, love roguelikes, love soulslike, and its moddable. But its just not well executed gameplay-wise.

Insanely fun. I just barely got started and am enjoying this immensely... even while getting my butt kicked! If you were looking for a combat game that lets you be the star of a martial arts film, this is it. Be warned though, this aint some button masher like the Arkham games. You gotta know your combos and when to deploy your more advanced moves. You wanna be the Kung Fu Hero? You gotta play Sifu.
----
Additional thoughts, which may be more of a guide, but I feel any prospective purchaser should be aware:
Keep your focus - You will get your butt kicked, repeatedly. The temptation will be to lose your cool and come back up button mashing. Don't.
Check your sense of honor - There are ten people in a room looking to kill you. You think it's unfair to use a weapon when they have none? Then you're dead. Bruce Lee faced off 20 unarmed goons in 'Enter the Dragon' with nunchucks for this reason. You're here for revenge, not to uphold a sense of honor.
Be aggressive  - Don't wait for enemies to come to you. If there's a room full of goons and one of them has their back turned to you, take that goon down without warning!
Don't play defense - This game learns from your moves. Come out swinging and parry only when you need to. If you use the same combo of strikes in succession, the enemies will counter it in short order. Keep them guessing and on their toes.
Repeat the first level - do this until you can walk into the club with 3 or more lives. 
Step away and come back - Frustrated? Take a break and come back to the game when you can keep your composure and aren't bored of repeating a level. This game is about training and honing skills. Sometimes you need to take a break for this to be effective.

Kung-fu roguelite? Sign me up. I wish the training mode let you practice against enemies using weapons, though.

[h1]This Is Probably The Closest I've Experienced Playing Fighting Games Like Street Fighter Or Tekken.[/h1]

Of course Sifu and those two are completely different, considering the former is a single-player brawler and the latter two are one on one PVP fighters. Yet, the combat in Sifu showcases a lot of similarity with those fighting games: it requires the player to pay close attention to enemies' move sets and deflect/avoid/parry accordingly; it has some simple combo inputs which allow the player to chain a series of attacks before the enemy recovers; it also punishes the player who just mashes buttons. As a result, Sifu has quite a deep learning curve. Knowing which attack you should parry and which you should dodge can be very frustrating for new player. Not gonna lie, when I finally beat the first stage, I've already reached the age of 63(and the game caps around 78). But once you master all the technique and remember all the attack patterns, you become a total one-man army that demolishes any foes standing in your way, just like in action movies.

[h1]Things I Like About Sifu:[/h1]

[b]1. One-on-one And Group Fight[/b]
Personally, I prefer the one-on-one fights because I believe those demonstrate the game's core mechanic the best. That's being said, group fights also have their own merits and satisfaction.
→[b]One-on-one[/b]: these fights are usually reserved for elites and bosses, hence are also the reason why I consider Sifu a single-player fighting game experience. Elites and bosses have a variety of combo chains that players need to learn and adapt fast, or else they will meet their untimely death, fast as well. Like fighting games, every attack can land on different position(Overhead, High, Mid, and Low) and has different timing. Players need to react to the attack by either parrying or avoiding it. Luckily the system has been simplified comparing to fighting games: all of the Overhead, High, and Mid can be parried at the right interval, and Low needs to be avoided. My biggest trouble is that some of them have fast High-Low mix-up that I always mess up. This may seem overwhelming at first, but overtime you will learn their move sets. You will find out that every attack is punishable, and you can easily turn the tide by disrupting their momentum. Then, it is your time to be aggressive, executing all the combo to deal the most structure damage. This exchange process between you and the enemy is really satisfying.
→[b]Group fights[/b]: now on the other hand, group fights require a slightly different mentality. The closest gameplay I can reference is that of Sleeping Dogs. You still need to parry and avoid attacks, except that now situational awareness plays a major role in the fight. Deduce which target should be prioritized. Use ledge and items to your advantage. Pushing enemies off the ledge deals an absurd amount of damage. Baseball bat and knife are always better than you bare hands simply because they deal significantly more structure damage. Throwing bricks and bottles basically means free beat-down section. And finally, pushing enemies around. This strategy is important. Slamming enemies into each other can create more breathing rooms, while slamming them into walls can disarm them fast and build more structure damage. Even through group fights can be hectic and unpredictable, you cannot deny the satisfaction of smoothly dispose several enemies in a quick succession.

[b]2. Other Compliments[/b]
→A rather clean and pretty art style.
→Quite a few of cool move sets to unlock.
→The game features light exploration for lore.
→Arena challenges are fun and full of references.

[h1]Things I Dislike About Sifu:[/h1]

[b]1. Rouguelite/like-like Upgrade Features Would Be Lovely[/b]
This is more of a suggestion.
I think the dragon statue upgrades throughout each stage can use some adjustments. Currently, they function as stat boosting, with some restrictions. Basically if you pass a certain age, have a lower score, or earn less XP, some upgrades will be locked for the rest of the playthrough. To me these requirements seems to be a little overkill considering Sifu is already a really punishing game. You lose score multiplier when you get hit or are playing passively. You age faster with each subsequent death, and some skills are also locked behind a certain age. What I would like to suggest about is that maybe change the dragon statue bonuses to three random buff players can choose from: one for stat-boosting, one for strengthening some of the core mechanics, and the other for utility. The buff can last the whole stage or right until the boss fight. The idea behind this roguelite/like feature is to slightly alleviate the steep learning curve of the game. Of course players should still get themselves familiar with the core mechanics and overcome the challenges the game throw at them, but at least the statue bonus can give them a glimmer of hope for success instead of a constant reminder that they suck at the game.

[b]2. Other Complaints[/b]
→Achieving Wude by sparing the five main bosses while killing hundreds of their lowlies, will never not be funny to me.
→I wish avoid can build as much structure damage as parry.

If Bruce Lee (because of setting) and Batman (because of gameplay) had a child, this would be it. Then the child was raised by loving and very dedicated developers and here we are. Great game, I can already tell.

Super fun game! 

The Structure/Focus systems are neat, they encourage equal amounts of dodging and parrying. The combat system is unique but those who have experience in the likes of Devil May Cry, Ninja Gaiden and the Arkham/Shadow of Mordor/Spider-Man combat systems will feel somewhat at home. I've heard comparisons to FromSoftware's Sekiro but I have not played this title at time of writing. 

Structure is basically a defense gauge and you can deplete that of your enemies by attacking and parrying them which will enable a health-restoring takedown. Focus is generated by landing attacks and dodging successfully and you can spend Focus on special moves that do extra damage or create favorable situations e.g. knocking an enemy to the ground, stunning them, or shoving them away. Even bosses have Structure, and you will generally defeat them by using takedowns on them twice, as depleting their health is a far less viable method of winning. 

The main standout mechanic apart from the combat system is Aging; which occurs every time you die and continue. Your age, starting from 20, will increase by the number on your death counter, which of course increases with each subsequent death, with permadeath taking place if you die at or above age 70. You decrease it by defeating elite enemies or enduring phases of boss battles. With this mechanic it is possible to "snowball" into a loss with repeated deaths, unless you revert back to previous levels (starting at the age you were when you entered them previously) and try to beat them without taking as many years off your life to improve your chances of completing the entire run. 

You earn upgrades from defeating enemies and finding jade statues and lose access to these upgrades as you age (at each 10 year milestone e.g. 30, 40, ..., 70) as well as reduced health, but you do increased damage with higher age brackets. You can prevent yourself from losing these upgrades whilst aging by upgrading them multiple times.

The snowball thing I mentioned makes it easy to be punished early for poor play, but it does encourage you to improve. The game certainly wants you to play it again and again and it is not that long. I'd give it an 8/10. 

P.S. the game also features both Mandarin and Cantonese voice tracks in addition to English. The PC performance is stellar as well as the graphics are pretty stylized and not that fancy.
