Low-poly no-texture aesthetic isn't usually my thing, but it works here.  There are negatives, but they aren't insurmountable.

The biggest design flaw is probably the camera.  Like most 3rd person camera games, Sifu's auto-positioning is imperfect, occasionally positioning the camera such that you can't see yourself, your enemies, or perhaps both.  It's easy to control and bring it back around, but doing so means you aren't attacking, which means you're probably dying.

Otherwise, my only complaint so far is the density if enemies in certain spots.  You'll spend a lot of time continuously countering as 4, 5, or 6 enemies surround and attack you while more wait in the wings, and when you're countering -- again -- you're not attacking.  This is exacerbated by the lack of a good general dodge/roll/jump mechanic to get you out of danger when you're surrounded.

Still, overall, great game.

Sifu crashes at launch almost every time.  The few times it doesn't it will crash within a minute or two of playing.  None of the suggestions on the discussions and the games support page, which are all standard troubleshooting, change anything.

The fighting is visceral, well animated and combat flows well from the controls.
Though you should get ready to knuckle down and learn your parries.

The dungeons or "hideouts" all have their unique theme and visual charm, and sometimes  have secondary or optional paths. Almost soulslike-ish you will unlock shortcuts to later parts of the level, so that each future run in a hideout (or dungeon) effectively brings you closer to it's final boss.

The age mechanic is cool, but I could see some people taking issue with having to grind the dungeons over and over for a better continue score / chance at the next dungeon.

Biggest letdown though is that the bossfights get worse every time.
The first actual boss is a nice fair challenge, with a good pace and ebb/flow of pressure between you and the bad guy.

Sifu is an excellent example of what a Martial Arts game should play like, quick as lightning, flashy but practical, and difficult.

You'll be doing all kinds of awesome stuff, punching thugs inside an abandoned apartment complex and tossing people of windows, only to jump out of said window into another apartment complex only to deck 3 baddies in the head with a spinning back kick, there are also many kinds of enviroments to punch people at like a night club, inside a skyscraper, at a museum exhibit and so on.
The game does have a fighting game style movelist, but aside from a few key moves that you'll be using, you won't need to read a book to learn all the moves, besides the game provides a very practical tutorial that you can use anytime at your hub area

The game will ease you into the gameplay with a very great intro sequence, ending with a tutorial styled as a cinematic opening to a Martial Arts movie, THIS GAME IS AWESOME and i can't stress that enough!

The Story is about a boy (or girl you can pick) who has had their father killed by a group of mysterious individuals led by a man named Yang, you shortly play as him through the intro sequence to show how powerful and intimidating he is, along with his friends.
Having his father killed in his own dojo and infront of him, the boy (or girl) will swear to [b]kill[/b] Yang and every one of his goons, and by the end of it, John Sifu will learn the true price of revenge. (thats not his real name i made it up :3)

The Gameplay is undeniably difficult compared to other games of its kind, the game does have a difficulty setting so i would reccomend it regardless of you not being a fan of hard games, the game provides a Sekiro style revive mechanic, allowing you to beat the crap of whoever just got you killed, and unlike sekiro, you can die as many times as you like!
but there's a catch, the more you die, the older you get, and the older you are, the less health you will have but you will also deal more damage to compensate, the age of your character carries on from stage to stage however so you may have to repeat a stage if you are not good enough to survive a tough boss at age 70 (the highest possible age you can have before a Game Over), though it may not be for everyone, the process re-doing a stage only to get through tough sections on a stage and smack the shit of enemies that previously got you from college debt (age 20) to midlife crisis (age 50) is unspeakably satisfying!


To conclude: The game demands constant attention and any reckless spam WILL get you killed, but as with actual Martial Arts through patience and most importantly practice, you will experience a game unlike any other!

Here's where I think it went wrong. The developers had some really fun gameplay on their hands but only 5 short levels. A game like this taking 3 hours to beat would be fine so long as there were incentives to do multiple runs. However, the devs weren't okay with the length, so they turned to their only option of  making it really hard, but they didn't want to just challenge their players, they wanted to completely decimate them. What they ended up with was Sekiro without checkpoints. They give you a limited number of lives but that comes with a caveat; the game also punishes you for losing lives. Deaths start to snowball into more deaths because your max health decreases each time, making the next heavy hit you take likelier to kill you, coupled with the fact that most grunt enemies are replaced with elite variants in later levels and you can see where the problem is. The boss fights are amazing, but they're such a ramp in difficulty that you'd be lucky to survive phase 1, let alone 2, which all bosses have. After you beat a boss you get the next level. "Hurray!" you might think, until you realise you get to carry all your deaths, your mistakes, your failures to the next level. Hope you like grinding the same stage over and over for upgrades and less deaths. All of this to make no difference against the final stage and boss, and let me tell you, the final boss is a sick joke. Focus (special) attacks don't work on him, he dodges every attack that doesn't follow a perfectly timed parry/dodge, he has a dozen combos with various parry/dodge timings that you must learn on the spot, some of which are almost unreactable, and it only takes a few attacks to get through your defense to kill you, and that's only phase 1. The difficulty of the final boss is like having to fight an Elden Ring boss at the end of a Mario game. I actually laughed out loud when I first fought him because I couldn't believe a dev would put in such a blatant f#$k you to the player, right at the end of it all. The skills system is weird, the uncooperative camera will get you killed in fights, not a fan of the limited upgrades, especially since half of them are useless on the final boss, which is the whole point of your run, music is meh, but overall, not a bad game. I think the gameplay is fun enough to excuse most of the problems, but it was so close to greatness.

On a side note, I had an easier time going for the true ending because I found an exploit that prevented me from ageing when I died. I will never tell a soul how to do it because this game is that hard and I don't want it patched.

[h1]Great ideas, flawed execution.[/h1]
I honestly wish I could recommend this game, it has a lot of great things going for it. Unique style, great animations, interesting story, and it takes inspiration from one of my favorite games of all time, Sekiro. It has a lot of unique innovative design, but it unfortunately fails in its execution. As a note, this review is based off of playing the game halfway through on Disciple (Average/intended difficulty), and halfway through on Master. I switched difficulties due to Disciple feeling too forgiving. Master is a good challenge, and it reinforces the "correct" way to play Sifu, but it also highlights all that is wrong with the game.

When Sifu is at its peak, when you're balancing tons of enemies and masterfully using the mechanics of crowd and weapon control, it is a RUSH (When you first enter the club is a perfect example). It feels like a skillful version of the old Arkham or Assassins creed games. But those moments are only sporadic, and most of your time will be spent fighting bosses or mini bosses, which at least on Master, it's not just a matter of move memorization, it is lighting quick reaction time as there is constant mix ups in their move set. All of this wouldn't be bad if there was a checkpoint system, but there isn't. So to learn a boss, you get to the boss, die a bunch learning the move set, then because you're old, you replay the ENTIRE area over.

[h1]The problem with the Age system.[/h1]
One of the main draws to this game is the aging system, but it's hardly functionally different than the lives system from old arcade games, except here you start with 50 and can't gain any more, and when you do die, you lose an unset amount of lives, while also locking you out of skills. If you die once, you'll age up one year, you die twice, two years, etc. but if you beat a difficult enemy (or buy a specific upgrade at a shrine (bonfire/checkpoint), how much you age will go down by one (it also resets if you beat an area). You start at 20 years old, and die at 70+ (Anytime you'd age after you hit 70, you die). So for an entire save, you can only die anywhere from 10 to 50 times. The game is only 5 areas. You can restart an area to the age you reached it at, to prevent game over, or to achieve a better result age wise. 

Do you see the confusion yet? If you're 38 at the end of level 1, should you restart? What about 31? If you've racked up 5 death counters mid level, should you reset, or do you hope there's enough special enemies to reduce it before the boss fight? To make matters worse, you lose total health as you age, sure you do more damage, but a player who dies a lot doesn't have the mechanics down yet, so why give them less health? You could be still in your 20's/30's by the time you beat the game because you overestimated the future difficulty, or you could be on one death away from game over on the 4th level. So at best, you've restarted a level over and over in tedium to keep your age down, and at worst you have to either brute force your way to the end, or restart half the game over to get your age down. It's sad to see this unique idea not being well thought out design wise. The age system, being a lives system, shouldn't have made it off the chopping block. They could have easily tied aging to purchasing skills and still achieved similar results (only age through buying skills, each with their own "training time").

[h1]The problem with the skill system.[/h1]
The only sense of progression is the skills, but you lose them upon Game Over. You can however permanently unlock them after 5 purchases of the same one, but doing so requires you to have replayed areas over and over. How you purchase those skills is at shrines throughout the level, using XP from defeating enemies. There are shortcuts in the game, to skip over the tedium, but I hardly used them so I could buy as many skills per run. And you'll often find, you may be too old for a current run, and instead of restarting, just play through the rest of the area just to buy skills. And that's not even mentioning the annoyance of buying the same skills over and over, or trying to use techniques you had yet to buy this run. Lastly, you'd think skills carry over on area completion (in addition to 5 unlocks), as your age is set in stone on completion, but I guess you character gets amnesia? Hopefully you see the issue again here, yet again, the game rewards the most tedious aspect of replaying an area over and over, and oddly this time around punishes the player for having few mistakes?  

Another problem is, the only way to heal, is by defeating enemies, or shrines, so you better hope any tough bad guy has tons of enemies before and after. You'll often find yourself going into tough fights with little to no health to get one shot and age up. 

[h1]It feels off[/h1]
It wouldn't be bad if everything felt tactile and responsive, but it lacks "game feel". You can deflect enemy moves with Space/LB/L1, however certain enemy moves if deflected will be a parry instead which will allow you to counter. So it almost feels random with new enemies when you get a parry and can follow up. And with dangerous moves (similar to thrusts or sweeps in Sekiro), the only indication is a orange glow on the limb they're attacking with, so you better hope your character isn't blocking your camera, which is another constant issue (Camera is honestly toughest boss). If you do land a parry, you can't combo out of it immediately, the first attack is its own "combo", then you can follow up with your own, it's just annoying having to add in an extra input ONLY when you land a parry. There's also directional inputs inspired from fighting games, so expect annoying misinputs because of that. The deflect/parry timing is strict, stricter than Sekiro. So between all of that, what you expect to happen, and what happens is often in conflict, "I deflected that!", "I was trying to kick, not punch!", etc. This of course decreases with play time, but much of the frustration could have been avoided with better design.  

So this game seems at odds whether or not it wants to punish or reward players for failing or succeeding (age vs skills) and whether or not it wants to increase or decrease replaying an area (shortcuts vs skills). The seemingly conflicting and lack of thoughtful design in conjunction with the lack of tactile responsiveness you'd expect out of game like this, makes me unable to recommend this game. Especially when the main conflict is one of if not the greatest draw to the game, the aging system. I really prefer finishing games before reviewing, but I had to stop playing because I stopped having fun (no, it wasn't because of difficulty, I spared the bosses I did beat and was in my 20's halfway through).

If the game is $10, maybe $15, I think I could recommend it (and/or with mods), it's honestly too short (besides design issues) to charge that price. And although it didn't effect the review, I also dislike the epic exclusivity deal they had.

To start, this is not Bamham, or a character action game. Thank you Sloclap for being different. You get a multitude of mechanics, different attacks, throws, blocking, parrying, and ways to dodge, and that's the fundamentals. Nothing (except takedowns) feels automatic or like a "gimme", but instead requires spacial reasoning and timing for every action taken

The difficulty pacing is amazingly done. The first playthrough can be a difficult one, as you get used to the unconventional controls and fundamentals. Playing through longer, you learn to adapt to different attacks and fighting styles, forcing you to git gud at different mechanics. On top of everything, you will learn new skills that will either save you in a pinch, manage the crowd, or help your aggro. Replaying the story and arenas will help you with playing around and mastering different methods.

The story is basic, but having a "Fists of Fury" story type really sells a Kung Fu game. Classic Kung Fu Movie fans (and Korean thriller fans) will appreciate the style choices. 

Usually I make these things funny but I really gotta praise Sloclap for making my favorite game. I am excited to see what they make in the future (I suggest grappling/wrestling)

A combination of brawler, soulslike and roguelike, Sifu is a great game. It looks good and the sound design is solid. Gameplay-wise you have your basic attacks and you unlock upgrades along the way that make you stronger. One interesting design decision is that if you buy an upgrade enough, it will be permanently unlocked. There are also more "roguelike" upgrades that never get permanently unlocked but serve a greater purpose such as having a higher stamina bar in a particular run.
The game design is also very interesting. And I say it in a good way. There are 5 levels in this game and you can find "secrets" in them that enable different shortcuts, sometimes even the whole level can be skipped which is great if you just want to go to the boss fight. And some of these unlocks are within other levels, so you can find a key in level 4 that can unlock a secret passage in level 1. These shortcuts stay forever. I think this is clever and a very nice addition. Levels themselves are quite different from each other and very creative in their design.
As I said, once you beat all 5 levels, you can play the whole game again to go for the good ending and if you unlocked all those shortcuts, it will probably be a much smoother playthrough than your first one. You also unlock game modifiers and "achievements" per level that give you points towards unlocking more of these modifiers. These include things from making you invincible to enemies dealing more damage, etc. Most of these modifiers don't count towards high scores but they are a nice addition if you want to replay the game a lot. There's also an arena mode which I haven't tried but the point still stands: it has a ton of replayability.
Now my biggest complain with the game is also on its design and it comes in terms of difficulty. Combat plays out a lot like a souls-like which is perfectly fine, I've played most of them and I like them, but in my case I found Sifu's normal difficulty extremely hard and frustrating. Halfway through the game I switched to easy which improved my experience a thousand times but it was a little too easy for me. There's also a hard mode that I have no intention in trying but knowing this I think I would have organised the game a little different: easy mode should stay as easy, then normal mode should be somewhere in between easy and normal, normal should be hard, and hard should be nightmare or something like that.
That said, the game requires a lot of skill and patience. Easy makes it much less punishing but it's still quite a challenge to get used to the combat and to perform parries, combos, etc. I had a lot of fun playing this once I switched to easy. Before that, I was a bit mad and frustrated at the game being so punishing. 
Story is okay. I enjoyed it but I wouldn't say it changed my life. It's good and it's well integrated into the game. More levels could have made it a bit more explicit and add depth but what's there is serviceable.
Overall, I'd definitely recommend. It's probably gonna be on my top 10 list at the end of the year, but in my case it didn't do enough to become my GOTY of 2023.

I am not a fan of souls-like games, and I thought it was largely because of the static enemies and repetitive nature of the levels and the unfairness inherent in finding new enemy types...

Turns out it was just the unfairness, because I love Sifu and the enemies stay roughly the same in each stage. 

Yes, there are multiple enemy types in Sifu and you are likely to get taken out by a new move set that you haven't encountered... but all of the enemies are human. They have four limbs that move in limited ways, and weapons which also have limited angles of attack. Once you understand where blows can come from, it becomes a much smoother experience which allows for more adaptable responses to new threats. You also don't lose as much of your progress and, if you fully die, you still have a chance to  use the experience you gained to make permanent skill unlocks. Also the enemies do have SOME variation on replaying a stage; one time a certain enemy may become strong after a take down and another time it is a different enemy. In one run maybe an enemy picks up a weapon they didn't get before. It isn't SO static that every fight is totally predictable.

The skill tree and revival mechanics are too convoluted, but they do work. You can choose to grind the game as much or as little as you want, but you have most of the skills you need to win right out of the gate. It just takes practice, determination, and mastering the flow of combat to really be successful. You start to seize openings, read an opponent long before their attack, and anticipate methods of isolating individuals from groups. Skills really are just the icing on the cake, allowing you to really punish opponents and take advantage of openings.

The game also teaches you HOW to get good while you play. All bosses have two phases. The second boss has a first phase where there are almost unlimited weapons to use, and in the second phase all the weapons are gone. Why? The game is trying to teach you that you don't need them. You need to get good at parry and avoid mechanics, and that is what this boss is a test of. 

The visual design is also incredible. Truly beautiful settings with no small amount of visual storytelling combine to create an almost mystical experience. A friend of mine said the sound of impacts could have been more realistic and that there could have been more realistic blood, but fundamentally this game isn't about realism. No one is pulling off these kinds of victories in real life, so it is better to think of it as a more cinematic experience anyway. Every level is uniquely beautiful, and even all of the arena areas are novel. I was honestly expecting a rehashing of old levels, but the arenas truly are an expansive addition of new areas and challenges to enjoy. 

The game is fantastic. I think at 44 hours I've had as much fun as I will have for now, but I'm sure in a year or two I will have lost all my skill, forgotten some of the enemy layouts, and it would be fun to start over from the beginning. It definitely takes perseverance, but honestly that is determined more by your desire for perfection than by the game necessitating it. I replayed the second stage SO MANY TIMES to make it through without dying... but I was proud when I did, and happy in the fact that I wouldn't need to go back there again. When I just squeaked through the ending at age 25 I felt as though I had truly mastered the game and that sense of mastery just doesn't exist in many games.

The combat is quite deep with many, many options available for offense and defense. It's rewarding and satisfying to learn and improve at. Since combat is pretty much all there is to this game, the fact that it's so good means the game as a whole is mostly a good experience.

Nevertheless, there are a few blemishes. There isn't very much content here, even if what you get is very high quality. A lot of effort is spent getting you to replay levels to stretch that. Bosses are, of course, the hardest part of the game and losing to them means you need to redo the whole stage. It's pretty much guaranteed that your first few attempts at a boss will be losses while you try to learn their moves and figure out dodge and parry timings, which means doing the stage over and over. Even after getting your first stage clear, you'll probably feel the need to redo the stage anyway so as to finish with more age (a sort of limited extra life mechanic) left for the rest of the game. I achieved the normal ending on standard difficulty after just 11 hours, and getting the true ending just requires you to replay the whole game again while making one small change in each stage.

The final stage is also a bit of an anticlimax, as it's short even by this game's standards and the final boss himself turns off one of the more fun mechanics and feels like a step down in difficulty.

With all that being said, I would still strongly recommend this game to anybody looking for a highly challenging action combat game, as the core combat mechanics are just that good.

I desperately wanted to like this game more than I did. In theory its a ton of fun and super stylish. 

Problem is learning the game well relies not only on memorizing and managing to pull off a number of combo's and button presses in the blink of an eye, it requires you to also memorize attack patterns and combos and be able to read them instantly. 

For example, the dodge/block/countering mechanic doesn't just require you to time it correctly (with a very small window), but most/many attacks also require you to dodge/counter in the correct direction (high vs Low). So when an enemy goes for an attack, you need to already know if its going to be a high attack or low attack and respond accordingly. 

Good in theory, but again, the timing on it is insanely narrow. Other games with counter/dodge mechanics tend to give you 2x or 3x as much time to react, and require less mechanical input to carry out. Its not just "Press LB to dodge", its "Hold LB and flick the control stick in the appropriate direction, oops your timing was good, but guessed the wrong direction"

Additionally, as I mentioned, you need to memorize attack patterns too, because while early enemies will only attack once or will stagger if you block them, others will attack in 2-3 hit combos. Issue is, after a successful dodge or block, you have a brief window to counter attack. This is a problem because the emphasis is on BRIEF. If you wait a fraction of a second to see if they have a followup attack, you'll miss your window, but if you try to counter and they're only hit 2 a 3 attack combo, you're going to get hit instead. 


Given high complexity of the game, I could see it being fun if you literally have dozens of hours available to get really good at it. I imagine it would feel incredibly satisfying to be able to dance and weave around enemies, being a full on Bruce Lee. 

However, if you're like me and don't have that much time to invest in what is a relatively shallow game, I cant recommend it. 

Any game that requires you to spend that much time just to start having fun, isn't getting a recommendation from anyone with limited time to game. 

tl;dr If you have the surplus time and patience to learn the fighting system and have the hair trigger reflexes and pattern recognition skills the game requires, its probably a lot of fun. For the rest, however, the barrier for entry is too high and will likely just cause frustration.

Sifu  might be the most difficult game I had to play (I'd say quite close to Sekiro), but it also has one of the most enjoyable fighting system I've seen. It really allows the player to get creative with how they approach any situation, and it's pure joy to finally manage to clear difficult encounter without dying.

Talking about dying, Sifu does something really interesting with its age system. I've heard some people found it frustrating to start the same levels over and over again, but personally I thought it was really smart. It allows you a lot of leniency with the first levels, so you should be able to see the end of them even if you end up being 60yo, but then it pushes you to come back, train and get better, without forcing you. The level  design itself is built around this: the first time you go through a level, you're forced to explore everything. Then you unlock shortcuts which allow you to go through the level quickly, avoiding unnecessary risks. Once you're comfortable, you can then go back to do the level completely, taking more bonuses in the process.

This is very Kung Fu: do it again and again until your movement is perfect. And as a kung fu practitioner myself, I feel that the game really reproduced the philosophy of martial arts training really well. To talk a bit about the moves themselves, they're cool as shit. I don't think it portrays realistic fights, but I'm pretty sure it was not the goal. Sifu makes you live though Hong Kong cinema fight scenes, and makes you feel like Donnie Yen or Jackie Chan. You're not in a street fight, you're in Ip Man or Drunken Master.

So I recommend this game with all my heart, with the only caveat that the difficulty might be a problem for some people.

Sifu is an intense kung fu brawler that demands a lot of practice and patience to master. Each death you suffer will leave its mark on your body, progressively aging until you are too old to fight. On your path to revenge the only way forward is to master the art of kicking ass.

[h1]Combat[/h1]
Every character, including yours, has both a traditional health bar, as well as a structure bar (equivalent to posture in Sekiro). You can defeat any enemy by either depleting their health with plain attacks or damaging their structure. Performing blocks at precisely the right time or moves that throw enemies off balance, will increase the structure bar until it's filled up. This will open someone up for a takedown move that instantly kills them, regardless of remaining health.

Most of the time you will be surrounded by crowds of foes fighting you at once, which means you often can't focus on killing a single enemy at a time. Instead, you will have to react to whoever is the most immediate threat and get them away from you just long enough to deal with the next one. Good situational awareness over your opponents and thinking on your feet are a crucial skills to pick up.

In addition to combos that deal plain damage, some moves have specific utility purposes. Palm strikes can push an enemy away from you to create some space. Leg sweeps knock them onto the ground and disarm them. With throws you can knock someone into a nearby wall for additional damage, or into a crowd to stagger many foes at once. Brute force alone usually isn't enough to do well, but utilizing the environment and choosing the right moves will help tremendously.

Occasionally you will get the chance to pick up weapons like wooden bats or staffs, letting you deal more damage and extending your reach. They are very potent against weaker enemies, who will go down in far fewer strikes. Weapons have limited durability and won't last forever, so you can't rely on them at all times, but in certain troublesome encounters the extra edge can make or break a fight. Throwing your weapon can also stun and massively hurt whoever is unlucky enough to be in the way.

Combining all the various aspects of combat and using them effectively isn't going to come naturally right away. You may start out just circling around groups, trying to play it safe while fishing for lucky hits with some stray punches. The game encourages you to replay stages a LOT, becoming gradually bolder and more secure with your grasp on the mechanics until they become firmly embedded as instinct. This is the point where you will begin making many split-second decisions resulting in impressive looking strings of moves, that knock enemies all over the place and leave nobody in the room with any chance to catch their breath.

[h1]Difficulty[/h1]
Upon death, the game allows you to resurrect right on the spot and carry on fighting immediately. This comes at the cost of your character's age increasing each time you continue. Growing too old means you lose for good and have to restart the level. After beating a level, your current age is saved as a starting point for the next one, so when you die of old age, you only lose progress of the current stage. You can go back to previous ones and try to beat them with fewer deaths, to give you more room for mistakes in the late game, which is very much encouraged.

After struggling to finish the early levels without wasting too many years, it might seem like a monumental task to ever be beating the whole game, let alone replaying it for the true ending. However, you'll find that repeated runs of a level will go by MUCH faster and smoother as your experience grows. Lost health is easily regained with takedowns, and improving at reading and responding to enemies will allow you to do them faster and more reliably.

Consistently playing very badly will eventually force you to start over and try to do better. With overall decently skillful play however, the occasional misstep will not become a serious obstacle. The game is much more forgiving than it makes itself seem, it asks not for perfection, but you do have to grow alongside the game's increasingly demanding challenges.

Bosses are less forgiving, and likely where you will burn most of your deaths on. They tend to react better to some of your "dirty" moves and generally aren't as easily overwhelmed as regular enemies. The emphasis lies more on learning the precise patterns on when to block and evade them. It's a very different pace from the rest of the game and feels a lot more rigid in how you overcome them. Luckily, being able to resurrect means you are less likely to be stuck with retrying a boss forever, unless you want to go for minimum deaths.

[h1]Technical Issues[/h1]
Motion Blur and Temporal Antialiasing cannot be disabled easily in-game, it is necessary to edit "Engine.ini" in "%localappdata%\Sifu\Saved\Config\WindowsClient" and add these lines at the end:

[SystemSettings]
r.MotionBlurQuality=0
r.PostProcessAAQuality=0

I would also recommend installing the game on an SSD if possible. The game loads chunks of the level during gameplay when you pass certain load triggers. This causes a noticeable stutter, which is made worse by being installed on a hard drive. Installing it on an SSD doesn't make it fully go away, but it makes it much more bearable. I'm not sure why proper asynchronous loading wasn't implemented, since consistent stutters in the same areas are quite annoying when replaying levels over and over again. Thankfully most of the time they don't interfere with combat. The game runs fine and without hitches during regular gameplay.

[h1]Final Judgement[/h1]
This is easily my favorite game that I discovered this year. It captures the vibe of a gritty, chaotic martial arts movie, not only with its combat, but also with the attention to detail. Little unpredictable moments like enemies accidentally hitting each other in a crowded hallway or furniture breaking apart into improvised weapons go a long way to make fights feel immersive. The animations for EVERYTHING are incredibly smooth and incorporate the nearby environment very seamlessly, such as unique takedown animations for slamming someone's face into a kitchen table, should you find yourself next to one.
Everything about this game is executed masterfully and it all comes together to an incredibly satisfying experience, that is going to stick with me for a while.

Sifu is worth full price.

This game was made for me.

As someone who's been doing Karate for 21 years, seeing a developer create such an incredible re-playable challenging Martial Arts experience with such an interesting concept of Death and Life as a mechanic... I'm blown away.

Learning Martial Arts requires a few things: Desire to learn, trial and error, consistent practice, and working through failure to come back and apply what you've learned from your failure. Getting good at this game draws a clear parallel to learning martial arts, and it's beautiful. It's one of the few stylized games I like (I most go for super realistic graphics and realistic games, but the gameplay within this game is exceptional and gives me the ability to overlook the painted poly-look of the game.)

This game is challenging, but rewarding. I wouldn't consider this game punishing (like some souls games ie. Sekiro, Elden Ring, DS 1, 2, 3, The Surge 1 &2, etc.), this game provides opportunity through defeat. With each death you incur, you grow older, which hardens you. You lose a small bit of your health bar over time, but your damage increases. It balances even in defeat. If you're a new player and you want a less challenging experience, it offers multiple difficulty settings including unlockable cheats and modifiers (requiring some effort to unlock, but very rewarding)

If you're considering getting the DLC outfits, here is a warning to someone hoping to buy the outifts and have them waiting for you on your next load-in. They're locked. You need to earn them (like everything else in the game) through completing challenges that include some serious modifiers.

Do I recommend this game? Yes. Get it. You won't regret it.
Is the game easy? No. If you plan on jumping in and dominating, you will not (without some serious willingness to learn the enemy attacks, enemy types, movesets, situational attacks, dodging, parrying, deflecting, your structure bar, etc.)
Is the game rewarding?

It's one of the most rewarding games I've ever played. Worth every dollar and worth every minute.

Great game with a good amount of difficulty. Every time I load it up I find my self getting better. Making use of the training room for certain enemies and even bosses is a fantastic feature that I wish a lot of games had.

The design of the game mechanics overall is probably my favorite thing. Resurrecting and becoming older with each death which in turn changes your stats and available skills that you can unlock is neat and makes you think about what you should try unlocking first. The shortcuts that open up thanks to keys you've picked up from your previous runs help a ton and calm my frustration immensely by saving me a ton of time, especially those shortcuts that lead straight to the boss.

I only have two complaints: The first one is my interpretation of the tutorial made me feel like parrying was way more helpful than it actually is when instead almost every boss becomes significantly easier if you just dodge instead. Maybe I just misunderstood the tutorial so this complaint is slightly nit-picky.

My second complaint is that I feel like the last boss, the person who is the sole reason you set out on this revenge path in the first place, feels very lackluster in terms of appearance and the fight itself. All other previous bosses have better settings and introductions in my opinion.

tl;dr: good hard game, very little to complain about, the game mechanics are clever and allow replayability without feeling tedious and instead encourage improvement in your own abilities while giving you the tools to do so.

Great action game with a twist.
The martial arts action is grounded in reality while remaining satisfyingly fancy. While the more flashy moves are a bit tricky to execute well, the game-play rewards skill and precision. The action is captured well in stylised and well done graphics. The character ageing mechanic is an interesting twist and is more than just a visual change (took me a couple of hours to notice the age-related change in stats).

The locations you fight in are varied, well done, provide avenues for several different approaches, and some are absolutely gorgeous.

Initially I had one gripe with this game and that was the camera, but then I realised it is just another aspect to be mastered: if you want to be able to always see all of your opponents, you have to be mindful of where you position yourself and remain in control of the flow of the fight. While it may be frustrating at times, for me it just adds another layer of depth to the fight and in a sense makes it even more grounded, as maintaining visibility and awareness is something you'd expect to be an aspect of a real fight, especially involving multiple opponents.

If grounded martial arts action and game-play that rewards skill and precision sound interesting to you, I think you'll like this game.

Sifu is a difficult but fair beat 'em up. There are many rougelite elements, as well as permanent progression rewards.

My favorite part of the entire game is the satisfaction experienced once obtaining some level of mastery over the dodge/parry mechanic. I completed the game on PS5 when it was initially released, and I am looking forward to doing so again on my PC/Steam Deck (solid 60 fps on the deck, with occasional frame drops and load stutters), The additional arena challenges look like a lot of fun, and I would absolutely recommend this game to anyone interested in difficult beat-em-ups/souls-likes. It is very fair and approachable, but requires a decent level of skill to fully appreciate.

It's Sekiro all over again...

This is a branch of game design that just does not resonate with me in any way. Being a knowledge check in the most thinly veiled way. Sifu looks much better than I expected, with great environmental design and fights reminiscent of Oldboy. The controls are strongly inspired by fighting games, utilizing direction inputs, direction changes, directional double tapping and presumably more. A complicated control scheme is fairly easily justified here if it yields gameplay expressiveness.

The best comparison I can make is a bit of gameplay footage where a streamer beats Malenia in Elden Ring using no armor and only their fist. The fight takes around 2 hours. All the while he's casually speaking with his friends. He has crossed the "knowledge check" by such comical margins nothing of the game remains but repetition of the same trick. That's Sifu. It hides the challenge by being ambiguous about what to do, but once that facade is dropped it's just repetition. Enemies abide by attack patterns that repeat and as such can be dealt with using the appropriate directional movements. You can also parry these attacks. Parrying is a notorious muscle-memory check, and once again Sifu is no different. 

It's one interpretation of having the player optimize their gameplay. In some games the challenge is conveyed to you very clearly. Examples include Doom Eternal and Hogwart's Legacy. In other games the challenge is veiled in ambiguity, like Sekiro or Sifu. Even though neither is inherently "bad", the latter gets away with primarily "feeling like" it's challenging, despite it not really being that at all. The mod that displays the parry frames in Sekiro makes the game trivial. Why? Because the entire challenge lies in you making sense of seemingly arbitrary attack patterns - and this ambiguity masquerades the challenge (note that this applies only to the bossfights, Sekiro has much more going for it outside that too). And the fact that this almost looks like a challenge fools people into believing it actually is.

Sifu has a lot going for it fortunately, such as using the terrain and minor positioning optimization that can both be utilized to visibly increase the player's effectiveness. But the core gameplay loop is really just "know what to do, then jump through the hoop", constituting most of the challenge it offers.

I continue to be disappointed by the fact that games designed through this train of thought resonate with people so much, just because they don't really understand it and it feeling profound as a consequence. It offers no dynamic challenge but to just do the same thing over a few times until the muscle memory kicks in.

The game is fun... For a while. It is challenging with straightforward mechanics to learn from. Think Jet Li in Rise to Honor for PS2 meets Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice. The fighting is closer to Jeet Kun Do from what I, a non-martial artist, can see. I would prefer the flashiness of shaolin, but it probably doesn't fit with the setting. If you like Sekiro and have beat Sekiro, you may like this game.

Sifu borrows the posture system from Sekiro's combat with a story like Rise to Honor as you fight to avenge your *insert loved one here*. The controls are tight and it seems to do well with what it establishes. I don't feel like it expands upon enough of the combat for me to keep playing. It seems like parrying is also visually vague, I can never tell when I parry or not. 

The aging feature is cool; a way to introduce limited lives that doesn't feel like you are just counting down. As you age, you deal more damage but have less health and less access to certain upgrades. I would guess that you eventually die and have to start over.

Some issues that I feel should be addressed is playing in 21:9 resolutions. It isn't possible to bring the HUD into view, it is still in the far corners of the screen. It can be adjusted a small amount, but it should be more. This may solve the parrying issue I had, letting me know if I have been hit since I can see my health bar, since whether you get hit or not is also vague. Also, you can't turn off the film grain. This isn't the original Mass Effect, this is a new game; we have learned to make film grain an option, not a feature. Film grain messes with some ReShade configurations and since I can't turn film grain off, I can't use ReShade how I want to.

Sloclap takes their legendary combat system pioneered with Absolver and makes it easier to digest for a large player base in Sifu. Sifu simplifies the combat aspects of Absolver, focusing less on the fighting styles and  positioning relative to your opponent- and focusing instead on large 1 v 2+ encounters, environmental combat, and general "beat em up" mechanics like the combo meter. 

Sifu is not oversimplified, however. The talisman system will keep you coming back for the game's 20+ hour playtime (on hard difficulties) and allow you to feel your progression through your deaths. 

Ultimately, Sifu will never be as replayable as Absolver, but the appeal of Sifu is so broad that it will certainly outperform Sloclap's debut title. As much as I personally wish for Absolver to return or be expanded upon, Sifu is more than good enough for now

A phenomenal martial arts brawler. As if Sekiro, the Batman Arkham games and Devil May Cry had a baby, with a love for kung fu cinema throughout. Lovely choreography, and a colorful art-style. Nobody uses guns, even chefs know kung-fu, the boss stages do not make logical sense so long as they look cool, AND I LOVE IT.

Yes, speedrunners can complete the story (a standard kung-fu revenge plot consisting of 5 levels) in ~2h, but there is a ton of replayability. If you are into mastering combat mechanics and enjoy repeating levels to improve your score and performance, there will be plenty to keep you busy, for example:

* Trying to reach each level at a younger age (you get "older" as you die, with final death at age 70), as you can repeat any level at the youngest age you reached it at.
* Testing yourself in (currently) 45 challanges. These almost work as separate levels, as you encounter arenas you never saw in the story mode - rooftops, restaurants, warehouses, etc. Hopefully there are more to come.
* Adding modifiers to your playthrough - from making enemies tougher, to removing your ability to resurrect, to replacing your moves with ones used by certain enemies.
* Kicking the difficulty up a notch. I've been playing mostly on Disciple (recommended/default) difficulty, but the jump to Master difficulty is quite noticable. So just when you think you've mastered the game, it can put up more of a fight.

I understand the 40 EUR price tag can seem a bit much, but I think the game is well worth it at any sale. I got it for 30 EUR and think the value for money is top notch.

Finally, an honorable mention to the training mode, where you can pick any foe you've encountered (including bosses!) to practice the parry/dodge timing of their moveset. This is not an easy game, but the difficulty feels very fair, and it is very satisfying to see your skills improve.

I like challenging games like this. Dark Souls is one of my favorite games of all time. I loved God Hand. I don't have a problem with games that force you to learn the mechanics to succeed. The problem is that games that work like that need to be fair and have functional mechanics. Sifu just doesn't. There is a a clear problem with input lag. Parry timings are vague, and have minimal feedback if successful. Slipping is frustrating to use. It frequently feels like enemies (especially bosses) play by different rules than you do. It's intensely frustrating to constantly fight special enemies that will just power through your attacks no matter what you do. Combos also feel inconsistent. It's a struggle to get the game to actually execute combos consistently with the input lag on PC, and a good number of the combos you can unlock are useless. The game is very low on content and uses unfair mechanics to force you to repeatedly replay the small amount of content there is. I really love Kung Fu genre stuff. I love brawlers like God Hand and the Arkham games. I really want to like this game. I just can't.

If I were to describe this game in a few words, those words would be "That I got better, and tried harder". The game just arrived on PC and I have been hyped for it ever since its original release on consoles. When you first start this game, you expect to start as a Chinese badass who can stomp anyone in their path, but you start to actually "play the game" you end up at age 67 by the second boss. Sifu is a difficult game, but isnt impossible. If you favor games that has a fun factor based from the players ability to mess with the combo system provided, then this game is perfect. I found myself spamming block and a basic LM + LM + RM combo, but then I turned into IP Man as I was able to perfectly parry and dodge every enemy by my 5th run over the story mode. The skills and abilities that the game give you barely change the difficulty, it tests your knowledge on how to use it. You can acquire more health on take-downs through the shrines to get new combos and buffs, but you end up dying before you can take down an enemy. The game has an obvious learning curve once you get into it. The game wont spoon feed you. You will have to use your feeble, new-born hands to grasp that spoon and feed yourself like a grown adult.  After getting all achievements in this game, I can say for certain that if this game doesn't break your monitor, then it would surely have shattered your spirit before hand. You can give up and put down your keyboard day after day, but there is that backbone of hope that you can complete this game. Overall, Sifu is a great combo-chaining, gamer raging experience that is "pakked" full of YOUR blood, sweat, and tears. 8.5/10

What this game is and what it isn't:  It isn't an action rpg with an elaborate story mode.  It's 5 stages, that skill level permitting, is around 4 hours to beat.  That said, what this game is it does extremely well.  This is a beat em up, with a very very good/tight combat system.  It's a perfectionist's wet dream in terms of content from that aspect.  After the initial play through, you'll want to go back to stages and complete them with a better age.  The game has a detective board to fill, and certain clues/collectibles (such as a set of keys, access code, etc.) are found in later stages to open previously locked areas of the earlier stages.  Right off the rip when you begin this game, go to the training dummy.  The combat system is rewarding/punishing and understanding the basics of defense is essential.  Its easy to just start button mashing at first, resist the urge and favor defense (avoid and parry specifically).  Said training dummy can also be used to spar with mobs you've encountered in the game (perfect for practicing troublesome foes).  There are also stage modifiers within the game that can be enabled to increase/decrease the challenge. As well as "student" and "master" difficulties.  Student difficulty is still challenging enough to keep you engaged and trying to improve, don't be ashamed to utilize it for your initial play through.  You can permanently unlock skills using experience, these skills carry over to new games.  In short, if disciple is a bit rough in the beginning give student a go and then return to disciple once you've gained confidence (and unlocked skills).  Outside of story mode, there is also an arena.  Arena is essentially an arcade of various scenarios with specific challenges to complete.  Pure and simple enjoyment and additional content for the Sifu addict.  

If you enjoy the combat system and the challenge it presents, there's plenty of hours worth of play/replay to be found in this game.  You'll be striving to clear every stage while staying young, completing your detective board, and unlocking all your skills.  The plot and setting of the game, although short and simple, create a nice vibe and back story justifying going Jackie Chan on hordes of mobs.  Great game and highly recommended, but definitely a hit or miss title depending on gaming preferences.

This game has done for games what John Wick did for action movies. There's really nothing quite like it, other than its predecessor Absolver. Not many games out there capture the martial artist's feel. A few samurai games sure, a ninja assassin here but they just tend to be stealth-stab or action-slash adventures while this game is a bit more methodical.

What we have here is a roguelike, martial arts tale of revenge. Only five levels that aren't very long on their own but normal players will likely spend a few hours just mastering the first two or so. Every time you die or fail, you age up some years (variable depending on difficulty, on Student I was only aging up one year per death) which makes you do more damage as you become more practiced, but your health bar declines as your frail body does. 

Because I played on the easiest setting for my first run (taking around 3 hours total), I made it to around 24. I also downloaded a moveset mod inspired by The Raid which I think was a bit overpowered but feels and looks great. Moveset modders seem to be able to actually affect damage and conditions against enemies, and apparently there was some disarming effect in my combos that disarmed the second boss rendering him fairly helpless against me. It's pretty funny, but something to keep in mind. Yeah, I wouldn't call myself very good at this game but I'm still having a ton of fun.

Even modded up, I plan on doing one more run as a Student and then upping my difficulty one stage. There's a fair bit of replayability here, especially when you consider all the outfits and other game modes. Every level also has multiple routes, some let you skip some enemies and get to the end quicker. I found one of these one accident on my second attempt at the first level, which sadly skipped the "Oldboy" inspired hallway fight scene, which I quite adore.

In theory, if you're a better combo-clicker than I am, you can probably blow through the game in an hour or two and be done with it. It's more setting personal goals for yourself, and even unlocking a literal mechanic called "Goals" that you can hunt down for extra in-game achievements that affect all kinds of aspects of the game. Some make it easier, some make it harder. I find the variable customization rather comfortable for my basic self.

Like what John Wick did for movies, breaking down action into its bare essentials and just running everything by stuntwork, Sifu trims the fat of most games. There's not much left to say about it. It's just... fun, just as it is. Certainly a developer to keep an eye on.

One of the best games I've played, hands down. I had a few problems with it but I'll touch on that in a second. The art style is stylized and therefore whether or not you find it "good" is subjective but I really liked it. The music is amazing. The level designs are some of the best I have ever seen in a game. The attention to detail and beautiful backdrops really made it feel fine playing the same levels over and over. The museum in particular had some really interesting things going on that I don't want to spoil, but I will say they took the time to make entire exhibits that pass for real art - and genuinely interesting art at that. 

The combat is hard to learn but feels amazing once you master it. It's fast paced but methodical and gets better and more rewarding as you learn the game. It can be frustrating at first but learning the complexities is an extremely rewarding experience. The story is also genuinely interesting. I was worried about there only being 5 bosses, but they're so well developed from finding pieces for your investigation board, as well as through environmental storytelling across the levels. Every boss had a unique personality, role, and combat mechanics. 

All of that said, the one thing is that I found parts of the game confusing. The rogue lite elements are poorly explained and I found it confusing to understand what carried over when I started a "new run" (which was also confusing, because you can start a new run from a previous level which feels like continuing an old run rather than starting a new one and it wasn't clear to me that that's what I was doing until I googled how all of it works). Confusion aside, everything else in the game in a masterpiece.

As a long time For Honor player that is able to react to the majority of the moves, built up my spacial awareness I found this game to be super fun and easy to pick up. The big fights and bosses are not difficult so far and the combat is very fun and free. I was able to get the game fresh and pass the first 2 levels, including bosses, in one age cycle (70+ age). 
The game is very much worth it with, especially with the addition of arenas. Fun to dodge and parry your way through groups of people untouched.

This is my second time buying this game after having completed it on the PS5 when it originally came out, I personally have never found any other action game that grabbed me quite like this, Sifu may not have the in-depth combat expression that Japanese hack and slash games like DMC, Bayonetta or Ninja Gaiden may provide, but for me personally none of those games inspired me to master their combat systems quite like Sifu did. I think the reason for that is because by design Sifu is a hard game that understands that its players require a learning curve to get good at it, games like DMC for example hit you with these insanely cool moves that Dante can do in a cutscene without much effort and when trying to replicate that in game, it almost feels like a deflating experience to a new player who cannot possibly match the bravado of the great Dante Pizza Man. 

This isn't a criticism of those games, they are fantastic action games, but I almost find myself too discouraged from the get go (on higher difficulties). Sifu on the other hand felt more welcoming because it knew that it was a hard game and death is such an integral mechanic in the game that it allows for a less discouraging experience. Unlike Dark Souls or Sekiro, where upon death you are revived at the last bonfire or idol, Sifu allows you to revive right at the spot you died, this is an incredibly helpful mechanic especially against bosses, this means that you get at least 6-8 tries before you are sent back to the beginning of the level and gives you just enough time to understand the boss's moveset along with the layout of the level. For me death in Sifu never frustrated me or deflated me like in other challenging games, and that's why I think I resonated with it so much.

I replayed the main campaign on Master difficulty on PC and it felt like playing the game for the first time again. It was daunting at first but much like my original play-through if you stick with it and begin to practice, you enter a zone that few games can entrance you in. I was able to complete most levels on Master difficulty under 30, and will try to do a no-death run once I get enough time. In addition to that I think the Arena modes are a fantastic addition that I wish was in the game during its launch period, they allow for other mechanics to shine and really teach the player how to master different techniques during gameplay, that I didn't use during my initial playthrough, such as grabs, directional throws, chasing trip kick, flowing claw etc. Overall it feels like a complete package and I highly recommend this game to any fan of action games, it can be challenging but I think the addition of an easier difficulty will allow lesser experienced players to ease in to the game's mechanics, but for the true experience I do recommend playing the game on the original disciple difficulty if you are well versed with 3D action games. 

I feel like this game really didn't get the appreciation it deserved when it came out, despite selling well, I feel like Elden Ring largely overshadowed its presence and it didn't really get to shine the way I think it deserved. Good action games are few and far between and I really believe Sifu stands among the best, I have played most of the popular action games, and as a casual gamer, Sifu really made me want to become a better player and I can't really say that about other video games that I usually play and for me that's what makes this a special experience. In addition to that I do think the narrative, while simple, is told with elegance and brevity, the cutscenes are impactful and to the point, they are very well animated, and the art style is gorgeous. It provides just enough colour to draw you into its world, but it never distracts from the impact of the more serious tone of the story it is telling. I also think the way it conveys its themes in association with martial arts was quite touching, and each time I reach the true ending, a part of me is unquestionably moved by the final image.

Title: Sifu: A Gripping Martial Arts Journey of Vengeance

Review:

Sifu is an extraordinary martial arts game that immerses players into a captivating world of revenge, where every punch, kick, and parry carries an emotional weight. Developed by the talented team at Sloclap, Sifu offers an unforgettable experience that not only tests your combat prowess but also fuels your determination to avenge your father's honor.

From the moment you step into the shoes of the protagonist, you're greeted with an atmospheric world that oozes with authenticity. The attention to detail is impeccable, and the environments feel alive with bustling city streets, traditional dojos, and neon-lit alleyways. Every location exudes a sense of depth and history, further enhancing the immersive experience.

The combat mechanics in Sifu are the heart and soul of the game. Every fight is a thrilling dance of strategy, timing, and skill. The fluidity of the animations and the precision of the controls make each punch and kick feel impactful and satisfying. The learning curve is steep but incredibly rewarding. With each encounter, you'll gain wisdom and finesse, gradually evolving from a novice fighter to a masterful martial artist.

What truly sets Sifu apart is its ability to evoke genuine emotions within players. The story centers around seeking revenge for the death of your father, and this deeply personal motivation fuels your every move. As you progress through the game, facing challenging enemies and overcoming seemingly insurmountable odds, you can't help but feel a burning desire to avenge your father's memory. It's a testament to the game's narrative and character development that it instills such a strong emotional connection.

Furthermore, Sifu excels in portraying the physical toll that revenge exacts upon the protagonist. Each time you fall in battle, your character ages, becoming more weathered and worn. This unique mechanic adds an extra layer of tension and urgency to fights, as you're not only battling your opponents but also fighting against the relentless march of time. It's a visual representation of the sacrifices you're willing to make to achieve your goal.

The audio design in Sifu deserves special mention. The hauntingly beautiful score, composed by talented musicians, heightens the intensity and atmosphere of the game. The sound effects are visceral and pack a punch, ensuring that every strike you land or receive resonates with impact.

In conclusion, Sifu is an exceptional martial arts game that combines a richly crafted world, deep combat mechanics, and an emotionally charged narrative. It leaves players with an undeniable desire to avenge their father's honor, immersing them in a journey of growth, perseverance, and ultimately redemption. If you're a fan of martial arts, gripping storytelling, and intense action, Sifu is an absolute must-play that will leave you breathless and longing for more.

Sifu is a Kung Fu brawling game with some rogue-like elements. There are five levels to beat, each ending with a boss fight. On a perfect run it would probably take about an hour to finish it, but in reality it will likely take you 10-20 hours (or more, depending on the difficulty you’re playing at). The game is very challenging on ‘Disciple’ and almost impossibly hard on ‘Master’. You’re supposed to fail again and again, learning to do better in the process, until you really master the mechanics. 

Each time you die, your death counter increases by one and you age the amount of years equal to the death counter, so there’s a limit to how many times you can die. You can always replay already beaten levels to try and finish them at younger age to have more room for error moving forward. Unlocked skills stay with you when you restart a level or even start a new game.

The combat mechanic is very good. It’s responsive, fluid and cinematic, lots of different moves depending on your surroundings, weapon you hold, etc. It does get somewhat repetitive eventually, but it manages to stay fresh for a good while. The controls are simple and comfortable even on mouse & keyboard. The level design in Sifu is amazing and the soundtrack is very good.

If you like to challenge yourself and try and fail again and again, until you master the game, you’ll probably enjoy this one. If not, you might enjoy short (but very fun) experience playing on lower difficulty.

Ok, so.. After completing the game with the "Secret" ending on normal difficulty, I can say that I somewhat regret playing it. First, the reasons why I kept playing for so long (why I like the game that is):

- The game is very stylish. It has atmosphere of the old Chinese martial arts movies, the combos and finishers are satisfying, the enemies' design is perfect - memorable but disposable.

- The gameplay is quite challenging, I love it. You are basically a glass cannon, every enemy has potential to finish you in 2-3 combos, and bosses can do that just in several strikes, but at the same time you have enough evade and punish to go through hordes of enemies

- Arenas mode. In my opinion, they are actually more interesting than the story mode, they offer a good amount of variety and challenge.

- Art gallery level. It's amazing, artistic and very pleasant to play through. Bravo.

Now, the list of the things that led to eventual dislike:

- The plot sucks. While the premise of the plot is simple, but solid, the story itself is boring and bland. It's made in "you start with zero knowledge about why things happen and search for clues" kinda way, but 80% of the clues is garbage that gives no actual info, the amount of actual information is disappointingly little, and there's no sense in what is going on at all. The plot "twist" isn't a twist at all, it's just very basic and vague justification.
In fact, "vague" is the best word to describe the plot. The developers apparently decided that if they would make it vague enough, gamers will imagine the plot to be better than it is.

- The main aspect of the combat is to learn attacks of the enemies to effectively dodge and parry them, and that just takes too much time. Training mode, an extremely important aspect for games like this one, is almost useless - it gives you a task and ends as soon as you'll get it right once. So you'll either have to boot it again and make 40 seconds pause each attempt, or just train during the game itself, restarting dozens of times, just to train.

- Out of 5 levels, one is amazing (art gallery), one is decent (the club), and the rest are forgettable and bland garbage. I don't think I would've actually notice it, if there weren't for good levels to make such a contrast. The rest are just so bad in comparison, it's stunning.

- Artificial difficulty. Again, I like that this game is challenging, but some of the grind to learn dodges and parries is due to cryptic and deliberately difficult to read attack telegraphs. Some attacks are almost instant with little to no telegraph at all (like the gut kick), some - has unexpected pauses in animation, just to mess your parry time, and some has sequence of quick attacks, that correspond poorly with animation - it may show one attack, but you have to parry twice, and some - show 4 attacks, but you have to parry three times. Also, camera is bad, it may change angle unexpectedly, and that messes up your input directions, because they depend on the camera. 

- Cheap bosses. The first two are OK, fairly easy even. The rest three bosses are made in a way that you have to remember their attacks by heart to get through them without dying 5 or more times. They don't really change your perception of the game, nor do they demand to learn new tricks - just dodge and parry their attacks with unobvious animations and cryptic telegraphs. The last boss is somewhat interesting, but still very cheap, because he takes away some of your arsenal, and you're basically left with fewer attacks against a guy with tons of health and combos that are near-impossible to interrupt - most of your parries don't stop him. 

- Basically no proper ending. Getting a true ending is difficult, so it is beyond disappointing that there's no decent cinematic, no proper epilogue, there's no explanations to the weight of your actions. This is just lazy, and unsatisfying. There's supposed to be a big lesson here against violence, but it's not only ridiculous (let's forgive a bunch of murderers, two of which killed a child, because that'll make me a better person, sure!), but it's self-contradicting, because in order to forgive 5 criminals, protagonists murders hundreds of people on his way to them, some of which are literally asking the protagonist not to fight.

It's not a bad game, but it's a game with a ruined potential. It could've been SO much better if the developers had more resources and/or talent.

This game is the closest I've seen to the inverse of "wide as an ocean, deep as a puddle". There are only 5 levels to the main game, and 5 different enemy types not including their Elite versions. The main draw of this game is skill improvement; learning the enemies' fairly simple combos in order to punish appropriately with dodges, parries, or even attacks with innate dodge properties. If this sounds remotely fun to you, then don't hesitate to try this game. While it's fairly contained in terms of combat, it has a surprising amount of depth and skill expression that you may not even begin to scratch the surface of after 50 hours. For any potential new players though, there are some issues I have with the game that I feel will push some away from being too punishing and obtuse.

	Each time you die, a counter will tick upwards from your starting age of 20 and continue stacking, carrying over from each level. Each decade milestone you reach will lower your maximum health, but increase your damage. Once you reach the ripe old age of 70, it's game over. A majority of your game time will be from replaying levels to master them, lowering your death count, optimizing your combos, and overall just improving at the combat. While this sounds fairly interesting on paper, as someone who has played this game to death both on Steam and the EGS, I personally think this system is backwards and creates a negative feedback loop.

	Firstly, I believe the aging system to be way too punishing for a new player, while experienced players will just straight up completely ignore it. While it succeeds in its intended purpose of preventing an unskilled played from limping their way through the game without taking the time to improve, it fails just about everywhere else.

	[b][u]1.[/u][/b] As previously stated, aging milestones lower your max health but increase your damage. As a new player who is consistently dying a lot, this does absolutely nothing other than making it easier and easier to die, accelerating the fail state against you. As an experienced player, who will very rarely die, this system can be completely ignored and will never come into play.
	[b][u]2.[/u][/b] Aging milestones lock away parts of the skill tree. For a new player this obviously makes the game harder to play, as you must level perks 5 times each before being permanently unlocked, and if you haven't gotten these skills before completing a level and reaching an older age, you must either replay the stage to keep your age low or continue on and forego the skill, some of which are incredibly expensive but also powerful. As before, an experienced player will never have to interact with this system.
	[b][u]3.[/u][/b] Aging too much discourages you from even continuing on to a new level. Since age carries over between levels, and can only be lowered by completing the prior level with a lower age, lowering the next level's age retroactively, there's literally no point in even attempting the next one you've unlocked before improving on the last one. Barely beating a boss while you're low health and at the maximum age doesn't feel rewarding nor exciting, it just leaves a sour taste in your mouth knowing it doesn't even matter. 

	Those of you familiar with the game might be thinking to yourselves that the obvious explanation for these systems is to encourage you to replay levels to improve your age, while improving your skill at the same time, in a sneaky, albeit ham-fisted way to force you to improve. While I've made it clear that I dislike this system because players who have improved at the game and rarely die will never have to interact with these systems ever again, I dislike it even more for another reason; it's completely unnecessary.

	These 3 mechanics I've just discussed are only in the game to justify their own existence. 
	If I am dying a lot and limping through stages with an obscenely high age, I already want to improve. I don't need extraneous systems to force me to replay levels for fear of punishment. 
	I don't need my health to be lowered permanently or to start losing my skills; if I am reaching a new level at the age of 60, I'm already going to replay the last level. 
	If the 3rd stage's boss got me to age 65 before beating them, I'm not going to continue on to the next level. Depending on your death count, you may only be able to die twice in the entire stage, including the boss fight, before a game over.

	Lastly, I think the max health and damage mechanic of aging should be reversed to be less punishing. If you're dying a lot, having higher max health but lower damage would make it easier to learn from your mistakes and improve your pattern recognition of enemies; fights would take a bit longer because of your lower damage, but you would have more durability so as to not have an encounter you're still unfamiliar with beat you into the ground.

	If you've made it through this wall of text, just know that I don't dislike Sifu; quite the opposite in fact. Despite how negative this review may seem, it comes out of love for the game and a desire for it to be improved even further, whether in an update or a sequel. The combat has great depth, is incredibly fun to master, and with the most recent update including an Arena mode there is more than enough content to consider the game a full package. I just wanted to point out the issues I had when I first started the game about 6 months ago on the EGS, and that I've seen crop up repeatedly as my friends started playing as well.

[h1]Fantastic, tightly designed combat system that revolves around your own self-improvement, complemented by amazing art direction - The Museum is a sight to behold.[/h1]


[b][u]Combat[/u][/b]
Combat and movement are deceptively simple - light and heavy attacks, block and deflect/parry. Directional movements determine your attacks and whether your back is facing an enemy. 


Deflecting is pressing block at the last second before an attack lands, negating some "structure" damage, think of it as maintaining your form and posture during the fight. Deflecting certain attacks will result in a parry, stunning the enemy temporarily, and allowing you to counterattack however you choose. Hitting enemies and deflecting attacks will build their structure bars and when theirs breaks, allows you to execute them with a finisher that is contextual to the environment (you can adjust the camera distance to maintain vision on remaining enemies).


If not deflecting or blocking, you must [b]AVOID [/b]attacks. There are two directions for this - hold block + [b]up/down[/b]. Pressing [b]UP [/b]during block will avoid low attacks as you lift your leg up, whereas pressing [b]DOWN [/b]will avoid all high attacks as you move your body down or sideways. These avoids will allow you to whiff punish and can help lower how much structure damage you've accumulated. [b]DODGE[/b], on the other hand, is a full movement in any direction but will not allow proper punishes on enemy attacks.


In terms of skills, you will unlock them as you spend XP between shrines located in the levels or at your home. Each skill will be available when you spend on it but will lose it upon death unless you have spent on any skill 5 times for a permanent unlock. E.g., I buy the leg sweep once and then die. I can't use the sweep again but the game will list it as having been purchased once so you can spend on it again to use it, and eventually get to 5 purchases and you will never lose it upon death.


As an additional note, your character doesn't have many i-frames to hide behind so you must choose your actions carefully, accounting for how enemies are surrounding you. Some animations will allow you to avoid high attacks.




[b][u]Structure of the game[/u][/b]
The game pits you against 5 levels and bosses that you must progress through, each death will increase your death counter by 1 which is then added to your current age starting at 20. E.g., dying at 20 will age you to 21 and your death counter to 2. Dying again will age you to 23, death counter to 3, etc. Your death counter is reduced by one at certain encounters, at upgrade shrines, or [spoiler]between boss phases.[/spoiler] Every 10 years from 20 will reduce your health and increase your damage and you have 5 decades to survive.


The levels are as follows:
The Squats
The Club
The Museum
The Tower
The Sanctuary


Let's say you have completed The Squats and you are 28 years old when you get to The Club with only one upgrade to your structure bar. If you choose to return to The Squats, you will revert back to 20 years of age and no upgrades. If you complete The Museum at 50 years with multiple upgrades, again, returning to The Club will revert you to 28 with only your upgrades at that point.


This is all to encourage you to improve each run through a given level and keep your age to a minimum, as reaching 70 will be your last chance. It also gives you more room to re-select upgrades or increase how much you can spend on them.


[b][u]Arenas update[/u][/b]
The arenas are set levels (completely separate from story) with conditions and challenges to fulfil - these will unlock the next arenas progressively.


This update also provides gameplay modifiers (available in story) which affects both you and enemies, for easier or increased difficulty.




[b][u]Art and music[/u][/b]
The art direction and music are utterly amazing. You just have to see and hear it for yourself. There are so many great visual compositions found in the levels and some also change with your combat, it's such a treat to traverse each level.




I hope this has been informative and helpful.
