It is a genuinely engaging martial arts game with rogue-ish elements. The combat is very tight and encourages patience and weighted decisions - simply mashing buttons will not fly.
The difficulty is more about maintaining your own focus rather than upgrading your character. The aging mechanic is both unique and impactful: there is always a feeling that making mistakes takes away something from you aside from general health loss.

And yes, the combat system is incredibly tight, and emulates real-life kung fu moves suprisingly well.

Trust me though, it is worth it as this game has an IP Man and old-school Jackie Chan feeling that rewards you with exciting gameplay, combos and difficult enemies to truly test your skill. This has been a very fun experience as it was something new and exciting to learn, play and master.

The gameplay is essentially Arkham Asylum++ but instead of enemies taking turns punching at you, they all come at you together, meaning you have to be strategic in separating the enemies.

Each enemy has a flow-chart they follow that determines what attack they will make, with some attacks branching into multiple options, meaning you have to either find a solution for both of them or react to whichever comes out, but the game generally doesn't give you enough time or feedback to let you know which is coming out.

This means the game is hard, not because executing any of the combat is hard, but because you have to learn the flowcharts of each enemy and figure out the appropriate response to each step in the flowchart.

An example of something that makes the game artificially difficult is the evasion system. Sometimes you have to evade upwards and sometimes you have to evade downwards, but the difference between which it is is extremely subtle and combined with having little to no time to react means you just have to find an alternate solution.

Another problem is the targeting/camera system, which other people have pointed out. Backwards/forwards is not determined by the direction of the PC but is simply always up on keyboard/stick, meaning that moves which require directional input are unreliable because what the player thinks forward is and what the game thinks forward is will be different at times.

The game is extremely beautiful and the gameplay is really close to being good. I suggest playing on easy (student) difficulty because it just isn't worth it to beat it on master (hard). The game only has a ~20-30% completion rate, so make sure you take the easy way out when possible.

Very enjoyable combat system paired with a great soundtrack and a simple yet beautiful story (depending on which one you choose that is) with a lot of replayability especially with the arenas update that add. the arenas and new modifiers and cheats that you can use in the story's levels to make them harder or easier and more enjoyable. 

Fairly short overall but designed to be replayed either because you got a key item that you need to use in a previous level, improving your score or keeping your Age Counter as low as possible. 

The Age Counter is the death mechanic where everytime you die, the counter goes up. 
You start with 20 years and each time you die the counter doubles, so from 20 you go to 21 then from 21 to 23 and so on. The counter though gets reset if you complete a segment in the level while the age stays the same until the end of the game. So if you're having trouble with a level due to the fact that you do not have enough retries anymore, since the maximum age reachable is 70 then your best bet is to replay a previous level and try to die less times or not at all.
Though the older you get, the more damage you do, with the downside that some abilities become become locked and you have less health. Overall I never felt the counter being annoying or boring, kept me wanting to perfect my performance and try to finish the level without dying.

The game does not hold your hand (unless you play the lowest difficulty level which I personally didn't try) but it is very rewarding, I felt that since I started playing the game I got better everytime.

Once the game is over and you either do not want to replay the game again (which honestly you should to at least get the other ending which is very well done) there is the arena mode which features new levels with different goals: either you gotta survive and try to not die, defeat marked enemies, capture zones or just complete the level with as little time as possible.
Intuitive, satisfying and doesn't overstay it's welcome.

Rare are the moments where an attack hits you that you didn't allow through either distraction or misinput, the soundtrack is incredible, the level design is engaging and unique through all of the stages, and the progression through unlocking moves, learning what works, and honing your ability against the different enemy types never gets boring.

Though there are only five levels in the main story, the Arena section adds another nine stages that, while shorter (and downright claustrophobic in some cases), add on a considerable amount of playtime to a game that already had plenty of replay value.

On the whole, though it's a short experience overall to see all the content (I was able to perfect it in thirteen hours, although this may vary depending on personal skill and dedication to getting achievements), the crunchy visual feedback, ability to perform truly spectacular sequences at your own leisure, and the sheer amount of toying with the game that can be done through the modifier menu keeps me coming back.

Great challenging combat, super satisfying to play. The game makes you earn progress, which contributes to a very rewarding experience when you start getting better at the mechanics.

The good:

The combat is extremely satisfying and you can really feel yourself become more powerful as you master the difficulty curve. There are a few unlockable perks, but your character doesn't so much get stronger as you just get better and the game really rewards you for it.

Parries feel incredibly snappy and the follow-on punish attacks appropriately devastating. Movement controls are fluid and responsive. You have sizeable array of combos and moves to choose from - I'd say just the right amount of variety without it becoming intimidating and unmanageable, just about every move serves some sort of useful purpose in defeating the different enemy types the game throws at you.

Boss fights are tough but rewarding, they all have some sort of flaw in their attacks that can be taken advantage of to win without dying.

The levels are well designed with an excellent amount of visual diversity between each of the five levels. Progressing through each level and recovering keys and other objects open up new shorter routes to get to the boss chamber, this usually comes at the cost of not being able to unlock all the shrine perks so its kind of a tradeoff that I feel is pretty fair in its execution.

Visually the game is extremely pretty to look at, the user interface is clean and minimalistic, the art style is gorgeous in its simplicity, and each level feels incredibly diverse with a good mixture of open and claustrophobic spaces.

The Bad:

The camera needs work. There were points in the game where I felt fighting the camera was harder than fighting the enemy. It's not so bad when fighting in wide open spaces, which the game is fortunately generous with, but if the fight gets close to a wall or corner things get very claustrophobic very quickly as you lose situational awareness. 

The game seems to have some sort of "smart" camera system where it will occasionally pivot or snap to a rail when cinematically appropriate, most of the time the desired effect was achieved and it looked cool as hell (like the hallway scene) but sometimes the script that governs the camera decides to wrench the whole thing in a bad direction when you want it to go the other way and you end up wrestling with the AI cameraman usually to the detriment of the fight.

There were a few annoying progress blocking bugs, the most egregious being when a certain boss goes into their second phase but just straight up doesn't spawn inside the fight area, this fortunately only occurred once with that boss, and on a few other occasions when an NPC didn't spawn preventing a door from unlocking.

The game is fairly short, but its a fair length for the listed price, my only gripe is I wanted more :)

A modern-gen 3D beat'em up with old school design principles and modern sensibilities.

In short that is what Sifu is.; it's challenging, punishes you for button mashing, and rewards patience and timing. Sifu has a simple revenge premise; but as you get further into the game, it also has principles of Eastern Martial Arts philosophy in the story. I won't delve too much into it, but it has themes of martial morality. At the heart of Sifu's gameplay is the combat system which includes: light attacks, heavy attacks, dodges, parries, blocks, and counter-attacks. Think of it as a mix of Sekiro, the Arkham Series, and a little bit of DMC. Like Sekiro, this game is all about breaking your opponents' structure (posture in Sekiro) which leaves them vulnerable to a takedown that will remove them from the fight. Like the Arkham games you're put into arenas against multiple opponents and you can counter. The countering is more complex in Sifu, instead of hitting a button right when the enemy is about to strike you, you have to parry or dodge an enemy's combo and then counter when there's an opening, also known as punishing in the Sifu community. There's also a skill tree and a progression system which is where the modern mechanics come into play, taunting your opponents increases your score multiplier allowing you to gain XP faster for those shrine upgrades to make your character more powerful. Perhaps the most interesting mechanic in Sifu is the aging system, unlike in old school beat-em ups where there was as lives system, Sifu has an aging system where each time you die, you age, as you get older your character deals more damage, but the flip side to that coin is you can take less damage. So if you play offensively when you're younger and getting your ass kicked, as you get older and become a glass cannon, you may have to adapt your playstyle to one that's more defensive. While not a game for everyone, if you're a fan of the aformentioned games, Yakuza, Sleeping Dogs or Asian Martial Arts movies, or more recent Western shows like Daredevil, or the John Wick movies, Sifu is another game to add to your collection. It's not a very long game, but it does have a lot of replay value, an arenas mode, mod support and your first run through the campaign will take longer than the 4-6 hours.

Where do i start, i suppose to begin with the game is obviously very closely designed in a similar fashion to absolver; a game i actually negatively reviewed. What makes this game different? Everything, from the bottom of its core its completely different and way better, for starters its single player aspects that was so much more enjoyable in this style. It feels like absolver was purely a test run before making this one and it shows, everything has completely been revamped and remade and it simply just works way better. 

But enough of the comparisons, what of the actual game at its core. The story is clear and simple but not a very big strong point in the game, its pretty much just a revenge story with two options to play as a bad guy or good guy. Seeing how the story is so simple i dont have much to say about it so lets move on to the actual stuff which is combat. The game does martial arts a justice (coming from someone who has done it before), every move is carefully captured and the flow never seemed to be off at all. Every mistake i made it felt like i was making it, every misplaced dodge or block seemed to feel like it was me and not the game at fault which is a huge bonus seeing how other games get this wrong all the time. I usually dont use vibration in my games but with this one i felt it was needed to feel the full impact of every strike and hit, every block and counter i could literally feel through the controller which was nice. It felt so good when i finished someone, when i carefully blocked or parried, when i dodged and done any sort of counter i felt it, i cant possibly say anything negative about the combat at all. Upon that i even noticed sometimes i would actively move my head or body with the flow of the combat; thats how involved i was in the action and i think that speaks volumes. 

The difficulty, at the beginning it was fun, the first level was almost a breeze and the first boss really showed the importance of parries, dodges and timely blocks alongside counters but not so hard. The second area was a bit harder with the introduction of double lifed enemies, however still not that big of a problem and i actually enjoyed the more lengthy mission. With this boss it really showcased the importance of timely dodges but not so much anything else just there for you to protect dodges, id say more easier than the first boss was. Although after this it got really weird for me, the missions after this one was beautiful to look at and very interesting and unique, the regular enemies werent that bad either but what comes with complaints were the bosses after the second boss you encounter. The third boss for some reason was very odd, throwing out attacks randomly very far away from you as if they expected you to run like a mad man towards her, then she uses although predictable moves at its core but randomly coded so you have to notice the body movement more. She uses a long range chain scythe and even blocking makes you take damage which so far completely negates everything youve learned this far, why? i have no clue. Then onto her second phase which forces you to parry her moves that come out in miliseconds, i suppose you could try and try again to learn the exact timing but even if you do you only get one hit on her and sometimes you dont even get a hit in after parring which flaws its own combat system. After that the next boss is exactly the same, lazy, but with a different moveset that forces you to use running attack spam to get one hit on her then she flies away ... somehow. I feel like these two bosses were the worst experiences of my game and could be a prime example of at least having structure damage be permanent on enemies instead of it lowering so fast just for the sake of extending this already short game. The final boss ... man i dont know about anyone else but this dude kicked my ass 20 times before i had to literally lower the difficulty just so i could have a chance. Its as if they expected you to have 500 hours already spent in the game because he combos you so fast that if you blink youre already dead, if you make one mistake youre dead, if you even throw out a attack he backsteps miles away then taunts you and if you throw a attack at all he counters it and then ... yep .. youre dead. The only time i ever landed a clean hit on this dude was when i lowered the difficulty, and i was playing on normal this entire time. This is when i thought the game was pretty badly made because at what point did anyone before him be this insane? not once, they didnt prepare you at all for this kind of fight and at the first 15 tries i thought i was playing a completely different game. I even died to this dude on easy mode a few times, was that fun? me personally i didnt find it fun at all. If i can play a game throughout 99% of it on one difficulty and then practically be forced to lower it on ONE ENEMY then yeah they should've done something different. 

The overall negatives that i saw after that was the camera, i constantly fought with it the entire game and i constantly got backed up into a wall where my camera would then get glitched into the wall and i couldnt see so i was then beaten to death. I then sometimes had glitches where the boss of a area would get stuck and refuse to enter the boss area, practically forcing me to restart the entire mission which was annoying but other than that nothing else.

overall - 8/Sifu

If I could describe Sifu in a single phrase, it would be "Extremely challenging, extremely fun." 
The most important thing you need to know is that you will die A LOT in this game, and each time you do, your character gets older. As each decade passes, your maximum health goes down and your damage goes up. If you die past age 70, it's game over. 
Chances are, you will be replaying levels so that you can finish one younger than you did before. This is because your youngest age at the end of the previous level is how old you are when you start the next one. To ensure that replaying isn't a slog, the game is designed so that after your first runthrough of a level, you will have access to shortcuts which skip large chunks of the level, if not nearly all of it. If you're someone like me who has played Sifu prior to its release on Steam, the main story will take you 2-3 hours. If you're new, well, the amount of time will vary significantly. Anywhere between 8-12 hours seems right. But if you're itching for more, Sloclap has you covered.
After beating the main story, you have optional "goals" that you can do to unlock new outfits, many of which are references to iconic martial arts movies. There's also an arena mode which introduces a variety of new environments and levels to put your skills to the test.
Overall, Sifu is an excellent beat-em-up game based on a martial art known as Pak Mei, which is similar to Wing Chun. For the layman who knows nothing about martial arts, basically Kung Fu. Its controls are simple but require good timing and general awareness of your ingame surroundings/opponents. If you want a relaxing or easy game, this isn't what you're looking for. But if you're up for a challenge and are a fan of martial arts movies, you've come to the right place.

In a lot of really difficult games, there is some rewarding factor for beating a boss. Some cool armor, better stats, or some achievement. This game has none of that at all whatsoever. You get nothing but a very minor change to your already pretty shitty-looking character, with the robes turning black. All the perks you work hard to gain do not stay unless you buy them 5 times to make them permanent. The difficulty setting really does not do much other than change how much damage you have to do to defeat opponents which is a really shitty way of making the game easier. I understand that making games is hard and giving direction for people to understand easily without making it too easy is hard, but I felt like the scalar for how hard opponents became after the first two places just jumped up so high. Normal opponents were way too easy, then some were suddenly extremely hard without having much difference in how they looked or their fighting style. There are some things that you cannot block but the game does not really tell you that, they just throw it in. Parrying works maybe 30% of the time and deflecting vs constant blocking really does nothing to help you.

There are some good things about the game the actual movements that you're performing are smooth and visually it's pretty appealing. The sound design is not all that bad and the visual art style is cool in its own right. Actual directional audio is not bad either. Between audio and visual, it's really not bad at all.

In reality, if you like games that are extremely hard for really no reason and you have to teach yourself everything with the game giving you nothing is your jam, you would love this. If you are trying to play a fun game that is martial arts geared and allows you to have fun smacking down opponents, this is definitely not the game for you. This takes hours and hours to get good at. Many people I have seen have tried to justify that saying it's close to how martial arts normally take a long time to master but guys, it's a fucking video game. If you want to have fun, take your time elsewhere. If you want to be challenged beyond mental repair and turn your day into a living hell, this is the game for you masochist.

After successfully completing the master difficulty, all current goals and arena challenges, i can safely say that i absolutely love this game and i recommend it to people who genuinely seek a great challenge, like to overcome difficulties and want to put their skills to the test in video games.

Waiting a year for the release of the Steam version was worth it.

The combat is technical and deep, the game is actually hard on the highest difficulty (unlike most modern games), challenging, unapologetic, has lots of difficulty modifiers, graphically it is very nice to look at, stylish, polished and most importantly is very fun to play.

Difficult and challenging games like Sifu are the reason why videogames are amazing, they aren't afraid to challenge the player and they teach us a valuable lesson: sometimes life can be filled with difficulties and obstacles and in order to overcome them and achieve our goals, a person must be willing to work hard, learn, adapt to the situation and oftentimes fall, get up and keep moving forward (something that modern games, in my honest opinion, have completely forgotten to teach us).

I really wish that more games nowadays (from 3A with a big budget to indie games) adopted this mentality.

If i had to nitpick and express what i disliked or my concerns with the game, they would be the following:

1) The current lack of an endless survival mode: This is definitely my biggest concern.
I was expecting Arena mode to have at least one endless survival challenge where the player must defeat as many enemies or waves as possible.

Unfortunately this is not the case, the current survival challenges have all a fixed amount of waves to clear.

It would be a real shame if an endless survival mode won't be implemented in the future.

(Devs, if you are reading this review) I personally posted in the discussions section my ideas and suggestions for a customizable endless survival mode.
Please check this discussion if you are interested:

https://steamcommunity.com/app/2138710/discussions/0/6252726091241784916/

2) The current lack of a Steam Workshop.

3) The avoid command: After +70 hours i still find the avoid command (Guard + Movement) quite inconvenient.
I would personally implement in the options menu an additional way to perform this command, more specifically:

Guard + Interact: To avoid High, medium attacks and grabs.
Guard + Pick up weapon: To avoid Low attacks.

Very similar to how you would perform a counter in the Ninja Gaiden series.

In conclusion, Sifu (as long as you play it on disciple or master difficulty) is a break from the current trend of unnecessary over simplification, constant hand holding and instant gratification in modern gaming.

A true breath of fresh air.

I am conflicted about this one. The combat is fun and satisfying. Art is great. Problems arise when you get to bosses (yet they might not directly relate to bosses themselves), so here's the list of them:

1.a) Game loads very long. It could take a solid minute between "restart hideout" click and you getting the control of your character back.

1.b) Game stutters when entering certain areas. This makes you take some cheap hits in the beginning of the fight which is not ideal.

2) It takes quite a while to return to a boss after you die. I understand, that it ties to the game death mechanic, e.t.c. but whatever the intentions were, the result is that you could end up wasting 5-7 minutes to get to the boss (apart from the 3rd boss).

3) Bossfights are not that well balanced. This comes from an experience beating the game for true ending on Master for first time and then doing a quick rerun of everything on Normal. On Master difficulty enemies are seemingly faster but also gain a lot of optional combos. "Optional combo" in reality is exactly the same combo (in terms of timings and telegraphs) but it can be abruptly ended by some unblockable (they are kinda blockable but always deal a load of structure dmg) attack with barely any telegraph other than "Just look at their limbs lemao". The problem here is that there are two types of unblockable attacks: one requires weave back and punishes weave forward, other -- requires weave forward and punishes weave back. This means that the only way you can reliably fight the boss is to be able to react to the telegraph (which is usually <0.2 seconds from start to damage), read it correctly and then dodge accordingly. This makes it barely possible to dodge even if your reaction time is much better than average since you still need some time to do a proper read. At the same time on normal, enemies either don't have this extensions or rarely ever use then. Recovery time is so slow that you can sneak in an attack and you still have time to read+dodge almost everything, which leaves me wondering if I've ruined the experience for myself by starting on Master difficulty which is far from being fair. 

4) Continuing the Master-Normal comparison, every enemy on master has a combo breaker parry on the 4th (?) attack they take (but sometimes they decide that they will let you have some fun and won't do it) which makes almost every combo useless. Makes you wonder again what master difficulty purpose is.

Overall, I don't think I can recommend anyone play this on Master, however, Normal seems to be too easy to be an engaging a thoughtful experience. Despite this game's designers' best efforts I still had quite a bit of fun, so it could be that Normal is fine if you haven't played the game before, so it's probably a better way to play Sifu.

Sifu is relentlessly unforgiving, I can't recommend it enough despite how hard it made me rage at times. Because for every moment I spent shouting at my monitor, once I had achieved my goals I was overcome by a sense of real achievement and satisfaction.

The learning curve is a sharp one and the game will constantly kick you on your ass until you learn to kick back. I do think there should have been a little more of a tutorial especially for some of the moves that you unlock later, but overall I think with a little persistence it is something that eventually comes naturally.

The combat system is beautifully crafted and never seems to get old. It looks good, it sounds good, and it almost always feels good and fluid, albeit with some occasional, minor setbacks. A lot of the progression in the game comes from you yourself improving as a player. You learn the move sets, timings, and points of interest though-out the game which is almost entirely what allows you to progress. You get further almost entirely because you get better. The majority of the permanent upgrades consist of just giving you more combat moves to add to your arsenal (rather than percentage upgrades of damage or health, etc).

The real highlight of the game which had me almost always in awe is the art style of the game. It's almost a hindrance that the 5 story levels look as good as they do as they were so positively distracting whilst I was fighting! The environment feels authentic, it feels alive and real. You can even interact with the environment as part of your violent crusade and it's obvious a lot of thought has gone into the design, not just aesthetically but functionally too! Each of the stages have their own personality, their own theme, and alongside their diverse bosses, their own hard strategies.

If you enjoy a gameplay style that encourages you to be able to tap into a wide variety of skills in a moments notice, parry/posture/avoid mechanics, environmental utilization, roguelike, in a martial arts setting, then this game delivers excellently in all of these areas. I am amazed at the fluidity of this game and how rewarding it feels to switch between the above mentioned elements. After time spent in this game and getting my muscle memory down to where I don't necessarily have to think, just react, makes it SO fun. With the new update they have added a multitude of other modes. The game takes place over a series of levels which rise in difficulty and complexity as you progress through them, each stage ending in a boss you have to beat to proceed to the next level. Throughout the journey you will gain experience and a level score. The experience can be used to unlock new moves and if you purchase the move 5 times, you unlock it permanently to be used in all future runs. The level score is used to purchase roguelike elements that will expire if you die from age. One of my most favorite features is if you die during a level or perform poorly enough that you want to restart, you don't have to start from the beginning of the game, rather the beginning of the level you are on to try again. Aging stacks in a way where it is okay if you get KO'd here and there, but will severely punish you for repeated KO's in a short period of time as you age exponentially this way. I won't touch on the story, that's for you to enjoy, but I was not disappointed. Level design is fantastic and gives you the option to create room for yourself so you don't get overwhelmed. Soundtrack is very enjoyable. I don't just give a game 10/10 lightly, so with that said, the game is a masterpiece.

[h1]Hyped Up Preamble[/h1]
I knew I'd love this game from the moment I saw it. I was intrigued by the aging by death mechanic, as well as the first trailer actually revealing gameplay right away that looked like it was right up my alley. So for Sifu to finally come out on Steam and being able to play it has been a dream come true. It has surpassed my expectations and I highly highly recommend this game for the following reasons:

[h1]Gameplay: 11/10[/h1]
The most important and impressive aspect of this game is its gameplay, which is weird to say, but needs to be stated in this world of 100 hour open world campaigns with even 100 more hours of cutscenes to sit through. This game sets up its premise rather quickly by letting you learn the basic controls through the prologue that doubles duty as a tutorial for its complex combat mechanics.

This is probably one of the most robust system I've played so far where not only do you have to learn a huge variety of moves and string them together into combos, but you also gotta learn how to use proper defense such as spacing, blocking, and parrying. In addition, you also have a typical dodge as you'd fight in any other brawler, though that's more used for spacing where the real meat of the dense is the Parry and Avoid system.

You COULD just block attacks, but doing that for too long will break your Structure, leaving you defenseless and open for huge attacks. What you wanna do more of is Parrying enemy attacks to break THEIR structures or at the very least, the cool looking Avoiding of High and Low attacks which leaves your character bobbing and weaving their head around to avoid head kicks and sweeps.

This is one of those games where it's easy to learn, but very hard to master, and while what they give you from the outset is already such a robust moveset, you can add to your repertoire by unlocking new skills that all have a huge variety of uses ranging from more crowd control to more efficient damage and more. 

To add to the game's combat is probably one of the best collision systems I've seen in a game where you can push your enemies into each other, even trip them over each other, AND you can make them accidentally hurt each other like if one is swinging a bat at you, and if you duck at the right time, they could end up hitting their own pals so that's always fun!

The limitless possibilities leave for a very dynamic experience in every fight you get into which can provide a ton of replay value. A lot of people bemoan that you can beat this game in 6 hours and if they just wanna be done with games that way, that's fine, you do you. If you don't think $40 is worth 6 hours of your time, then that's fine. But I would argue that to get the best out of this game is to replay its well structured 5 levels continuously learning new moves and tactics as you do, all the while experimenting with different buffs per run.

Yes, per "run."

You see, this game is also a bit of a rogue lite where you can buy certain skills for a run if you need them, but you need to buy them five times if you wanna unlock them permanently for your next run. And for each run you can also choose from a variety of buffs ranging from regaining more health per Takedown and recovering Structure health from Avoiding attacks.

So all in all it's the kinda game that the more you put into it the more you get out of it. Zipping through it in 6 hours is barely even scratching the surface of this game, and hey props to you if you can do it. But the fun in this game is learning how to do those 6 hours more efficiently, maybe even cut it down and some unlocked shortcuts throughout each level.

Yeah, the focus is on combat, but there's some minor exploration as you can get lore notes and keys to certain areas from one level for another which also adds to the replay value and possible speedrunning challenges.

To top this all of there's also a built in video editor where you can record your base gameplay and then apply different camera angles and effects to your fights to create some truly cinematic looking action. There's a lot of YouTubers out there actually who have made super entertaining short kung fu films because of this, myself included, and to be honest, at least 40 of my 60 hours on this game so far have been spent on the video editor. 

Anyways I've been going on and on, let's just that the TL;DR version of this is...

[h1]Story: 5/10[/h1]
A gang of martial artists have killed your father and you've spent eight years training for your revenge. As you hunt them down, if you happen to die, you revive and get older. The older you get, the harder you hit, but the less health you have. Pretty simple excuse for getting to beat up a bunch of people in a variety of different settings from the slums to a high class museum.

Anyways, there's not much to say other than the dialogue is thankfully sparse, though I wish there was just a bit more. My usual gripe with modern games is that the characters just don't STFU and keep talking endlessly about nothing before any actual plot point is made. This game is too straight forward to a fault and could have built on its characters a bit more.

But at the same time, as I mentioned, you can unlock lore related items that tell you a bit about the characters and a lot of their backstories are implied from their very own levels, lore notes, and even their sparse dialogue. Probably a breath of fresh air I really need in a day in age where I feel annoyed with cutscenes that go on forever.


[h1]Graphics: 8/10[/h1]
The artstyle is awesome and while there is some clipping and wonky paired animations, the stand out feature of this is the animations that nailed some great accuracy with various martial art styles and hit reactions that really sell the action. Not to mention, the level design is just immaculate giving so much character to the end level bosses you're swearing your revenge on. 


[h1]Sound: 6/10[/h1]
Unfortunately though, as good as the animations sell certain attacks, the sound effects that go with most of them do not feel impactful enough to truly sell them. They just sound like very light slaps instead of really punchy with a lot of bass and treble to emphasize the impact. Plus the music is more so serviceable for the situations, but not entirely memorable.

So with the great IGN level of math skills, I give this game an...

[h1]Overall Score: 11/10[/h1]
Despite the flaws in its sound design and animation processing, the gameplay really really makes up for where the game lacks in other areas. It really is super solid and addicting and I see myself quadrupling my current amount of hours in no time. 

This is the kind of complex fighting game I've wanted for a long time and I am eternally grateful that Slocap has made this game. It's literally everything I've wanted and more, and while I would have preferred a more closed fist fighting style to feature as the one you use, it's a minor gripe. It doesn't matter at this point. This game is just too damn fun to really nitpick apart for dumb little things like I did with its sound design and story scores.

The gameplay is too addicting and the video editor is such a great addition that I have gotten myself lost for many hours since release just finding ways to make the action look as epic as possible with a variety of different character mods from Daredevil to Desmond Miles. Ah yes...that's where the fun can continue as well...the modding community really helps keep this game even more alive and applying mods for this game is so simple.

Anyways, why are you still reading this long winded review? Go buy the game already if any of this intices you!

If you like over the top martial arts action movies that have kung-fu then, get. this. game. With fighting games being a dying genre, Sifu is a game that makes fighting games what they are supposed to be. Fun and bad***. With 5 hard missions and 3 difficulties ranging from Student (Easy), Disciple (Medium), and Master (Hard). I played on Disciple and oh boy, this game is tough.

The main mechanic of this game revolves around death and age. From the start of the game you start at the age of 20, and every time you die, you get to come back to life.....but with this amazing ability.....there is a catch to this monkeys paw. The catch is when you come back to life you increase by 1 year (20 -> 21) and your age counter goes up by 1 until you fight certain amounts of enemies for the age counter to go down. So if you die again, you go from (21 -> 23) and so forth until you reach the age of 70 where you are officially dead. With this you must complete only 5 missions and beat the final boss all before you reach the age of 70. While it may sound easy, its not. Granted while the difficulty may shy most people away, death is your friend. As with the more you play the more your skills and age can carry over. So even if you do die, as long as you permanently unlocked a skill, you can always use it + re-try levels to beat it at a younger age and carry on over.

However, the combat is amazing. With its versatility. fluidity. and high-skill ceiling. You have many different ways to approach your enemies, you can dodge, "avoid", block, and parry your way through gangs of evil foes. The combat. is stylish and impactful that every hit you do feels like it has some sort of weight to it, the executions and the choreography is masterfully done that you never get bored of takedowns or movesets. The enemy/boss design has so much variety and spice that every fight is stimulating with the final boss being the hardest and the most satisfying fight.

Now some of the problems I had with this game which are nitpicks, are that there are some visual bugs and I wish there were more enemies in some areas. Also that they should have added in more moves. Like I said before, the movesets are fun. But I know there are so many moves in kung-fu that they could have added just a bit more. Other than that this game is a must play and while it is only 5 missions that could take you from 8 - 40hrs or maybe you might never even beat it, even if you don't like fighting games you should 100% try this.

Sifu is what would happen if Kill Bill was less Tarrentino and more Shaw Bros meets Soulslike.  

Like all good Kung Fu films, your master was assassinated and you are out for revenge by way of throwing kung fu hands.  Trick here is, you too were slain that faithful night, but thanks to a magic amulet you were reincarnated and trained for eight years to take revenge.  

If on this quest you should meet your end, you will be revived again only having aged a year, and so it goes.  Do very poorly in this game, your in game character will literally meet a game over due to old age.  

Of course you get levels, perks, and stat boosts throughout your quest to aid in your fists of fury.  One of my favourite options is you can play this game in cantonese or mandarin to add a bit more legit shaw bros flavor.  

The game is as hard as any soulslike though. Even on the easiest difficulty, unless you are skilled in the ancient video gaming martial art known as "git gud", you won't make it very far in your quest.  You will likely restart the game more than once as you learn boss patterns and level layouts.  

You should get Sifu is you are looking for a soulslike adventure on an indie budget and have fond memories of watching 80's and 90's hong kong films.  That's the person this game was made for.  The combo system isn't all that deep and combat can get a bit repetitive.  But the challenge is stiff, the story is good, and the atmosphere takes me back to an age when I first discovered Shaw Bros.  If this sounds like a fun time for you, dive in grasshopper.

Excellent beat-em-up that is held back by needlessly obtuse leveling mechanics. Mostly recommended.

1. When you die, you age. 
2. When you age too much, you lose access to level certain abilities.
3. When you die too much (independant from age), your lose access to level _other_ certain abilities.
4. Some abilities and powerups are learned by finding shrines in levels. Others are purchased by XP, some are not. Others can only be learned on death or in-between stages.
5. When you replay a stage, your progress is reset to what it was at the beginning of that stage.
6. You can unlock abilities permanently by purchasing it 5 times before you age out and die. 

Sound too complicated? It is. 

I believe you are meant to play as far as you are able to each run before aging out, and then go back and try again, hopefully with some permanent abilities unlocked. If you aim for a certain performance on each stage your first play through you will not have a fun time. 

I can recommend the game's combat and game flow, but these weird design decisions hold it back from being a game I can recommend to anyone. If you're on the fence, you probably should be, and wait for a good sale.

Sifu is, to me, a perfect example of a great game ruined by the obsession with difficulty that so many modern developers (and gamers) have fallen into. It's not that it's "too hard" in an objective sense, because anyone who really puts their head down and grinds the systems will eventually be able to reach the end. I put in about 15 hours on the Epic store when it first came out and was able to beat the final level at 22 years old. But even if you *can* eventually "git gud," the whole thing is just layered with so many pointlessly punishing design decisions that suck the fun out of what would otherwise be a great martial arts game. 

Everything about Sifu - the lazy roguelite elements, the incredibly narrow windows for blocks and parries, the huge number of enemies with unclear or easily misinterpreted attack telegraphs - feels like it was designed solely to add pain to every single mistake you make and require you to play absolutely flawlessly. It's just not possible to approach even the simplest encounters casually or with anything less than full attention. And some people might enjoy that, I guess, but for me it was just exhausting. I play games to have fun, and it feels like Sifu is designed with this very entitled attitude that assumes everyone is striving to be the most dedicated try-hard on the planet. Games should *earn* that level of engagement, rather than expecting it from the outset - but Sifu is obviously designed entirely around someone who has decided from the first minute that they're going to spend hours banging their head against the wall, rather than the (much larger) group of people who just want to be able to have a fun time with an inventive and dynamic combat system.

If you *are* someone who loves getting constantly beaten to a pulp by a wildly unfriendly and actively hostile game, you'll probably love this, and I know criticizing that will just get me a bunch of obnoxious comments from exactly that type of person. But I'm just tired of games that are designed to make people think to themselves, "Wow, this is really hard!" instead of actually being fun on a moment-to-moment level. I don't think anyone could actually defend the design decisions being made here just in terms of first-level enjoyment. I thought after a year or so of development, some of the roughest edges would have been sanded down. But sadly, it's the same tedious slog it was last year, so I refunded.

There is a connection between the concept of "time kills" and the game "Sifu" in the sense that both emphasize the importance of using one's time effectively.

In "Sifu", the player character is on a quest for revenge, and time is of the essence. The player must use their time wisely, mastering the combat system and progressing through the game's chapters efficiently in order to achieve their goal. Wasting time or failing to use it wisely can result in the player falling behind or failing to complete their objectives.

Similarly, in real life, time management is essential for success in any endeavor. Just as the player in "Sifu" must prioritize their actions and use their time effectively, individuals in the real world must also learn to manage their time in order to achieve their goals. This includes setting achievable goals, prioritizing tasks, and parrying efficiently.

Overall, the concept of "time kills" is a reminder to use one's time effectively and efficiently in order to maximize productivity and achieve one's goals. "Sifu" reinforces this concept through its emphasis on mastering the combat system and progressing through the game's story in a timely manner.

Title: The Fluidity of Mastery - A Sifu Game Review

When it comes to gameplay mechanics, Sifu has truly set the bar high, delivering a breathtaking experience that leaves players feeling like true martial arts masters. From the incredibly detailed animations to the stunningly smooth combat system, Sifu is a game that has managed to create a perfect balance between the art of martial arts and the world of gaming.

One of the most impressive aspects of Sifu's gameplay mechanics is the fluidity of combat. The developers at Sloclap have clearly put a significant amount of effort into creating a fighting system that is both accessible to newcomers and rewarding for experienced players. The controls are intuitive, allowing players to quickly pick up the basics and begin chaining together attacks in a satisfying manner.

The depth of the combat system is also noteworthy. Players will find themselves experimenting with a vast array of moves and combos as they progress through the game. This encourages creativity and keeps the combat feeling fresh and engaging throughout the entire experience. Moreover, the game's unique aging mechanic adds another layer of strategy, as players must carefully manage their resources and make smart decisions to avoid becoming too frail to continue.

The environments within Sifu are stunning, and the level design complements the gameplay mechanics perfectly. Players will find themselves navigating through intricate, maze-like environments, where every corner could potentially hold danger. This sense of exploration adds an exciting element to the game and ensures that players remain captivated by their surroundings.

One aspect that truly sets Sifu apart from other games is the incorporation of realistic martial arts techniques. This authenticity shines through in the gameplay, making the experience feel grounded and exhilarating. The developers have managed to create a game that captures the essence of true martial arts mastery, and it is evident in every punch, kick, and grapple.

In conclusion, Sifu is a masterclass in gameplay mechanics, providing players with a beautifully fluid and engaging combat system that will leave them feeling like true martial arts masters. The combination of intuitive controls, deep combat mechanics, stunning environments, and authentic martial arts techniques makes Sifu a must-play game for both newcomers and experienced gamers alike. This game is a shining example of how to perfectly blend art and gameplay, creating an experience that is truly unforgettable.

I re-purchased the game for the steam release. I originally bought the game on epic and played it for about 70 hours

Beat it in 2.4 hours on steam release so I could review it with a fresh perspective.

In my opinion, sifu is one of the best action games currently available to play, and don't let my hasty completion of the game fool you, the game isn't easy.

The biggest plus of the game is the engaging gameplay loop, followed by very responsive controls. Little to no input delay, and what helps with this is that you can animation cancel every single move in the game with a dodge or parry, the only way youll miss it generally is if you make a mistake, or if 2 enemies are attacking at the same time.

The game has a rogue-lite + "dark souls" feel to it.

Rogue-lite because of how progression works: 
Moves: You start off with a few moves but can unlock more, and if you put enough exp into a move, you unlock it forever. If you don't perma unlock an ability, you lose it when you game over.

Shortcuts: There are several shortcuts in the game that you get keys for by progressing in the game. Typically you will get shortcuts for previous levels, as to encourage you to re run previous levels to have a better age for the later levels.

Death: Death is also an aspect of the rogue-lite feel, as whenever you die, your age increases, which increases damage dealt but decreases your total health. If you die after hitting age 70 then it's game over for you.

The "Dark Souls" feel is due to how the game forces you to learn. The main philosophy behind dark souls isn't about having a difficult game, but rather, making a fair challenge for the player to overcome. Sifu does this very well, as all of the enemies, and bosses especially, will whoop you at first, but once you mentally slow down and start to read their attacks, it clicks and you can end up overcoming the enemies in a very glorious fashion. Makes you feel like Neo from the matrix but you arent buffed by being the chosen one, you just got better at the game.

The base game, pre updates, was pretty good as is in my opinion, and I got about 60 hours out of the base game.

What got me all of those hours was first, beating the game, about 10 hours for me. Then to get all of the moves perma unlocked was a few hours of grinding, idk how many but it didnt really take that long.

What took me a good long time to do, was beating the game at age 20.

Beating this game at age 20 will harden your soul, and test your resolve, because not all of these encounters are created equal, some are much harder than others, and when you're trying to get through the entire level without dying, you really get dialed into the gameplay, both the offense and the defense.

It was extremely satisfying to finally beat the game at level 20. It felt like I had overcome a huge obstacle, and that all of my practice and learning paid off when I defeated the last boss without dying. I had mastered the game.

Sloclap wasn't done though, and they added in some wild content I never imagined. First, the photo mode/ recording mode. A set of features that should be in most games, and isn't even found in most triple A games. 

Next, they added in a new modifier system, a challenge system, and some new outfits.

Modifier sytstem: You can change the rules of the game to be easier, or harder. Easier would be something like enemies deal less damage, you spawn with a weapon that can't break, etc. Harder would be enemies can attack through your block, you cannot heal, etc. It's there to customize your experience if you want to.

Challenge system: hand in hand with the modifier system and some of the outfits. Unlocked after you beat the game, whenever you complete a challenge you receive coins, which you can then use to unlock modifiers. Other challenges will unlock a few outfits (as of 3/29/23)

Outfits: I don't need to explain this. But what I do need to explain is that some of the outifts change as you age ingame, cool detail.

Then Sloclap decided, they still arent done, and with the steam launch, also game a brand new way to play: Arenas.

These are cool, as of writing the review I only completed 1 arena to get an idea as to how it played.

The arenas are pretty much a variety of game modes that you can play, in a bunch of new combat areas.

The one I played was a wave based mode, where various enemies were sent to me, and I had to complete the arena with as few deaths as possible. It was fun.

From what I have seen, there is also a King of the hill type game mode, and a beat up certain targets game mode.

Something like this is really cool for the game, I never anticipated a game modes type of content update, but Sloclap did it and they did it well. This update also includes new outfits to unlock.

I follow them on twitter, and this is confirmed to not be the last update. Currently there is plans to drop more arenas and outfits to the game.

So, are you convinced? If you like third person action games, you shouldn't pass this one up. It's awesome, and the base price is just $40 too. This game has modern polish, support, and gameplay, it's well worth the asking price.

To succinctly explain the game for those that don't know much about it - 
it's a MASTERPIECE in fighting games, with a pretty nice story and a brilliant feeling of [i]learning[/i] from your mistakes. 
Also pretty novel death counter idea, you're basically guaranteed to not finish the game in "one go" as is standard. 

But that's the leitmotif of the game - mastery. You will redo the same levels, getting better at them both mechanically and by unlocking more skills along the way. 
You will learn the enemy patterns, you will start parrying everything, you will cease to die as much as you did originally.

In the end, you will avenge your sifu, your late father.

Will you learn to kill? Will you learn Wude and understand? Up to you and how much you commit.

[h1]Sifu: A Fighting Game That Proves Decepticons Can Master the Art of Kung Fu[/h1]

[quote=Starscream]The Epic store is garbage. I hate it. So I pirated Sifu until it came out on Steam. Ethics and laws don't matter in this world to a transformer anyway. Sifu is a great game, reminds me of when I defeated the Autobots at Sherman Dam.[/quote]

[b]Sifu[/b] is the best damn thing to come out of the human world since the invention of [i]energon cubes[/i]. It's like they made a [i]Bruce Lee[/i] simulator just for me. This game is so immersive that it made me forget how much I hate humans for a few hours. As a Decepticon warrior, I never thought I'd find a game that could make me feel like the legendary Bruce Lee. But then I played [b]Sifu[/b], and I was hooked faster than you can say "Autobots, roll out!"

The fighting mechanics in [b]Sifu[/b] are top-notch. Every punch, every kick, every move feels like it has weight behind it. The game has a learning curve that will challenge even the most seasoned Decepticon warriors, but it's worth it. The feeling of satisfaction when you finally take down a tough opponent is energon-inducing.

The graphics and sound design in [b]Sifu[/b] are also something to be praised. The game has a distinct style that reminds me of [i]Megatron's[/i] early designs. The environments are detailed and immersive, and the sound effects make every hit and impact feel visceral.

But what sets [b]Sifu[/b] apart from other fighting games is its focus on storytelling. The game follows a young fighter on his path to avenge his family, and it's told in a way that feels like a gritty, human version of the [i]Transformers: The Movie[/i] (the one from 1986, not that [i]Michael Bay[/i] garbage). The story will keep you engaged from start to finish.

[list]
 [*]Sifu is like the ultimate Bruce Lee simulator, it's like you're really him kicking ass and taking names.
 [*]The game mechanics are so fluid and responsive, just like the movements of a skilled martial artist.
 [*]The difficulty level is just right, challenging enough to keep you engaged but not frustratingly hard.
 [*]The combat system is well-designed and versatile, allowing for a wide range of moves and combos to unleash on your enemies.
 [*]The game's visuals are stunning, with beautifully rendered environments and characters that look like they just stepped out of a kung fu movie.
 [*]The soundtrack is epic, with pulse-pounding music that gets your blood pumping and makes you feel like you're in the middle of an intense fight scene.
 [*]Sifu has a compelling story that draws you in and keeps you hooked until the very end.
 [*]The game has a great replay value, with plenty of unlockables and secrets to discover.
 [*]Sifu captures the essence of martial arts and delivers an authentic experience that will satisfy both fans of the genre and newcomers alike.

[/list]

In conclusion, [b]Sifu[/b] is a must-play for any Decepticon warrior looking for a good time on Earth. It's like the [i]Arkham[/i] games, but for [i]Bruce Lee[/i] fans. It's the best damn [i]Bruce Lee[/i] simulator out there, and it'll make you feel like a true Decepticon warrior.

And if you're a fan of [i]G1[/i] Transformers like I am, you'll find plenty of energon to sustain you in [b]Sifu[/b].

[i]The game was completed shortly after the release in 2022 and since there was no level of difficulty selection at the time, this review is relevant for "Disciple" level of difficulty. I've gotten both ending and replayed the game a few times to unlock all the skills and achievements.[/i]

[url=https://www.pcgamer.com/kung-fu-game-sifu-will-be-singleplayer-only-all-about-mastery-through-practice/] The main concept of the game is honing your skill as a player through practice and adversities the game throws at you.[/url] Thus let's look at the game through the lens of the developers' presentation of their project. Since the devs have a very clear vision of their product, which mostly doesn't align with the modern game design, it has to be said that this game is not meant to appeal to the masses.

Sifu is a third-person beat 'em up, which successfully incorporates a few ideas from Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice, which, apparently, are becoming the next trend in the industry, and a peculiar iteration of Freeflow Combat, popularized by the Batman Arkham series, with a few additions and changes.

[b]Pros:[/b]

+ [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tHaODlf6FIc&ab_channel=Sloclap]Complex and deep combat system[/url]:

1) A plethora of defensive mechanics, which absolutely have to be used properly depending on the situation: avoid, dodge, block and deflect. The base of the defensive gameplay is the Structure Gauge, which is affected by blocking and deflecting like this: when you get hit while blocking, the Structure Gauge is getting filled and upon reaching its maximum, the player gets stunned, which most likely will lead to death. Deflecting is basically a perfectly timed block achieved by blocking right before the hit would land. Not only this move doesn't fill the Structure Gauge, but also allows the player to perform effective counter attacks. Each successful Avoid reduces the Structure Gauge meter. Dodges have no effect on the Structure Gauge, but are useful for strategic repositioning during the fight. Such interactions stimulate the player to actively watch their defense status and make the right decisions, as ignoring these mechanics or using them incorrectly will lead to defeat, which in turn will lead to frustration. This specific unforgiving approach to combat makes this game accessible to smaller audiences, but it doesn't make it bad though.

2) The offensive arsenal is also rather varied: many various strikes, which you can tie into combos, throws, focus-attacks (effective special attacks, which spend special points meter), the ability to partially use the environment and 3 types of melee weapons. Overall, there are plenty of ways to improve your skill. [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q2KlxhgYo3c&ab_channel=LiquidDrone] This the the highest level of mastery that I've seen at the time I was writing this text, although obviously you should watch it only if you don't mind the spoilers.[/url]

+ [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w77IYxQpBOw&ab_channel=Sloclap] SSStylish visuals and combat choreography[/url].

+ Difficult bosses which challenge the player's skills.

[b]Neutral:[/b]

• Many references to martial arts movies.

• The high barrier to entry.

• [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3eCCJJ9CCHM&ab_channel=Sloclap]Rather controversial Aging System.[/url] The thing is that the game starts off when the main character is 20 years old. Every time you die, the character is magically resurrected, but ages 1 year. Every subsequent death adds a year to the total death counter, so if you die at age 21 with the counter showing 2 deaths, you get back to life and turn 23 now. The following death adds another one to the counter making it 3 total, and if you die again you're adding 3 years to your current age, which is 23 so you get back to life and turn 26, and so on. It might sound complicated but in practice it's much simpler. Aging 10 years reduces the character's health, but increases the damage output. Although, the main problem most players will face is reaching 70 years of age, which is the final life you get since dying at this age is permanent and sends you back to the start of the level and you're resurrected with the age you entered the level at. Thus, you need to play as clean as possible and avoid unnecessary deaths at all cost to beat this game. Though, considering the overall harshness of the game, this is easier said than done for an unprepared player, which might become a reason to quit, since not everyone will be interested in replaying the same levels to improve their personal scores. It would've been easier to manage that if Sifu had been a full-fledged roguelike, but the devs made it easier by adding an easy mode (Student) a little while after the release.

• The game is a real gem for speedrunners or players who like to improve their own scores. 

• There are various types of collectibles scattered around the levels, which immerse the players into the game's lore. You can also find keys for opening the shortcuts, which are useful for future replays.

[b]Cons:[/b]

- Sometimes the camera selects suboptimal angles which block the view. This is unacceptable for a beat 'em up where you're supposed to keep your eyes on each and every brawler and control the crowd properly.

[b]Incredibly stylish, skill-dependent and absolutely unforgiving indie-action with a wonderful combat system, which you might not be able to beat, but it's undoubtedly worth trying.[/b]
